{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox album | name = A Very StarKid Album | type = Compilation | artist = [[StarKid Productions]] | cover = Very StarKid Album.jpg | alt = | released = July 22, 2010 | recorded = 2010 | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Showtunes]] | length = 33:19 | label = [[StarKid Productions]] | producer = | prev_title = [[Me and My Dick (soundtrack)|Me and My Dick (A New Musical)]] | prev_year = 2010 | next_title = [[A Very Potter Sequel (soundtrack)|A Very Potter Sequel]] | next_year = 2010 }} '''''A Very StarKid Album'''''{{cite web|last=Donahue|first=Ann|title='Glee' Newcomer Darren Criss Reflects on His 'Dream' Week|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/951040/glee-newcomer-darren-criss-reflects-on-his-dream-week|publisher=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=July 30, 2011|date=November 13, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110629194732/http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/951040/glee-newcomer-darren-criss-reflects-on-his-dream-week| archivedate= June 29, 2011 | deadurl= no}} contains several songs from the musical ''[[A Very Potter Sequel]]'',{{cite book| last = Milam| first = Whitney| title = Team StarKid tops Glee and Gaga on iTunes, talks new projects| url = http://www.hollywoodnews.com/2010/07/24/a-very-potter-musicals-team-starkid-premieres-sequel-tops-glee-and-gaga-on-itunes-and-talks-future-projects/ | publisher = HollywoodNews | date = July 24, 2010| accessdate=July 30, 2011 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110718153454/http://www.hollywoodnews.com/2010/07/24/a-very-potter-musicals-team-starkid-premieres-sequel-tops-glee-and-gaga-on-itunes-and-talks-future-projects/| archivedate= July 18, 2011 | deadurl= no}} sequel to the [[Harry Potter]] [[parody]] musical ''[[A Very Potter Musical]]'',Caulfield, Keith. [http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/958920/my-dick-rises-to-become-first-charting-student-musical "'My Dick' Rises to Become First Charting Student Musical"] [[Billboard.com]], March 18, 2010. Retrieved on July 30, 2011. produced by [[StarKid Productions]]Austrone, Xavier. [http://wizardinglife.com/2010/11/StarKid-interview-starship-coverage-a-very-potter-threequel/ "StarKid Interview: Starship Coverage & A VERY POTTER THREEQUEL!?"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110804052901/http://wizardinglife.com/2010/11/starkid-interview-starship-coverage-a-very-potter-threequel/ |date=August 4, 2011 }} Wizardinglife.com, November 22, 2010. Retrieved on July 30, 2011. with music and lyrics by [[Darren Criss]]{{cite web|last=Davenport|first=Misha|title=Darren Criss from 'Glee,' Starkid launch Chicago home with 'Starship'|url=http://www.suntimes.com/photos/galleries/3703284-421/darren-criss-from-glee-starkid-launch-chicago-home-with-starship.html|work=Chicago Sun-Times|accessdate=July 30, 2011|date=February 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110629195958/http://www.suntimes.com/photos/galleries/3703284-421/darren-criss-from-glee-starkid-launch-chicago-home-with-starship.html| archivedate= June 29, 2011 | deadurl= no}}{{cite web|last=McKee|first=Jenn|title= Darren Criss, U-M grad and 'Very Potter Musical' star, will be a new face on "Glee"|url= http://www.annarbor.com/entertainment/darren-criss-u-m-grad-and-very-potter-musical-star-will-be-a-new-face-on-glee/|publisher= [[AnnArbor.com]]|date= October 25, 2010|accessdate=August 7, 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110707144314/http://www.annarbor.com/entertainment/darren-criss-u-m-grad-and-very-potter-musical-star-will-be-a-new-face-on-glee/| archivedate= July 7, 2011 | deadurl= no}} (who also starred in both musicals as [[Harry Potter (character)|Harry Potter]]{{cite web|title=Glee Star Darren Criss Confirmed to Succeed Daniel Radcliffe on Broadway|url=http://www.broadway.com/shows/how-succeed-business-without-really-trying/buzz/157133/glee-star-darren-criss-confirmed-to-succeed-daniel-radcliffe-on-broadway/|publisher=[[Key Brand Entertainment|Broadway.com]]|date=August 1, 2011|accessdate=August 1, 2011}}), and book by Matt Lang, Nick Lang, and Brian Holden.[http://teamstarkid.com/avps.html Team StarKid's Home Page for "A Very Potter Sequel"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718075913/http://teamstarkid.com/avps.html |date=July 18, 2011 }} The album features seven of the twelve songs from ''A Very Potter Sequel'' as well as tracks from others members of the group. Songs from the musical that were absent from the album were later released as the [[A Very Potter Sequel (soundtrack)|''A Very Potter Sequel'' soundtrack]]. The album was released [[Music download|digitally]] through [[iTunes]] and [[Amazon.com]] on July 22, 2010, and was made available on the StarKid Productions [[Bandcamp]] page on August 3, 2010. The album reached No. 14 on the iTunes Pop Charts and No. 27 out of all Top Albums officially topping [[Lady Gaga]] (#29) and ''[[Glee (TV series)|Glee]]'' (#31) on the charts. The album also reached No. 19 on [[Billboard 200|Top]] [[Compilation album|Compilation]]s. ==Track listing== {{Tracklist | all_writing = [[Darren Criss]] | extra_column = Performer(s) | title1 = Days of Summer | note1 = from a ''A Very Potter Sequel'' | extra1 = Darren Criss, Joey Richter, Bonnie Gruesen, Lauren Lopez, StarKid Company | length1 = 2:08 | title2 = To Have a Home | note2 = from ''A Very Potter Sequel'' | extra2 = Darren Criss | length2 = 3:55 | title3 = The Coolest Girl | note3 = from ''A Very Potter Sequel'' | extra3 = Bonnie Gruesen | length3 = 3:16 | title4 = Let the Games Begin | note4 = from ''A Very Potter Sequel'' | extra4 = StarKid Company | length4 = 2:59 | title5 = Those Voices | note5 = from ''A Very Potter Sequel'' | extra5 = Darren Criss, Nicholas Joseph Strauss-Matathia, Brian Rosenthal, Arielle Goldman | length5 = 3:14 | title6 = Stutter | note6 = from ''A Very Potter Sequel'' | extra6 = Joe Walker | length6 = 2:47 | title7 = No Way | note7 = from ''A Very Potter Sequel'' | extra7 = Darren Criss, Lauren Lopez, Joey Richter, Bonnie Gruesen | length7 = 2:02 | title8 = Not Alone | note8 = re-recorded version of a song from ''A Very Potter Musical'' | extra8 = Darren Criss | length8 = 4:19 | title9 = Sami | note9 = from ''Little White Lie'', similar to "Harry" from ''A Very Potter Musical'' | extra9 = Darren Criss | length9 = 3:42 | title10 = Ready to Go | note10 = from ''Me and My Dick'' | extra10 = Darren Criss | length10 = 1:25 | title11 = Even Though | note11 = from ''Me and My Dick'' | extra11 = Darren Criss | length11 = 2:16 | title12 = Sango, Sango, Sango | extra12 = StarKid Company | length12 = 0:24 | title13 = Liam's Got a Phone Call | extra13 = The Liams! | length13 = 0:52 }} ==Personnel== {{Col-begin}} {{Col-2}} ;Featured Performers {| class="wikitable" Class="wikitable" style="width:27em; font-size:100%; line-height:1.2" |- ! position |- |US ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Billboard charts|Top Compilation Albums]] |align="center"|19 |} ==Other appearances == * "Sami" was previously released as part of the web-series ''[[Little White Lie (web series)|Little White Lie]]'' (2009),{{cite web|last=Smith|first=Grady|title='A Very Potter Musical' star Darren Criss talks about his new EP and the future for Team StarKid|url=http://music-mix.ew.com/2010/07/30/a-very-potter-musical-star-darren-criss-talks-about-his-new-ep-and-the-future-for-team-starkid/|work=Entertainment Weekly|accessdate=July 30, 2011|date=July 30, 2010}} and was re-written as "Harry" for the ''[[A Very Potter Musical]]''. * "Not Alone" is a re-recorded version of a song from ''A Very Potter Musical''. * "Not Alone" and "Sami" were also released on Darren Criss' [[Human (EP)|''Human'' EP]].{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/human/id382660889|title=Human – EP by Darren Criss – Download Human – EP on iTunes|publisher=[[iTunes]]|date=July 20, 2010|accessdate=July 30, 2011}} * "Ready to Go" and "Even Though" were also released on the ''[[Me and My Dick (soundtrack)|Me and My Dick'' soundtrack]]. ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.teamstarkid.com/ StarKid Productions] official website * [https://www.youtube.com/user/StarKidPotter Star Kid Productions] on YouTube {{StarKid Productions}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Very StarKid Album}} [[Category:Works based on Harry Potter]] [[Category:StarKid Productions albums]] [[Category:Cast recordings]] [[Category:Theatre soundtracks]] [[Category:2010 soundtracks]] [[Category:2010 compilation albums]]

revision.text:
<!-- Image with unknown copyright status removed: [[image:Ace_of_Aces_Handy_Rotary.jpg|thumb|360px| Ace of Aces Handy Rotary Series]] --> [[File:AceOfAces-Game.png|400px|thumb|right|Original Ace of Aces game showing case, two player books and instruction sheet]] '''''Ace of Aces''''' is a two-player combat picture book game designed by Alfred Leonardi and first published in 1980 by [[Nova Game Designs]].
== Gameplay == Each set includes a pair of small books, one for each player (generally marked 'German' and 'Allied'). These are like [[gamebooks]] in that instead of reading through them, a person is 'at' one particular page, and the book represents a [[World War I]] [[fighter aircraft|fighter]]. Each player turns to the same page number in his book; the illustration on that page shows the view from the cockpit of his airplane, looking at the opponent. Along the bottom of the page is series of maneuvers that can be performed, with page numbers listed under them (while the page numbers are different with each page, the maneuvers are constant).
Each player selects a maneuver. Both players then announce the corresponding numbers. Each player turns to the page number announced by the opponent, looks up his own maneuver there, and turns to the page number listed under it. After both players have done this, they are on the same (new) page, looking at new views of each other. The process is repeated until one player has maneuvered his opponent into the sights of his guns and can shoot him down.
The maneuvers in both books are the same, with each set representing a range of aircraft with similar handling characteristics. Different sets are completely compatible with each other and can be used together, as long as opposing books are selected.
Additionally, a single player can in essence "fly solo" by picking up any single book and executing maneuvers. The result is not unlike using the aircraft pictured in the book's pages as a fixed, non-moving spatial reference point. This provides an easy way for newcomers to the game to get a feel for what each maneuver does, and hence a reasonably quick way to get up to a competitive level of play against opponents.
Gameplay could further be customised by using an included sheet of rules which provided for "intermediate" and "advanced" games. These games added factors such as altitude difference, ammunition supply, windspeed and jammed guns to the basic game (which assumed the guns always worked and had an endless supply of ammunition, and that the players would fly at the same altitude throughout in still air).
Despite what some perceived as a lack of "realism", the basic game was extremely popular and simple to learn, and it could be played anywhere there was room for two people to sit or stand.
== Expansions == *''Handy Rotary Series'' (1980) *''Powerhouse Series'' (1981) *''Flying Machines'' (1983) *''Balloon Buster'' (1985) *''Handy Rotary Deluxe Edition'' (1986) *''Wingleader'' (1988) *''Jet Eagles'' (1990)
==Other games== ''Ace of Aces'' was the first game of this type, but others were done later. ''Bounty Hunter'' used much the same format for an [[western movie|old west]] [[gunfight]] (only one set was released, ''Shootout at the Saloon''). ''Dragonriders of Pern'' used the ''Ace of Aces'' format in a contest to stop [[Thread (Pern)|Threadfall]]. Alfred Leonardi also designed the ''[[Lost Worlds (gamebook)|Lost Worlds]]'' combat book game system which is sometimes mistakenly described as using the ''Ace of Aces'' system. [[Joe Dever]] also used this style of books in a fantasy setting for his Combat Heroes books.
In 1989, West End Games released a set of books with the title "Starfighter Battle Book: X-wing vs. Tie Interceptor", using exactly the same Ace of Aces format: even the shooting pages are the same as those in the earlier game.
==Reception== Nick Schuessler reviewed ''Ace of Aces'' in ''[[The Space Gamer]]'' No. 45.<ref name="SG">{{cite journal|last= Schuessler |first= Nick |date=November 1981 |title=Capsule Reviews|journal=[[The Space Gamer]]|publisher=[[Steve Jackson Games]]|issue=45|pages=35}}</ref> Schuessler commented that "enjoy trying to figure out how this little paper computer always gets you back to the same page with the right pictures showing."<ref name="SG"/> In 1981, ''Ace of Aces'' won the [[Charles Roberts Award|Charles Roberts]]/[[Origins Award|Origins]] ''Gamers Choice'' of 1980<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.originsgamefair.com/awards/1980/list-of-winners |title=Origins/Charles Roberts Award Winners (1980) |publisher=Academy of Adventure Gaming Arts & Design |accessdate=2007-10-16 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080415213107/http://www.originsgamefair.com/awards/1980/list-of-winners |archivedate=2008-04-15 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> and was inducted into the Adventure Gaming Hall of Fame in 1994.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.originsgamefair.com/awards/1993/list-of-winners |title=Origins Award Winners (1993) |publisher=Academy of Adventure Gaming Arts & Design |accessdate=2007-10-16 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071106005056/http://www.originsgamefair.com/awards/1993/list-of-winners |archivedate=2007-11-06 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> In 1999, ''[[Pyramid (magazine)|Pyramid]]'' magazine named ''Ace of Aces'' as one of the ''Millennium's Best Games''. According to that magazine the game is "nothing more than a hex-based single-unit wargame, [but] what made ''Ace of Aces'' great was the presentation. By completely hiding the actual mechanics of the game in the flipbooks, it didn't ''feel'' like a wargame."<ref>{{cite journal| title=Second Sight: The Millennium's Best "Other" Game and The Millennium's Most Influential Person|journal=[[Pyramid (magazine)|Pyramid]] (online)| url=http://www.sjgames.com/pyramid/login/article.html?id=1306| date=1999-12-24|last=Haring| first=Scott D.| accessdate=2008-02-16}}</ref>
== Reprint project ==
The game is long out of print, but in June 2012 a Kickstarter project was initiated to reprint the game, with the permission and cooperation of the game's designer. The project was successful and the game was republished in January 2014.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[[Flying Buffalo]]'s [http://www.flyingbuffalo.com/ace.htm home page] for the game *[http://maverick.brainiac.com/aoa/aoa1.html ''Ace of Aces'' Collector's Guide] by Joseph J. Scoleri III *Gamebooks.org [http://www.gamebooks.org/show_series.php?name=Ace+of+Aces description of the game] and list of available game books *BoardGameGeek [http://www.boardgamegeek.com/boardgamefamily/66/ace-aces list of the games in the series] *{{bgg|798|''Ace of Aces''}} *Duelo de Águias, Brazilian edition, Grow, 1984 [https://web.archive.org/web/20140714183335/http://www.ilhadotabuleiro.com.br/jogos/duelo-de-aguias] *[http://kck.st/KqIUkG Kickstarter project to reprint the game] - June-July 2012
[[Category:Gamebooks]] [[Category:Origins Award winners]] [[Category:Charles S. Roberts Award winners]] [[Category:Flying Buffalo games]]

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=February 2014}} '''Allusion''' is a [[figure of speech]], in which an object or circumstance from unrelated context is referenced covertly or indirectly.<ref>{{cite web |title=allusion {{!}} Definition of allusion in English by Oxford Dictionaries |url=https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/allusion |website=Oxford Dictionaries {{!}} English |accessdate=1 October 2018}}</ref><ref>"A covert, implied or indirect reference" (''[[OED]]''); Carmela Perri explored the extent to which an allusion may be overt, in "On alluding" ''Poetics'' '''7''' (1978), and [[M. H. Abrams]] defined allusion as "a brief reference, explicit or indirect, to a person, place or event, or to another literary work or passage". (Abrams, ''A Glossary of Literary Terms'' 1971, ''s.v. "Allusion"'').</ref> It is left to the audience to make the direct connection;<ref>H.W. Fowler, ''A Dictionary of Modern English Usage''.</ref> where the connection is directly and explicitly stated (as opposed to indirectly implied) by the author, it is instead usually termed a [[reference]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/allusion|title=the definition of allusion|author=|date=|website=Dictionary.com|accessdate=15 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/reference|title=the definition of reference|author=|date=|website=Dictionary.com|accessdate=15 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.britannica.com/topic/allusion |title=Allusion |date=2015 |quote=allusion, in literature, an implied or indirect reference to a person, event, or thing or to a part of another text. }}</ref> In the arts, a literary allusion puts the alluded text in a new context under which it assumes new [[poetic function|meanings and denotations]].<ref name="BenPorot76p107"/> It is not possible to predetermine the nature of all the new meanings and inter-textual patterns that an allusion will generate.<ref name="BenPorot76p107"/> Literary allusion is closely related to [[parody]] and [[pastiche]], which are also "text-linking" [[literary device]]s.<ref name="BenPorot76p107">Ben-Porot (1976) pp.107-8 quotation: {{quotation|The literary allusion is a device for the simultaneous activation of two texts. The activation is achieved through the manipulation of a special signal: a sign (simple or complex) in a given text characterized by an additional larger "referent." This referent is always an independent text. The simultaneous activation of the two texts thus connected results in the formation of intertextual patterns whose nature cannot be predetermined. ... The "free" nature of the intertextual patterns is the feature by which it would be possible to distinguish between the literary allusion and other closely related text-linking devices, such as parody and pastiche.}}</ref>
In a wider, more informal context, an allusion is a passing or casually short statement indicating broader meaning. It is an incidental mention of something, either directly or by implication, such as "In the stock market, he met his Waterloo."
==Scope of the term== [[File:NAMA Tablette 1287.jpg|thumb|right|220px|Backside of a clay tablet from [[Pylos]] bearing the motif of the [[Labyrinth]], an allusion to the mythological fight of [[Theseus#The myth of Theseus and the Minotaur|Theseus and the Minotaur]]]]
In the most traditional sense, ''allusion'' is a literary term, though the word has also come to encompass indirect references to any source, including allusions in [[film]] or the [[visual arts]].<ref name="preminger">Preminger & Brogan (1993) ''The New Princeton Encyclopedia of Poetry and Poetics.'' Princeton University Press.</ref> In literature, allusions are used to link concepts that the reader already has knowledge of, with concepts discussed in the story. In the field of film criticism, a film-maker's intentionally unspoken visual reference to another film is also called an [[Homage (arts)|homage]]. It may even be sensed that real events have allusive overtones, when a previous event is inescapably recalled by a current one. "Allusion is bound up with a vital and perennial topic in literary theory, the place of authorial intention in interpretation", William Irwin observed, in asking "What is an allusion?"<ref>Irwin, "What Is an Allusion?" ''Journal of Aesthetics and Art Criticism'' '''59''' (2001)</ref>
Without the hearer or reader's comprehending the author's intention, an allusion becomes merely a decorative device. Allusion is an economical device, a [[figure of speech]] that uses a relatively short space to draw upon the ready stock of ideas, cultural [[meme]]s or emotion already associated with a topic. Thus, an allusion is understandable only to those with prior knowledge of the covert reference in question, a mark of their [[cultural literacy]].<ref name="preminger"/>
==Allusion as cultural bond== The origin of ''allusion'' is in the Latin verb ''ludere, lusus est'' "to play with, jest."{{citation needed|date=April 2014}} Recognizing the point of allusion's condensed riddle also reinforces cultural solidarity between the maker of the allusion and the hearer: their shared familiarity with allusion bonds them. Ted Cohen finds such a "cultivation of intimacy" to be an essential element of many [[jokes]].<ref>(Cohen, ''Jokes: Philosophical Thoughts on Joking Matters'' [University of Chicago Press] 1999:28f). Irwin 2001:note 8 noted the parallel.</ref> Some aspect of the referent must be invoked and identified for the tacit association to be made; the allusion is indirect in part because "it depends on something more than mere substitution of a referent."<ref>Irwin 2001:288</ref>
The allusion depends as well on the author's intent; a reader may search out parallels to a figure of speech or a passage, of which the author was unaware, and offer them as unconscious allusions—coincidences that a critic might not find illuminating.{{dubious|date=April 2014}} Addressing such issues is an aspect of [[hermeneutics]].
William Irwin remarks that allusion moves in only one direction: "If A alludes to B, then B does not allude to A. The Bible does not allude to Shakespeare, though Shakespeare may allude to the Bible." Irwin appends a note: "Only a divine author, outside of time, would seem capable of alluding to a later text."<ref>Irwin 2001:289 and note 22.</ref> This is the basis for Christian readings of [[Bible prophecy|Old Testament prophecy]], which asserts that passages are to be read as allusions to future events due to Jesus's revelation in {{Bibleref|Luke|24:25-27|TNIV}}.
Allusion differs from the similar term [[intertextuality]] in that it is an intentional effort on the author's part.<ref name="preminger"/> The success of an allusion depends in part on at least some of its audience "getting" it. Allusions may be made increasingly obscure, until at last they are understood by the author alone, who thereby retreats into a [[private language]] (e.g. "Ulalume", by [[Edgar Allan Poe]]).
==Academic analysis of the concept of allusions== In discussing the richly allusive poetry of [[Virgil]]'s ''[[Georgics]]'', R. F. Thomas<ref>R. F. Thomas, "Virgil's ''Georgics'' and the art of reference" ''Harvard Studies in Classical Philology '' '''90''' (1986) pp 171–98.</ref> distinguished six categories of allusive reference, which are applicable to a wider cultural sphere. These types are: # ''' Casual Reference''', "the use of language which recalls a specific antecedent, but only in a general sense" that is relatively unimportant to the new context; # ''' Single Reference''', in which the hearer or reader is intended to "recall the context of the model and apply that context to the new situation"; such a specific single reference in Virgil, according to Thomas, is a means of "making connections or conveying ideas on a level of intense subtlety"; # ''' Self-Reference''', where the ''locus'' is in the poet's own work; # ''' Corrective Allusion''', where the imitation is clearly in opposition to the original source's intentions; # ''' Apparent Reference''' "which seems clearly to recall a specific model but which on closer inspection frustrates that intention"; and # ''' Multiple Reference''' or '''Conflation''', which refers in various ways simultaneously to several sources, fusing and transforming the cultural traditions.
A type of literature has grown round explorations of the allusions in such works as [[Alexander Pope]]'s ''[[The Rape of the Lock]]'' or [[T. S. Eliot]]'s ''[[The Waste Land]]''.
==Examples== In [[Homer]], brief allusions could be made to mythic themes of generations previous to the main narrative because they were already familiar to the epic's hearers: one example is the theme of the [[Calydonian Boar|Calydonian boarhunt]]. In [[Hellenistic]] Alexandria, literary culture and a fixed [[literary canon]] known to readers and hearers made a densely allusive poetry effective; the poems of [[Callimachus]] offer the best-known examples.
[[Martin Luther King Jr.|Martin Luther King, Jr.]], alluded to the [[Gettysburg Address]] in starting his "[[I Have a Dream]]" speech by saying 'Five score years ago..."; his hearers were immediately reminded of [[Abraham Lincoln]]'s "Four score and seven years ago", which opened the Gettysburg Address. King's allusion effectively called up parallels in two historic moments without overwhelming his speech with details.
A [[sobriquet]] is an allusion. By [[metonymy]] one aspect of a person or other referent is selected to identify it, and it is this shared aspect that makes a sobriquet evocative: for example, "the city that never sleeps" is a sobriquet of (and therefore an allusion to) New York.
An allusion may become trite and stale through unthinking overuse, devolving into a mere [[cliché]], as is seen in some of the sections below.
===15 minutes of fame=== [[Andy Warhol]], a 20th-century American artist most famous for his [[pop-art]] images of [[Campbell Soup Company|Campbell soup]] cans and of [[Marilyn Monroe]], commented on the explosion of media coverage by saying, "In the future, everyone will be world-famous for 15 minutes." Today, when someone receives a great deal of media attention for something fairly trivial, and he or she is said to be experiencing his or her "[[15 minutes of fame]]", that is an allusion to Andy Warhol's famous remark.
===Lot's Wife/Pillar of Salt=== According to the Book of Genesis, God destroyed the cities of Sodom and Gomorrah, but Lot, the nephew of Abraham, was given time to escape with his family before the destruction. God commanded Lot and his family not to look back as they fled. Lot's wife disobeyed and looked back, and she was immediately turned into a pillar of salt as punishment for her disobedience.
An allusion to Lot's wife or to a pillar of salt is usually a reference to someone who unwisely chooses to look back once he or she has begun on a course of action or to someone who disobeys an explicit rule or command.
===Cassandra=== In [[Greek mythology]], [[Cassandra]], the daughter of [[Troy|Trojan]] king [[Priam]], was loved by [[Apollo]], who gave her the gift of [[prophecy]]. When Cassandra later angered Apollo, he altered the gift so that her prophecies, while true, would not be believed. Thus, her accurate warnings to the Trojans were disregarded, and disaster befell them.
Today, a "Cassandra" refers to someone who predicts disasters or negative results, especially to someone whose predictions are disregarded.
===Catch-22=== This phrase comes from a novel by [[Joseph Heller]]. ''[[Catch-22]]'' is set on a [[U.S. Army Air Force]] base in [[World War II]]. "Catch-22" refers to a regulation that states an airman's request to be relieved from flight duty can only be granted if he is judged to be insane. However, anyone who does not want to fly dangerous missions is obviously sane, thus, there is no way to avoid flying the missions.
Later in the book the old woman in Rome explains that Catch-22 means "They can do whatever they want to do." This refers to the theme of the novel in which the authority figures consistently abuse their powers, leaving the consequences to those under their command. <!--unnecessarily obscure:Catch-22 as it is currently construed is a misnomer as is "[[Heisenberg's Uncertainty Principle]]" which is actually "[[Schrodinger's cat]]". (This puts those who know the difference in a double bind but not a Catch-22.)-->
In common speech, "catch-22" has come to describe any absurd or [[no-win situation]].
===T. S. Eliot=== The poetry of [[T. S. Eliot]] is often described as "allusive", because of his habit of referring to names, places or images that may only make sense in the light of prior knowledge. This technique can add to the experience, but for the uninitiated can make Eliot's work seem dense and hard to decipher.
===James Joyce=== The most densely allusive work in modern English may be ''[[Finnegans Wake]]'' by [[James Joyce]]. [[Joseph Campbell]] and [[Henry Morton Robinson]] wrote ''[[A Skeleton Key to Finnegans Wake]]'' (1944) that unlocked some of Joyce's most obscure allusions.

"What Is an Allusion?" ''The Journal of Aesthetics and Art Criticism'', 59 (3): 287-297. * Irwin, W. T. (2002). "The Aesthetics of Allusion." ''Journal of Value Inquiry'': 36 (4). * Pasco, Allan H. {{Refimprove|date=June 2007}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = '''ARYA DANCE ACADEMY''' | image =|Caption1 | caption = Arya Dancers | years_active = 2001 – present | genre = [[Dance|Indian Classical/Traditional/Filmi Dance]] * | origin = {{flagicon|USA}} [[Parsippany, NJ]] | Representation = [[Arya International]] / [[CAMI Spectrum]] * | website = [http://www.aryaintl.com Arya Dance Academy Website] | background = group_or_band}}
'''Arya Dance Academy''' was established in 2001 by Rupal Patel, who was seen as a judge on Dance India Dance, USA edition.
Arya's teachers are taught by people such as [[Birju Maharaj]], [[Kumudini Lakhia]], Mrilani Sarabhai, and Sarmishtha Sarkar. They teach classical dance styles as Kathak and Bharatnatyam, to Bollywood, Filmi Fusion, and Indian Folk dances as well as modern classical dance incorporating Ballet and Jazz.
Since 2004, the Academy has been responsible for dancers and choreography displayed at the [[Bollywood Movie Awards]], Bollywood Music Awards, Bollywood Fashion Awards and the Unforgettable Tour. In addition, in 2010, Arya Dance Academy was asked to perform at the 84th annual Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade. This was the first Indian dance troupe to perform in the parade's history.
Arya has taken home many awards from the prestigious dance competition - Naya Andaz. In 2009, Arya Juniors took home 1st Place for the junior category. In 2010, Arya took home 1st Place in Juniors again and 2nd Place in Seniors. In 2011, Arya took home 3rd prize in Juniors and 1st prize in Seniors.
==External links== *[http://www.aryaintl.com Arya Dance Academy, the official website] *[http://www.BollywoodAwards.com Bollywood Awards Official Website]

'''BARGE''', the '''Big August Rec.Gambling Excursion''', is a yearly convention held in Las Vegas during the first weekend of August. It consists of a series of tournaments both of poker and other gambling games, as well as a banquet and a host of informal social and gambling activities organized by attendees. Some of the well-known poker players who have participated either as speakers or players in the no limit holdem tournament include: [[Howard Lederer]], [[Chris Ferguson]], [[Phil Hellmuth|Phil Hellmuth Jr]], [[Greg Raymer]], [[Mason Malmuth]], [[David Sklansky]], [[Mike Caro]], [[Matt Matros]], [[Linda Johnson (poker player)|Linda Johnson]], [[Phil Gordon]], [[Paul Phillips (poker player)|Paul Phillips]], [[Andy Bloch]], [[Bill Chen|William Chen]], [[Doyle Brunson]] and many others.<ref name=cp2006>{{cite web|last=Wheeler|first=Lisa|title=BARGE Invades Las Vegas for 13th Year|url=http://www.cardplayer.com/poker-news/1304-barge-invades-las-vegas-for-13th-year|publisher=Card Player|accessdate=1 February 2012}}</ref><ref name=pnd2009>{{cite web|last=Jones|first=Lee|title=RIP Binion’s Horseshoe Hotel by Lee Jones|url=http://www.pokernewsdaily.com/rip-binions-horseshoe-hotel-by-lee-jones-6794/|publisher=Poker News Daily|accessdate=1 February 2012}}</ref><ref name=lvs1997>{{cite web|last=archive|title=Poker for charity at Binion’s|url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/1997/aug/01/poker-for-charity-at-binions/|publisher=Las Vegas Sun|accessdate=1 February 2012}}</ref><ref name=mm2005>{{cite book|last=Matros|first=Matt|title=The Making of a Poker Player: How an Ivy League Math Geek Learned to Play Championship Poker|year=2005|publisher=Lyle Stuart|isbn=0-8184-0642-9|pages=115–135|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZDyEYLur6f0C&pg=PA115&lpg=PA115&dq=%2Bbarge+%2Bpoker+%2Bgeek&source=bl&ots=zPZ8C6b8aK&sig=9F2AEr2dLtmpz-rY7u98wwjot9Q&hl=en&sa=X&ei=N40oT9WjD8awiQKqr72uAQ&ved=0CB4Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref><ref name=ks2005>{{cite book|last=Scheinberg|first=Kim|title=Tales from the Tiltboys|year=2005|publisher=Sports Publishing LLC|isbn=1-59670-140-4|pages=27, 40–41|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vEIadpv4DYoC&pg=PA72&dq=%2Bbarge+%2Bpoker+%2Bgeek&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Yo4oT8ODMeOeiQLGld3JAQ&ved=0CDcQ6AEwAQ#v=snippet&q=BARGE&f=false}}</ref><ref name=ds2001>{{cite book|last=Spanier|first=David|title=The Hand I Played: A Poker Memoir|year=2001|publisher=University of Nevada Press|isbn=0-87417-490-2|pages=154|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KH2RgiNg98QC&pg=PA154&dq=%2Bbarge+%2Bpoker&hl=en&sa=X&ei=JY8oT-2XMcPXiQLNobGcAQ&ved=0CGoQ6AEwCTgK#v=onepage&q=barge&f=false}}</ref><ref name=ph2009>{{cite book|last=Hellmuth|first=Phil|title=Phil Hellmuth's Texas Hold 'Em|year=2009|publisher=Harper Collins|isbn=0-06-176367-5|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=19BkYuXVALEC&pg=PT301&dq=%2Bbarge+%2Bpoker&hl=en&sa=X&ei=_44oT-GBO4ihiALBjIW-AQ&ved=0CFAQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=barge&f=false}}</ref>
BARGE is formally open to "members of the rec.gambling" community,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.barge.org/barge2010info.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-07-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100701091325/http://www.barge.org/barge2010info.html |archivedate=2010-07-01 |df= }}</ref> but registration must be done in advance over the Internet. BARGE organizers include Russell Fox, Rich Bremer, Jeff Deitch and Stevan Goldman. Former organizers include Chuck Weinstock, Peter Secor, Michael "mickdog" Patterson, Nick Christenson, Bree Goldman and Mike Zimmers.
== BARGE history == The first BARGE was an informal gathering of a small number of participants of the rec.gambling newsgroup in Las Vegas in 1991 during [[SIGGRAPH]], a computer graphics convention. The next year, many of the same players got together and had a poker tournament at [[The Mirage]]. The poker tournament was No Limit Hold'em (as it still is, while additional poker tournaments have been added), and nine players participated. Since then, BARGE has been held at various Las Vegas locations (see below for a list). Attendance has grown steadily, averaging about 200 participants.
In its earlier years, BARGE attendees were interested in Blackjack as much as they were in Poker. Some famous Blackjack players (card counters) who have attended BARGE include [[Andy Bloch]], [[Stanford Wong]], [[Arnold Snyder]] and 'Mr. M.' Since around 1998, BARGE attendees and BARGE activities have centered much more around Poker.
In 2006 BARGE was moved to later in the month of August due to a conflict with the World Series of Poker as some attendees participated in both events. Since then BARGE has returned to its traditional 1st weekend of August.
BARGE is the progenitor of all the other annual "ARG" events, including ATLARGE (held in Atlantic City), ESCARGOT (held in the Los Angeles area), FARGO (held in Connecticut, prior to 2014 at Foxwoods, now at Mohegan Sun), MARGE (held in Biloxi), EMBARGO (Winter Las Vegas event) and others.
== BARGE traditions == Traditions are extremely important to BARGE. For example, Scottro (a prominent BARGE participant) denied that his much-washed originally red hat was actually pink, resulting in dozens of players wearing pink baseball hats at the 2006 BARGE, held at the Venetian. "To Throw Down the Pink Hat" has subsequently come to mean "to challenge someone to a heads-up poker match."
Perhaps the most famous BARGE tradition is "Presto!" as a nickname for a hold'em hand of pocket fives. The term was originated by Frank Irwin (as slang for a blackjack) but its poker meaning is far more widespread, making appearances on multiple sets of commemorative chips, badges, etc.
Other BARGE traditions include multiple poker tournaments, a blackjack tournament, a video poker tournament, the Official ADB Darkside [[Craps]] Crawl, a Sushi outing with Sake tasting, the Unofficial BARGE Smoker and Bourbon Tasting, Karaoke night, and the only known [[Community_card_poker#Chowaha|Chowaha]] games played in casino settings for real money. [[Chinese Poker]] has also been played at BARGE for many years.
After the BARGE banquet on Saturday evening, another tradition is played out. 'Reindeer games' – various exotic poker games—are spread. These games include or have included [[Community_card_poker#Chowaha|Chowaha]], first spread at Binion's in 1997; Binglaha (a variant of Omaha, in which whether the game is played high-only or high/low is determined after the flop betting by a roll of a die), first spread at Binion's in 2003, 'Must-drink, must-toke [[HORSE]]', and [[Lowball (poker)|Lowball]].
Whenever anyone busts out of a BARGE tournament, they are given a round of applause; not as an ironic gesture, but as a thank-you for participating in BARGE. Many players also bring a "bust-out gift," which they give to the player who busted them. These are typically small, memorable tokens, but have included such gifts as a decoupage "Last Supper" featuring Chris "Jesus" Ferguson (the late Don Perry's gift in 2005, the year he won) and an iPad (JK Scheinberg's gift in 2010).
The winner of the No-Limit tournament is traditionally tasked with designing a set of chips for next year's BARGE, with some sort of commemorative design. These chip sets are then sold the next year. The BARGE Chip Committee, currently headed by Patrick Milligan (circa 2008), helps the winner with the logistics and artwork.
== BARGE guest speakers and BARGE locations == Each year, the Saturday night banquet features a guest speaker. Past speakers: * 2017 – Binion's – Thomas Gallagher * 2016 – Binion's – [[Daniel Negreanu]] * 2015 – Binion's – [[Jennifer Shahade]] * 2014 – Binion's – [[Mickey Appleman]] * 2013 – Binion's – [[Stanford Wong]] (Friday) * 2012 – Binion's – [[Karina Jett]] * 2011 – Binion's – [[Mori Eskandani]] * 2010 – Binion's – [[Barry Tannebaum]] * 2009 – Binion's – [[Doyle Brunson]] * 2008 – Binion's – [[Tom Schneider]] * 2007 – Binion's – [[Gavin Smith (poker player)|Gavin Smith]] * 2006 – Venetian – [[Phil Gordon]] "Being Highly Overrated" * 2005 – Plaza – [[Wil Wheaton]] * 2004 – Binion's – [[Greg Raymer]] * 2003 – Binion's – [[Howard Lederer]] * 2002 – Binion's – [[Linda Johnson (poker player)|Linda Johnson]] – Steve Lipscomb "World Poker Tour Preview" * 2001 – Binion's – [[Phil Hellmuth]] * 2000 – Binion's – [[Chris Ferguson]] * 1999 – Orleans – [[Mike Sexton]] * 1998 – Binion's – [[Mike Caro]] * 1997 – Binion's – [[Arnold Snyder]] * 1996 – Binion's – [[Mike Caro]] * 1995 – Binion's – [[Mason Malmuth]] * 1994 – Luxor – none * 1993 – Rio – none
==BARGE No-Limit Hold 'em Champions== * 2018 – Don Rieck * 2017 – Chris Mecklin * 2016 – Becca Kerl * 2015 – [[Jennifer Shahade]] * 2014 – Andreas Wolfram * 2013 – David Lawful * 2012 – Paul McMullin * 2011 – Rich Bremer * 2010 – Chuck Humphrey * 2009 – David Heller * 2008 – Dan Chevrie * 2007 – John Pickels * 2006 – Mordecai Schwartz * 2005 – Don Perry * 2004 – [[Gavin Smith (poker player)|Gavin Smith]] * 2003 – Paul Person * 2002 – Mike McBride * 2001 – Russ Fox * 2000 – Jeff Bartoszewicz * 1999 – John Harkness * 1998 – [[Lee Jones (author)|Lee Jones]] * 1997 – [[Steve Brecher]] * 1996 – Mike Zimmers * 1995 – Tom Sims * 1994 – Dave Hughes * 1993 – Roy Hashimoto * 1992 – Steve Jacobs

[[File:Pieter Bruegel d. Ä. 041b.jpg|thumb|375px|right|[[Children's Games (Bruegel)|Children's Games (1560)]] by [[Pieter Bruegel the Elder]], shows five boys playing buck buck in the bottom right hand corner of the painting.]] [[File:MBI BuckBuck crop.jpg|thumb|225px|right|College students playing the game]]
'''Buck buck''' (also known as '''Johnny-on-a-Pony''', or '''Johnny-on-the-Pony''') is a children's [[game]] with several variants.<ref name="ARE">{{cite web | url=http://dare.wisc.edu/?q=node/70 |title=buck buck | work=[[Dictionary of American Regional English]] |accessdate=20 January 2010}}</ref> One version of the game is played when "one player climbs another’s back" and the climber guesses "the number of certain objects out of sight."<ref name="ARE" /> Another version of the game is played with "one group of players <nowiki>[climbing]</nowiki> on the backs of a second group in order to build as large a pile as possible or to cause the supporting players to collapse."<ref name="ARE" />
As early as the 16th century, children in Europe and the Near East played Buck, Buck, which had been called "''Bucca Bucca quot sunt hic?''".<ref>{{cite book|pages=221–222|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ealms5PGJj0C&pg=PT221#v=onepage | chapter=Johnny Ride a Pony|title=The Big Book of Rules: Board Games, Kids' Games, Card Games, from Backgammon and Bocce to Tiddlywinks and Stickball|author=Spadaccini, Stephanie|author2=John Farnsworth|last-author-amp=yes|year=2005|publisher=[[Penguin (publisher)|Penguin]]|isbn=978-0-452-28644-3}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Hindman|first=Sandra|title=Pieter Bruegel's Children's Games, Folly, and Chance|journal=[[The Art Bulletin]]|date=September 1981|volume=LXIII|issue=3|pages=470–471}}</ref> [[Pieter Bruegel the Elder|Pieter Bruegel]]'s painting [[Children's Games (Bruegel)|"Children's Games" (1560)]] depicts children playing a variant of the game.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.gamesmuseum.uwaterloo.ca/VirtualExhibits/Brueghel/pony.html | title=Game: Johnny On A Pony (Detail from Brueghel's Painting) | publisher=[[University of Waterloo]] | work=''Elliot Avedon Virtual Museum of Games'' | date=February 9, 2010 | accessdate=2011-11-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite book| title=Games and Great Ideas: A Guide for Elementary School Physical Educators and Classroom Teachers |author=Clements, Rhonda L. |page=10 |isbn=978-0-313-29460-0|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jYi0CfWmzpUC&pg=PA10#v=onepage&q |year=1995| publisher=[[Greenwood Publishing Group]]}}</ref>
In the [[United Kingdom]], the game is sometimes called '''High Cockalorum''', but has a large number of different names in various local dialects. These include: 'Polly on the Mopstick' in [[Birmingham]], 'Strong Horses, Weak Donkeys' in [[Monmouthshire]], 'Hunch, Cuddy, Hunch' in west [[Scotland]], 'Mont-a-Kitty' in [[Middlesbrough]], 'Husky Fusky Finger or Thumb' in [[Nottinghamshire]], 'High Jimmy Knacker' in [[east London]], 'Jump the Knacker 1-2-3' in [[Watford]], 'Wall-e-Acker' or 'Warny Echo' in [[West London (sub region)|north West London]], 'Stagger Loney' in [[Cardiff]] and 'Trust' in [[Lancashire]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2007/aug/12/letters.theobserver |title=The Observer - Your Letters |last1= |first1= |date=12 August 2007 |website=theguardian.com |publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited |access-date=25 October 2016 }}</ref> The game is sometimes played in the [[mess|sergeants' or officers' messes]] of the [[British Armed Forces]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pprune.org/military-aviation/245199-mess-games-where-s-original-btw.html |title=Aircrew Forums - Military - Mess games |last1= |first1= |date=24 September 2006 |website=pprune.org |publisher=Professional Pilots Rumour Network |access-date=25 October 2016 }}</ref>
==Other national variants== {{original research section|date=January 2017}} A similar game is played in South Korea (malttukbakgi)[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zWp8NR-wY58]. There is even a statue depicting it.[http://i.imgur.com/aTaya.jpg] Malttukbakgi (말뚝박기) is a game that both Korean girls and boys play up until high school. In malttukbakgi, there are two teams. Team A has one person stand up against the wall and the rest of the team have all their heads up in someone else’s butt/crotch area to form what looks like a big horse. Team B then jumps up onto the human horse one by one, each jumping with as much force as possible. If anyone from any team falls to the floor, that team loses. If everyone stays up, then the person against the wall and the person in front will play a game of gawibawibo (rock, scissor, paper) to determine the winner.
[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7S7t7yRicDA Turkish] [http://www.turkishculture.org/lifestyles/turkish-culture-portal/turkish-childrens-games-750.htm?type=1 game] called Uzun Essek, or "Long Donkey." The person standing up is called the Pillow, or the referee. One team bends over as you see in the picture, then the other team one by one jumps on the "Donkey." If the Donkey can stand the pressure, the first person to go in the jumping team puts up one or two with his fingers. If the donkey can guess the number right, they get to jump. If the jumpers fall to the ground, it is the donkey's turn to jump. If the donkey falls, the jumpers jump again.
==In popular culture== [[Bill Cosby]]'s 1967 album ''[[Revenge (Bill Cosby album)|Revenge]]'' includes a track "Buck, Buck" in which he describes playing the game as a child. He mentions that in his hometown of [[Philadelphia]] it was called "Buck Buck," while in [[New York City]] it was known as "Johnny on the Pony." This track introduces [[Fat Albert]], "the baddest Buck Buck breaker in the world," who "weighed 2,000 pounds" and could cause earthquakes when he ran down the street. The character would later become the basis for the cartoon series ''[[Fat Albert and the Cosby Kids]]'' which includes a buck buck episode (season 1 episode 6). The same story, in a slightly different form, is also included in Cosby's book ''Childhood''.
In the 2014 ''[[Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (2014 film)|Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles]]'' film, the heroes use a game of buck buck as an attack that is key to their defeat of the main villain.<ref>M. Enois Duarte, "[http://bluray.highdefdigest.com/13353/teenagemutantninjaturtles2014.html Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (2014) (Dolby Atmos)]", ''High-Def Digest'' (December 17th, 2014).</ref>

'''''Bumblebee''''' is an upcoming American [[science fiction]] [[action film]] centered around the [[Transformers (toy line)|Transformers]] [[Bumblebee (Transformers)|character of the same name]]. It is the sixth installment of the live-action [[Transformers (film series)|''Transformers'' film series]] and a [[prequel]] to 2007's ''[[Transformers (film)|Transformers]]''. Directed by [[Travis Knight]] and written by [[Christina Hodson]], and starring [[Hailee Steinfeld]], [[John Cena]], [[Jorge Lendeborg Jr.]], [[John Ortiz]], [[Jason Drucker]], and [[Pamela Adlon]], it is the first live-action ''Transformers'' film not to be directed by [[Michael Bay]], though he still acts as a producer.
[[Principal photography]] on the film began on July 31, 2017, in [[Los Angeles]] and [[San Francisco]], [[California]]. ''Bumblebee'' is scheduled for release in the United States on December 21, 2018 in 2D, [[Real D 3D]] and [[Dolby Cinema]].
==Synopsis== Twenty years before the events of the [[Transformers (film)|first film]], in 1987, [[Bumblebee (Transformers)|Bumblebee]] takes refuge in a small [[California]] beach town junkyard, where a teenage girl named Charlie Watson takes him in. However, the two of them soon find themselves hunted by a government agency known as Sector 7, led by Agent Burns. As they run from society, the two learn that Bee is not the only Transformer on Earth, and that the others might not be as friendly.<ref name="Jul2017D" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.tfw2007.com/2011/09/09/hascon-2011-bumblebee-movie-tidbits-348630|title=Hascon 2011: The Bumblebee Movie Tidbits - Transformers News - TFW2005|date=September 9, 2017|publisher=}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Cast== {{main|List of Transformers film series characters}}
===Humans=== * [[Hailee Steinfeld]] as Charlie Watson, a teenage girl who finds and befriends Bumblebee * [[John Cena]] as Burns, an agent of Sector 7 * [[Jorge Lendeborg Jr.]] as Memo, Charlie's friend * [[John Ortiz]] as Powell, an agent of Sector 7 * [[Jason Drucker]] as Otis Watson, Charlie's younger brother * [[Pamela Adlon]] as Mrs. Watson, Charlie and Otis' mother * [[Rory Markham]] as Adams, an agent of Sector 7 * [[Rachel Crow]] * [[Abby Quinn]] * [[Gracie Dzienny]] * [[Ricardo Hoyos]] * [[Kenneth Choi]] * [[Stephen Schneider (actor)|Stephen Schneider]] * [[Len Cariou]]
===Transformers=== ====Autobots==== * [[Bumblebee (Transformers)|Bumblebee]], a young Autobot scout who transforms into a yellow [[Willys MB]] [[jeep]] before switching for a rusty yellow 1967 [[Volkswagen Beetle]]. * [[Peter Cullen]] as the voice of [[Optimus Prime (Transformers)|Optimus Prime]], the leader of the Autobots.<ref name="news.tfw2005.com">{{cite web|url=http://news.tfw2005.com/2017/10/02/peter-cullen-confirmed-bumblebee-movie-351131|title=Peter Cullen Confirmed In The Bumblebee Movie - Transformers News - TFW2005|author=James Dyer|date=October 2, 2017|publisher=|access-date=October 2, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171005013223/http://news.tfw2005.com/2017/10/02/peter-cullen-confirmed-bumblebee-movie-351131|archive-date=October 5, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.movieweb.com/amp/bumblebee-movie-optimus-prime-confirmed| title=Optimus Prime Is Definitely in Bumblebee Movie| author=Ryan Scott| date=July 23, 2018| website=[[MovieWeb]]| access-date=July 24, 2018| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180724033658/https://movieweb.com/amp/bumblebee-movie-optimus-prime-confirmed/| archive-date=July 24, 2018| dead-url=no| df=mdy-all}}</ref> * [[Wheeljack]], an Autobot [[scientist]].<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=2018-10-22|title=Bumblebee Trailer Breakdown With Director Travis Knight|url=https://www.empireonline.com/movies/features/bumblebee-trailer-breakdown-travis-knight/|website=Empire|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181023035049/https://www.empireonline.com/movies/features/bumblebee-trailer-breakdown-travis-knight/|archive-date=October 23, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
====Decepticons==== * [[Angela Bassett]] as the voice of Shatter, a Decepticon triple-changer who transforms into a red [[Plymouth Satellite]] and a [[Harrier Jump Jet]].<ref name="EWeekly">{{cite web|url=http://ew.com/movies/2018/07/13/bumblebee-decepticon-trackers-first-look/|title=First Look: Bumblebee unveils two new Decepticon muscle cars|date=July 13, 2018|publisher=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|access-date=July 13, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180713170612/http://ew.com/movies/2018/07/13/bumblebee-decepticon-trackers-first-look/|archive-date=July 13, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> * [[Justin Theroux]] as the voice of Dropkick, a Decepticon triple-changer who transforms into a blue [[AMC Javelin]] and a [[Bell AH-1 SuperCobra]].<ref name="EWeekly" /> * [[David Sobolov]] as the voice of [[Blitzwing]], a Decepticon seeker who transforms into a red/white [[McDonnell Douglas F-4 Phantom II]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fAIX12F6958|title=Bumblebee (2018) - Official Teaser Trailer - Paramount Pictures|date=June 5, 2018|publisher=|access-date=June 5, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180605113944/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fAIX12F6958|archive-date=June 5, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.tfw2005.com/2018/07/20/san-diego-comic-con-2018-bumblebee-the-movie-panel-368692|title=San Diego Comic Con 2018 - Bumblebee The Movie Panel - Transformers News - TFW2005|website=news.tfw2005.com|access-date=July 21, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180721043814/http://news.tfw2005.com/2018/07/20/san-diego-comic-con-2018-bumblebee-the-movie-panel-368692|archive-date=July 21, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="twitter.com">[https://twitter.com/volobos/status/1035346211392368640]</ref> * [[Jess Harnell]] as the voice of [[Barricade (Transformers)|Barricade]], a Decepticon scout.<ref name="tfw2005.com">{{cite web|url=http://news.tfw2005.com/2018/05/31/jess-harnell-reprises-his-role-as-barricade-for-transformers-bumblebee-364640|title=Jess Harnell Reprises His Role As Barricade For Transformers: Bumblebee - Transformers News|website=TFW2005|access-date=May 31, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180612141135/http://news.tfw2005.com/2018/05/31/jess-harnell-reprises-his-role-as-barricade-for-transformers-bumblebee-364640|archive-date=June 12, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> * [[Shockwave (Transformers)|Shockwave]], a Decepticon scientist.<ref name="Hollywood Reporter trailer">{{cite web|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/how-bumblebee-trailer-redesigns-transformers-a-new-era-1146549|title=How 'Bumblebee' Trailer Demonstrates Best of Both Worlds|3=|website=The Hollywood Reporter|access-date=September 27, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180928043928/https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/how-bumblebee-trailer-redesigns-transformers-a-new-era-1146549|archive-date=September 28, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> * [[Soundwave (Transformers)|Soundwave]], a Decepticon Communications officer who houses a series of minions that transforms into [[cassette tapes]].<ref name="Hollywood Reporter trailer"/>
[[Martin Short]] has a voice role in the film.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.tfw2005.com/2018/04/14/martin-short-working-voice-transformers-bumblebee-362330|title=Martin Short Working On Voice-over For Transformers: Bumblebee - Transformers News - TFW2005|website=news.tfw2005.com|access-date=April 14, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180612140450/http://news.tfw2005.com/2018/04/14/martin-short-working-voice-transformers-bumblebee-362330|archive-date=June 12, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
==Production== On February 12, 2016, it was announced that the sixth film in the ''[[Transformers (film series)|Transformers]]'' series ''Transformers 6'' would be released on June 8, 2018, while later it was revealed that the film would be an untitled spin-off, featuring [[Bumblebee (Transformers)|Bumblebee]].<ref name="FirstAnnounced" /> On November 11, 2016, ''Deadline'' reported that [[Paramount Pictures]] was moving forward with the project by revealing that [[Christina Hodson]] had written the script for the spin-off, and she was one of the female writers Paramount and [[Michael Bay]] hired in the "writers room."<ref name="WriterHodson" /> On March 2, 2017, ''Deadline'' reported that [[Travis Knight (animator)|Travis Knight]] was hired to direct the film.<ref name="TravisKnightDirector" /> In May 2017, it was revealed that the film's story would be set in the 1980s, and that it would have fewer robots.<ref name="TFW2005" /> In the same month, it was announced that it would be titled as ''Transformers Universe: Bumblebee''.<ref name="Expo2017Title">{{cite news|last1=Lesnick|first1=Silas|title=Licensing Expo 2017 - Full Gallery at ComingSoon.net|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/movies/news/851337-licensing-expo-2017-justice-league-costumes-new-movie-posters-and-more#/slide/65|accessdate=July 31, 2017|work=ComingSoon.net|date=May 23, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170731235434/http://www.comingsoon.net/movies/news/851337-licensing-expo-2017-justice-league-costumes-new-movie-posters-and-more#/slide/65|archive-date=July 31, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>

news|last1=Kroll|first1=Justin|title=Hailee Steinfeld Eyes 'Transformers' Spinoff 'Bumblebee' (EXCLUSIVE)|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/news/hailee-steinfeld-transformers-spin-off-bumblebee-1202444749/|accessdate=July 31, 2017|work=Variety|date=May 31, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170801003745/http://variety.com/2017/film/news/hailee-steinfeld-transformers-spin-off-bumblebee-1202444749/|archive-date=August 1, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="SteinfeldConfirmed">{{cite news|title=Hailee Steinfeld confirms part in Transformers spin-off|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/newsbeat/article/40249076/hailee-steinfeld-confirms-part-in-transformers-spin-off|accessdate=July 31, 2017|work=BBC Newsbeat|date=June 12, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180417191428/http://www.pressofatlanticcity.com/attheshore/headliners/steve-martin-and-martin-short-head-to-borgata-for-an/article_7d516048-de98-11e7-9fa4-c7175ccf2b9d.html|archive-date=April video game]] and [[Shockwave (Transformers)|Shockwave]] in ''[[Transformers: Prime]]'' confirmed he will voice Blitzwing.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/volobos/status/1033867788824309760|title=David Sobolov on Twitter|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="twitter.com"/>
===Filming=== [[Principal photography]] on the film began on July 31, 2017, in [[Los Angeles]], [[San Francisco]], [[Vallejo, California|Vallejo]], and [[Mare Island]], [[California]], and was scheduled to finish on November 16, 2017, under the working title ''Brighton Falls''. Filming concluded 6 days ahead of schedule on November 10, 2017.<ref name="Jul2017D" /><ref name="FilmingJuly2017OU">{{cite news|last1=Marc|first1=Christopher|title='Bumblebee' aka Brighton Falls To Wrap Filming In November|url=http://omegaunderground.com/2017/07/23/bumblebee-aka-brighton-falls-wrap-filming-november/|accessdate=July 31, 2017|work=Omega Underground|date=July 23, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170731230803/http://omegaunderground.com/2017/07/23/bumblebee-aka-brighton-falls-wrap-filming-november/|archive-date=July 31, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="FilmingJuly2017DoG">{{cite news|last1=Kaye|first1=Don|title=Transformers: Bumblebee starts shooting next week|url=http://www.denofgeek.com/uk/movies/bumblebee/51005/transformers-bumblebee-starts-shooting-next-week|accessdate=July 31, 2017|work=Den of Geek|date=July 27, 2017|language=en}}</ref>
Later, in November 2017, the film was revealed to have changed its title to ''Bumblebee: The Movie'', as well as having wrapped up filming.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Wood|first1=Matt|title=The Bumblebee Movie Just Got A New Title And A Cool 80s Logo - CinemaBlend|url=https://www.cinemablend.com/news/1724400/the-bumblebee-movie-just-got-a-new-title-and-a-cool-80s-logo|accessdate=November 12, 2017|work=CinemaBlend|date=November 12, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171112233602/https://www.cinemablend.com/news/1724400/the-bumblebee-movie-just-got-a-new-title-and-a-cool-80s-logo|archive-date=November 12, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
===Music=== [[Dario Marianelli]] is set to provide the music score for the film,<ref name="auto">{{cite web|title=Dario Marianelli to Score 'Transformers' Spinoff 'Bumblebee'|url=http://filmmusicreporter.com/2018/05/09/dario-marianelli-to-score-transformers-spinoff-bumblebee/|publisher=''Film Music Reporter''|accessdate=May 9, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180514015656/http://filmmusicreporter.com/2018/05/09/dario-marianelli-to-score-transformers-spinoff-bumblebee/|archive-date=May 14, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> making this the first time [[Steve Jablonsky]] has not scored one of the films in the franchise. [[Hailee Steinfeld]]'s single "[[Back to Life (Hailee Steinfeld song)|Back to Life]]" was released from the soundtrack on November 2, 2018.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop/8482959/hailee-steinfeld-back-to-life-bumblebee|title=Hailee Steinfeld Releases Magnetic Single 'Back To Life' From 'Bumblebee' Soundtrack: Listen|work=Billboard|access-date=2018-11-05|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181103003903/https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop/8482959/hailee-steinfeld-back-to-life-bumblebee#|archive-date=November 3, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
===Post-production=== Visual effects for the film will be provided by [[Industrial Light & Magic]], Catina Creative and The Third Floor with [[Jason Smith (visual effects)|Jason Smith]] and Tony Lupoi serving as the main visual effects supervisors.<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=September 24, 2018|title=BUMBLEBEE - The Art of VFXThe Art of VFX|url=https://www.artofvfx.com/bumblebee/|website=www.artofvfx.com|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181115153802/https://www.artofvfx.com/bumblebee/|archive-date=November 15, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
==Release== ''Bumblebee'' is set to be released in the United States on December 21, 2018 by [[Paramount Pictures]], having initially being set for a June 8, 2018 release.<ref name="Jul2017D" /> The first trailer was released on June 5, 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://comicbook.com/movies/2018/06/04/bumblebee-the-movie-2018-trailer-transformers-spinoff/|title=Transformers 'Bumblebee: The Movie' Trailer Released|last=Anderson|first=Jenna|date=5 June 2018|website=comicbook.com|publisher=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180612140213/http://comicbook.com/movies/2018/06/04/bumblebee-the-movie-2018-trailer-transformers-spinoff/|archive-date=June 12, 2018|dead-url=no|access-date=20 August 2018|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The new trailer was released on September 24, 2018<ref>{{Citation|last=Paramount Pictures|title=Bumblebee (2018) - New Official Trailer - Paramount Pictures|date=2018-09-24|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lcwmDAYt22k|access-date=2018-09-24|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180924125916/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lcwmDAYt22k|archive-date=September 24, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> while its international trailer was released on the same date showing that Bumblebee was formerly disguised into an old [[Jeep Wrangler]] before he became a [[Volkswagen Beetle]].<ref>{{Citation|last=Comicbook.com|title=BUMBLEBEE International Trailer (2018) John Cena Transformers Movie HD|date=2018-09-24|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-VNtqJX5nWY&feature=push-u-sub&attr_tag=yIT8yMFPzzIO0TJU:6|access-date=2018-09-24}}</ref>
On November 21, 2018, Paramount announced it would hold one-day previews for the film on Saturday, December 8, 2018, similar to the promotion [[Amazon Prime]] and [[Sony Pictures]] run with films like ''[[Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle]]'', ''[[Hotel Transylvania 3: Summer Vacation]]'' and fellow December 2018 release ''[[Aquaman (film)|Aquaman]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://deadline.com/2018/11/bumblebee-sneak-previews-hailee-steinfeld-december-paramount-1202506008/|title=‘Bumblebee’ Will Sneak Into Theaters On Dec. 8|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=November 21, 2018|first=Anthony|last=D'Alessandro|accessdate=November 21, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181121203042/https://deadline.com/2018/11/bumblebee-sneak-previews-hailee-steinfeld-december-paramount-1202506008/|archive-date=November 21, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
===Box office projections=== In the United States and Canada, ''Bumblebee'' will be released alongside ''[[Aquaman (film)|Aquaman]]'', ''[[Welcome to Marwen]]'' and ''[[Second Act (film)|Second Act]]'', and is projected to gross around $40 million over its five-day opening weekend.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://deadline.com/2018/11/aquaman-mary-poppins-returns-bumblebee-christmas-box-office-projections-1202510967/|title=‘Aquaman’ & ‘Mary Poppins Returns’ Eye $70M+ Christmas Stretch Hauls – Early Tracking|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=November 29, 2018|first=Anthony|last= D'Alessandro|accessdate=November 29, 2018}}</ref>

revision.comment: Adding [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "Gentleman's club in San Diego & Las Vegas" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|Gentleman's club in San Diego & Las Vegas}} {{about|the strip club||Cheetah (disambiguation)}} {{Refimprove|date=January 2008}} [[File:Cheetahs San Diego CA.jpg|right|300px|thumb|Cheetahs, in [[San Diego]], California]]
'''Cheetah's Topless Club''' is a "[[strip club|gentleman's club]]" or topless bar located in [[San Diego, California|San Diego]], and [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]], best known for being featured in the 1995 movie ''[[Showgirls]]'', and also for having been owned by Mike Galardi, a nightclub owner who was investigated by the [[FBI]] with a controversial invocation of the ''[[Patriot Act]]''. The Cheetah's club in San Diego is a full nude club where no alcohol is served. It has achieved notoriety for having been frequented by some of the September 11 hijackers.
==Las Vegas Club== The Las Vegas club was founded in 1991 by Michael Galardi, and employs about 150 dancers. In 2004, Galardi admitted in a San Diego federal trial that he bribed Las Vegas officials in an attempt to influence strip club regulations. In a Las Vegas federal court, he stated that he paid between $200,000 and $400,000.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Jan-24-Sat-2004/news/23067753.html |title=Liquor license status: Cheetah's owner to contest LV fine |publisher=[[Las Vegas Review-Journal]] |first=Michael |last=Squires |date=January 24, 2004}}</ref>
The club is managed by [[The Godfather (wrestler)|Charles Wright]], a retired [[professional wrestling|professional wrestler]] best known for his stints in [[WWE|World Wrestling Entertainment]] as a [[Haitian Vodou|voodoo]] [[witch doctor]] ("Papa Shango") and as a [[pimp]] ("The Godfather"), and was also part of the [[Nation of Domination]] under the name Kama Mustafa.
In an April 2012 episode of NBC's ''[[Smash (U.S. TV series)|Smash]]'', the New York City club entrance can be seen when Megan Hilty's character Ivy Lynn walks down the street.
==See also== * [[Planning of the September 11, 2001 attacks]] * ''[[Showgirls]]'', 1995 film shot on location * [[Operation G-Sting]] - About the FBI's "Operation G-Sting" * [[Charles Wright (wrestler)|Charles Wright]] - General manager of the club * Missy Monroe, porn actress who got her start at Cheetah's * [[Brent Jordan]], bouncer from 1991–2003 who wrote a book, ''Stripped'', about working at the club
==References== * [[Brent Kenton Jordan|Jordan, Brent Kenton]], ''Stripped: Twenty Years of Secrets from inside the Strip Club'', Satsu Multimedia Press, 2005, {{ISBN|0-9703441-2-0}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110629092917/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/Jan-24-Sat-2004/news/23067753.html "Cheetah's owner to contest LV fine"] ''Las Vegas Review Journal'', January 24, 2004 * [https://web.archive.org/web/20061220101655/http://www.cnn.com/2003/US/West/05/15/stripclub.probe.ap/ "FBI raids Vegas strip clubs, San Diego city offices"] ''CNN'', May 15, 2003 * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070311034157/http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=%2Fchronicle%2Farchive%2F2005%2F04%2F07%2FEDGV5C3MQE1.DTL "Time to fix the Patriot Act"]''San Francisco Chronicle'', April 7, 2005 * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060427004955/http://www.lasvegassun.com/sunbin/stories/sun/2003/nov/04/515818511.html "Patriot Act aided Feds in probe"] ''Las Vegas Sun'', November 4, 2003
==Notes== {{reflist}}

to 9 August|publisher=[[International Business Times]]|date=19 July 2013|accessdate=26 January 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305014439/http://www.ibtimes.co.in/chennai-express-release-date-delayed-shah-rukh-deepika-starrer-pushed-to-9-august-492285|archivedate=5
