web|url=http://www.boxofficeindia.com/boxnewsdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=6217&nCat=|publisher=Box Office India|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131110024322/http://www.boxofficeindia.com/boxnewsdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=6217&nCat=|date=7 November 2013|title= Worldwide Opening Weekend: KRRISH 3 Sixth|accessdate=13 January 2015|archivedate=10 November 2013 }} The film performed well on Monday, collecting over {{INRConvert|120|m|nolink=yes}}. It grossed {{INRConvert|115|m|nolink=yes}} on its first Tuesday, becoming Shah Rukh Khan's highest-grossing film in India.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131103151247/http://www.boxofficeindia.com/boxnewsdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=5961&nCat=|date=14 August 2013|url=http://www.boxofficeindia.com/boxnewsdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=5961&nCat= |title=Chennai Express Is Highest Shahrukh Khan Grosser in Five Days |publisher=Box Office India |accessdate=15 August 2013|archivedate=3 November 2013 }}{{cite web|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-08-15/news-interviews/41410165_1_chennai-express-crore-125-cr |title=Chennai Express crosses 125 cr; 200 cr target? |work=The Times of India |date=1 January 1970 |accessdate=15 August 2013}} The film grossed {{INRConvert|125.60|m|nolink=yes}} on Wednesday.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131103152123/http://www.boxofficeindia.com/boxnewsdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=5963&nCat=|date=15 August 2015|url=http://www.boxofficeindia.com/boxnewsdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=5963&nCat=|title=Chennai Express Wednesday business|publisher=Box Office India |accessdate=16 August 2013|archivedate=3 November 2013 }}{{cite web|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-08-15/box-office/41412916_1_chennai-express-cr-shahrukh-khan |title=Chennai Express: 137.1 cr till Wednesday |work=The Times of India |date=15 August 2013 |accessdate=26 August 2013}} Box Office India reported that the film grossed {{INRConvert|190|m|nolink=yes}} net on Thursday, taking its first week total (including paid previews) to {{INRConvert|1.461.50|b|nolink=yes}}, beating the previous record of ''Ek Tha Tiger''.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131230005445/http://www.boxofficeindia.com/boxnewsdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=6343&nCat=|url=http://www.boxofficeindia.com/boxnewsdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=6343&nCat=|title=Top Ten All Time First Week Grossers: DHOOM 3 Leads By 25%|archivedate=30 December 2013 |publisher=[[Box Office India]] |date=27 December 2013 |accessdate=27 December 2013}}{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131103155108/http://www.boxofficeindia.com/boxnewsdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=5968&nCat=|url=http://www.boxofficeindia.com/boxnewsdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=5968&nCat= |title=Chennai Express Beats Ek Tha Tiger First Week Record |publisher=Box Office India |date=16 August 2013 |accessdate=26 August 2013|archivedate=3 November 2013 }}{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131103152413/http://www.boxofficeindia.com/boxnewsdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=5980&nCat=|url=http://www.boxofficeindia.com/boxnewsdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=5980&nCat= |title=Chennai Express Week One Territorial Breakdown|publisher=Box Office India |date=19 August 2013 |accessdate=26 August 2013|archivedate=3 November 2013 }}{{cite web|title=Chennai Express Beats Ek Tha Tiger First Week Record |url=http://www.boxofficeindia.com/boxnewsdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=5968&nCat= |date=16 August 2013 |publisher=[[Box Office India]] |accessdate=23 September 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131103155108/http://www.boxofficeindia.com/boxnewsdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=5968&nCat= |archivedate=3 November 2013 }} It had a worldwide gross of {{INRConvert|2.5|b|nolink=yes}} in the first seven days.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131103151245/http://www.boxofficeindia.com/boxnewsdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=6141&nCat=|archivedate=3 November 2013 |url=http://www.boxofficeindia.com/boxnewsdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=6141&nCat= |title=Top Worldwide First Weeks 2013: Besharam 50% Of Yeh Jawaani Hai Deewani |publisher=Box Office India |date=9 October 2013 |accessdate=17 October 2013}} The film collected {{INRConvert|237.50|m|nolink=yes}} on its second weekend, taking the total domestic net to {{INRConvert|1.68|b|nolink=yes}}, and also became the second-highest-grossing Bollywood film in ten days with a worldwide gross of {{INRConvert|3.14|b|nolink=yes}}.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131103152539/http://www.boxofficeindia.com/boxnewsdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=5977&nCat=|archivedate=3 November 2013 |url=http://www.boxofficeindia.com/boxnewsdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=5977&nCat= |title=Chennai Express Second Weekend Business |publisher=Box Office India |date=19 August 2013 |accessdate=26 August 2013}}{{cite web |url=http://boxofficeindia.com/boxnewsdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=5979&nCat=|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131105220137/http://boxofficeindia.com/boxnewsdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=5979&nCat=|archivedate=5 November 2013 |title=Chennai Express Crosses Ek Tha Tiger Worldwide in Ten Days |publisher=Box Office India |date=19 August 2013 |accessdate=12 January 2015}} The film earned {{INRConvert|1.85|b|nolink=yes}} in two weeks and had collected {{INRConvert|1.94|b|nolink=yes}} after its third weekend in the domestic market.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131103153321/http://www.boxofficeindia.com/boxnewsdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=6002&nCat=|archivedate=3 November 2013|url=http://www.boxofficeindia.com/boxnewsdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=6002&nCat=|title=Chennai Express third weekend|publisher=Box Office India|date=26 August 2013}} It grossed {{INRConvert|160|m|nolink=yes}} in its third week, bringing up its total to {{INRConvert|2.00.75|b|nolink=yes}}.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131103151553/http://www.boxofficeindia.com/boxnewsdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=6014&nCat=|date=30 August 2013|archivedate=3 November 2013|url=http://www.boxofficeindia.com/boxnewsdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=6014&nCat=|title=Chennai Express Hits 200 Crore in Three Weeks|publisher=[[Box Office India]]|accessdate=30 August 2013}} ''Chennai Express'' broke the domestic net record set by ''3 Idiots'' in its fourth weekend{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131103151027/http://www.boxofficeindia.com/boxnewsdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=6033&nCat=|archivedate=3 November India |date=5 September 2013 |accessdate=17 October 2013}}{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131103151742/http://www.boxofficeindia.com/boxnewsdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=6034&nCat=|archivedate=3 November 2013|url=http://www.boxofficeindia.com/boxnewsdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=6034&nCat= |title=Chennai Express Only Bright Spot in a Dull August |publisher=Box Office India |date=5 September 2013 |accessdate=17 October 2013}} and added around {{INRConvert|57.40|m|nolink=yes}} in week four to take the total to {{INRConvert|2.06|b|nolink=yes}}.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131103154302/http://www.boxofficeindia.com/boxnewsdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=6036&nCat=|archivedate=3 November 2013|url=http://www.boxofficeindia.com/boxnewsdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=6036&nCat= |title=Chennai Express 206 Cr in Four Weeks Madras Cafe 41 Cr in Two Weeks |publisher=Box Office India 2013|url=http://www.boxofficeindia.com/boxdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=6041&nCat= |title=Shudh Desi Romance Opens Well Zanjeer Dull |publisher=Box Office India |date=7 September 2013 |accessdate=17 October 2013}}{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131103152225/http://www.boxofficeindia.com/boxnewsdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=6045&nCat=|archivedate=3 November |accessdate=17 October 2013}} The film collected {{INRConvert|3.5|m|nolink=yes}} on its sixth week, for a final total of {{INRConvert|2.08.25|b|nolink=yes}}.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131103151158/http://www.boxofficeindia.com/boxnewsdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=6076&nCat=|archivedate=3 November |accessdate=17 October 2013}}{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131103151740/http://www.boxofficeindia.com/boxnewsdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=6079&nCat=|archivedate=3 November 2013 |accessdate=17 October 2013}}{{efn|While Box Office India confirms that the film grossed {{INRConvert|2.08|b|nolink=yes}} at the end of its run, other trade analysts like [[Taran Adarsh]] and [[Komal Nahta]] claimed an 8-percent higher figure of {{INRConvert|2.27|b|nolink=yes}}.{{cite web|url=http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/box-office/special-features/id/279|title=BO Report Card: Krrish 3 is the first highest grosser of 2013 so far|publisher=Bollywood Hungama|date=4 November 2013|accessdate=12 January Office India's figures have been used.}} The film's lifetime domestic distributor share stands at {{INRConvert|1.15|b|nolink=yes}}, breaking ''Ek Tha Tiger''{{'}}s previous record of {{INRConvert|1.07|b|nolink=yes}}.{{cite web|title=Chennai Express Heads For ALL TIME RECORD Distributor Share - Box Office India|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130826011927/http://www.boxofficeindia.com/boxnewsdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=5983&nCat=|date=20 August 2013|archivedate=26 August 2013 |url=http://boxofficeindia.com/boxnewsdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=5983&nCat=|publisher=[[Box Office India]]|accessdate=10 January 2014}} ===Overseas=== ''Chennai Express'' also broke overseas records; during paid previews in the UK the film collected more than any first day of a Bollywood film in the UK.{{cite web|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130811101140/http://boxofficeindia.com/boxnewsdetail.php?page=shownews&articleid=5939&nCat= |archivedate=11 August 2013 the US ($2.22 million), the UAE (AED 7.73 million) and the UK (£934,118).{{cite web|title=Weekend Box Office Results for August 9–11 – Box Office Irritating Song |"[[Lungi Dance]]" |{{nominated}} |- |Worst Lyrics |"1 2 3 4 Get on the Dance Floor" |{{nominated}} |} ==Game== A [[Platform game|platform running game]] titled ''Chennai Express: Escape from Rameshwaram'', based on the film and featuring Shahrukh Khan & Deepika Padukone, was developed by [[UTV Software Communications|Disney UTV]]'s digital wing, and launched on 24 July 2013 for [[Android (operating system)|Android]] systems. In the game, the player rides a virtual roller-coaster, fighting off goons and dodging obstacles while they attempt to collect over 10,000 coins in order to unlock Padukone's game avatar.{{cite web|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/entertainment/1865083/report-shah-rukh-khan-launches-chennai-express-game|title=Shah Rukh Khan launches Chennai Express game|publisher=[[DNA India]]|date=24 July 2013|accessdate=25 July 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130726120813/http://www.dnaindia.com/entertainment/1865083/report-shah-rukh-khan-launches-chennai-express-game|archivedate=26 July 2013|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.Indiagames.ChennaiExpressEscapeFromRameshwaram|title=Chennai Express Official Game|first=Indiagames|last=Ltd|date=1 {{refimprove|date=September 2013}} {{Expand French|Cinéma algérien|date=December 2011}} {{short description|film industry}} {{Infobox cinema market | name = Cinema of Algeria | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | screens = 19 (2009)<ref name=screens_uis>{{cite web|title=Table 8: Cinema Infrastructure - Capacity|url=http://stats.uis.unesco.org/unesco/TableViewer/tableView.aspx?ReportId=5542|publisher=UNESCO Institute for Statistics|accessdate=5 November 2013}}</ref> | screens_per_capita = 0.1 per 100,000 (2009)<ref name=screens_uis/> | distributors = <!-- {{br separated entries|entry1|entry2|entry3}} <ref name=distributors_uis>{{cite web|title=Table 6: Share of Top 3 distributors (Excel)|url=http://stats.uis.unesco.org/unesco/ReportFolders/reportFolders.aspx|publisher=UNESCO Institute for Statistics|accessdate=5 November 2013}}</ref> --> | produced_year = | produced_ref = <!-- <ref name=production_uis>{{cite web|title=Table 1: Feature Film Production - Genre/Method of Shooting|url=http://stats.uis.unesco.org/unesco/TableViewer/tableView.aspx?ReportId=5545|publisher=UNESCO Institute for Statistics|accessdate=5 November 2013}}</ref> --> | produced_total = | produced_fictional = | produced_animated = | produced_documentary = | admissions_year = 2006 | admissions_ref = <ref name=adm_gross_uis>{{cite web|title=Table 11: Exhibition - Admissions & Gross Box Office (GBO)|url=http://stats.uis.unesco.org/unesco/TableViewer/tableView.aspx?ReportId=5538|publisher=UNESCO Institute for Statistics|accessdate=5 November 2013}}</ref> | admissions_total = 700,000 | admissions_national = | box_office_year = 2007 | box_office_ref = <ref name=adm_gross_uis/> | box_office_total = $100,000 | box_office_national = <!-- ${{Format price| }} --> }} '''Cinema of Algeria''' refers to the [[film industry]] based in the north African country of [[Algeria]].
==The colonial era == During the era of French colonization, movies were predominantly a propaganda tool for the French colonial state.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HqeQ3zN18JEC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=France at War in the Twentieth Century: Propaganda, Myth, and Metaphor|last=Delporte|first=Christian|date=2000|publisher=Berghahn Books|isbn=9781571817013|language=en}}</ref> Although filmed in Algeria and viewed by the local population, the vast majority of "Algerian" cinema in this era was created by Europeans.
The colonial propaganda films themselves generally depicted a stereotypical image of pastoral life in the colony, often focusing on an aspect of local culture that the administration sought to change,{{citation needed|date=February 2013}} such as polygamy. One example of such a film is Albert Durec's 1928 ''Le Désir''.
Popular French cinema filmed or set in Algeria often echoed many of the tropes common in administration-funded films. For example, [[L'Atlantide (1921 film)|L'Atlantide]] was a wildly popular 1921 French-Belgian silent movie filmed in the [[Aurès Mountains]], [[Djidjelli]], and [[Algiers]] in what was then French Algeria.<ref>{{cite book|last=Abel|first=Richard|title=French Cinema: The First Wave, 1915-1929|year=1984|publisher=Princeton University Press}}</ref>{{page needed|date=February 2013}} Although not explicitly about Algeria, the movie (itself based on a popular book) depicts two French Foreign Legion officers and their love affair with the lascivious queen of a fictional Saharan kingdom. One of the earliest films to engage with the French presence in North Africa, the film emphasizes not only the romance and exoticism of the venture, but also European anxieties over their role in Africa and the possibly dangerous affects of inter-racial contact.<ref>{{cite book|last=Slavin|first=David Henry|title=Colonial Cinema and Imperial France, 1919–1939: White Blind Spots, Male Fantasies, Settler Myths|year=2001|publisher=JHU Press|pages=35}}</ref> Other films with similar themes followed, including ''Le Bled'' (1929), ''[[Le Grand Jeu (1934 film)|Le Grand Jeu]]'' (1934), and ''[[La Bandera (film)|La Bandera]]'' (1935).
European domination of the means of cinematic production ended in the early days of the Algerian War, when several Algerian nationalists from the [[Armée de Libération nationale|National Liberation Army]] (ALN) obtained basic film-making equipment which they used to create four short programs. These films were screened via a relay system to viewers in a variety of sympathetic socialist nations.{{Citation needed|date=February 2013}} Their content supported the growing nationalist rebellion, including the place of ALN hospitals and a [[Mujahideen]] attack on the French mines of the [[Société de l'Ouenza]].
==The emergence of Algerian cinema in the 1960s and 1970s== Algeria became an independent nation in 1962, a topic which garnered heavy attention amongst Algerian movie productions of the 1960s and 1970s.
[[Mohammed Lakhdar-Hamina]]'s canonical 1967 film ''[[The Winds of the Aures]]'' depicts a rural farming family whose lives are destroyed by colonialism and war. The plot depicts the tragic plight of a mother who leaves her home in the Aurès mountains of eastern Algeria to search desperately for her son, a nationalist who has followed in his father's footsteps but been captured by the French army. Symbolically, the film uses the family to represent the fate of the nation: impoverished, exploited, but struggling to be free.<ref>{{cite book|last=Spaas|first=Lieve|title=Francophone Film: A Struggle for Identity|year=2001|publisher=Manchester University Press|pages=135–6}}</ref> The film won an award at the [[1967 Cannes Film Festival]] for Best First Work.<ref name="festival-cannes.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/archives/ficheFilm/id/2754/year/1967.html |title=Festival de Cannes: The Winds of the Aures |accessdate=2009-03-08 |work=festival-cannes.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120208075338/http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/archives/ficheFilm/id/2754/year/1967.html |archivedate=2012-02-08 |df= }}</ref>
Outside of Algeria, one of the most famous films of this era is [[The Battle of Algiers]] (1966), an Algerian-Italian film that obtained three Oscar nominations.
Other examples of Algerian cinema from this era include ''[[Patrol in the East]]'' (1972) by ''[[Amar Laskri]]'', ''[[Prohibited Area]]'' (1972) by ''[[Ahmed Lallem]]'', ''[[The Opium and the Stick]]'' (1970) by [[Ahmed Rachedi (film director)|Ahmed Rachedi]], Palme d'Or-winner ''[[Chronicle of the Years of Fire]]'' (1975) by [[Mohammed Lakhdar-Hamina]], and [[Costa Gavras]]' [[Academy Award|Oscar]]-winning ''[[Z (1969 film)|Z]]''. A notable French-Algerian documentary about the aftermath of the war is the 1963 [[Peuple en marche]].
Along with decolonization and the Algerian War, the plight of urban youth is another common theme. One example of this theme is [[Merzak Allouache]]'s ''[[Omar Guetlato]]''.
Several comedy stars also emerged, including the very popular ''[[Rouiched]]'', star of ''[[Hassan Terro]]'' or ''[[Hassan Taxi]]''. In addition, [[Hadj Abderrahmane]] - better known under the pseudonym of the ''Inspector Tahar'' - starred in the 1973 comedy ''[[The Holiday of The Inspector Tahar]]'' directed by [[Musa Haddad]]. The most famous comedy of this period is ''[[Carnaval fi dechra]]'' directed by [[Mohamed Oukassi]], and starting [[Athman Ariouet]].
==Contemporary cinema, 1980 to the present== Algerian cinema slumped in the mid-1980s, and major productions became rare. Some{{Citation needed|date=February 2013}} attribute this fact to the state's unwillingness to subsidize Algerian film. There were a few success, including [[Mohamed Oukassi]]'s 1994 comedy ''[[Carnival fi Dachra]]'', filmed in [[Maghrebi Arabic]] and following the story of a man who runs for mayor of his village (or "dachra") only to be seduced by power and seek to become the president of Algeria. Director [[Merzak Allouache]]'s ''[[Athmane Aliouet]]'' and "[[Salut Cousin!]]" (1996) are two other examples of Algerian comedies produced in this era.
Some {{Citation needed|date=February 2013}} characterize contemporary Algerian cinema to be in a rebuilding phase. The recent trend has been an increase of Francophone cinema, as opposed to films in [[Algerian Arabic]]. Some {{Citation needed|date=February 2013}} attribute this to the Francophone market encouraged by increased [[immigration to France]] in the 1990s. For example, Franco-Algerian productions such as [[Rachid Bouchareb]]'s ''[[Outside the Law (2010 film)|Outside the Law]]'' have met with great success (and controversy).
A full statistical report on the cinema industry in Algeria, edited by Euromed Audiovisual and the European Audiovisual Observatory can be found on the Observatoyr's website here <ref>[http://www.obs.coe.int/documents/205595/412951/Rapport_Alg%C3%A9rie_FR_21-05-2014.pdf/22cf4634-dd56-47c5-be36-df08d8cb426a Report on the audiovisual and film sector in Algeria by Euromed Audiovisual and the European Audiovisual Observatory]</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Algeria|Film}} * [[Cinema of the world]] *[[Culture of Algeria]] *[[List of Algerian films]] * [[Centre Algerien de la Cinematographie]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * Guy Austin, ''Algerian National Cinema'', Manchester University Press, 2012, {{ISBN|978-0-7190-7993-1}}
{{Arab Cinema}} {{Africa topic|Cinema of}} {{Algeria topics}} {{World cinema}}

page.title: Fraser Film Release and Photographic Company

revision.text:
'''Fraser Film Release and Photographic Company''' was an Australian film company formed in 1912 by two brothers, Archie and Colin Fraser. It operated as a film exchange, importing movies from overseas, and production house, making shorts, features and documentaries.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article26905393 |title=Advertising. |newspaper=[[The West Australian]] |location=Perth |date=16 May 1914 |accessdate=10 April 2012 |page=2 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article120279958 |title=FRASER FILM EXCHANGE. |newspaper=[[The Referee (newspaper)|The Referee]]|location=Sydney |date=23 December 1914 |accessdate=9 November 2014 |page=15 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
Early financial support came from [[Giuseppe Borsalino]], an Italian businessman who invested in Italian films and used Fraser Films as an Australia outlet for his company.<ref>Graham Shirley and Brian Adams, ''Australian Cinema: The First Eighty Years'', Currency Press 1989 p 34-35</ref> Among the filmmakers who worked for them were [[Franklyn Barrett]], [[Raymond Longford]] and [[Alfred Rolfe (director)|Alfred Rolfe]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article120359799 |title=The Lure of the Movies—A Mammoth Enterprise. |newspaper=[[The Sunday Times (Sydney)|The Sunday Times]] |location=Sydney |date=1 March 1914 |accessdate=10 December 2014 |page=2 Supplement: SUNDAY TIMES GLOBE PICTORIAL |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
Despite some early successes, the company suffered from pressure exerted by the "combine" of [[Australasian Films]] and decline of production from Europe due to World War I where Fraser brought many of their films. The company wound up in 1918.<ref name="Pike">Andrew Pike and Ross Cooper, ''Australian Film 1900–1977: A Guide to Feature Film Production'', Melbourne: Oxford University Press, 1998, p 39</ref>
==Select credits== *''Whale Hunting in Jarvis Bay'' (1913) – documentary *''[[A Blue Gum Romance]]'' (1913) – feature *''[[The Life of a Jackeroo]]'' (1913) – feature *''[[The Silence of Dean Maitland (1914 film)|The Silence of Dean Maitland]]'' (1914) – feature *''[[We'll Take her Children in amongst our own]]'' (1915) – short *''[[The Day (1914 film)|The Day]]'' (1914) – feature *''[[Ma Hogan's New Boarder]]'' (1915) – short *''[[The Sunny South or The Whirlwind of Fate]]'' (1915) – feature *''[[Murphy of Anzac]]'' (1916) – feature
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://colsearch.nfsa.gov.au/nfsa/search/display/display.w3p;adv=;group=;groupequals=;holdingType=;page=0;parentid=;query=%22fraser%20film%20release%22;querytype=;rec=1;resCount=10 Archive and Colin Fraser] at [[National Film and Sound Archive]]
[[Category:Cinema of Australia]]

revision.text:
{{distinguish|Faroe Islands|Faro, Portugal}} {{Infobox islands |name = Fårö |native_name = |image_name = Rauks (3881539849).jpg |image_caption = Rauks at Langhammars, Fårö |image_size = |map = Sweden Gotland |label = Fårö |label_position = left |map_caption = Gotland (Sweden) |country = Sweden |country_admin_divisions_title = County |country_admin_divisions = [[Gotland County]] |country_admin_divisions_title_1 = Municipality |country_admin_divisions_1 = [[Gotland Municipality]] |waterbody = [[Baltic Sea]] |elevation_m = |elevation_footnotes = |prominence = |coordinates = {{coord|57|57|N|19|09|E|type:isle_region:SE_dim:50000|display=inline,title}} |length_km = |width_km = |area_km2 = 113.30 |area_footnotes = <ref name="numbers"/><ref name=scb>{{cite web|url=http://www.scb.se/statistik/_publikationer/OV0904_2011A01_BR_02_A01BR1101.pdf |title=Statistisk årsbok 2011 |publisher=[[Statistics Sweden]] |language=Swedish |page=12 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zxLyViMj?url=http://www.scb.se/statistik/_publikationer/OV0904_2011A01_BR_02_A01BR1101.pdf |archivedate=5 July 2011 |accessdate=5 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite encyclopedia|editor-last=Westrin|editor-first=Th.|encyclopedia=[[Nordisk familjebok]]|title=Fårö|page=205|date=908|edition=9 (Uggleupplagan)|url=http://runeberg.org/nfbi/0121.html}}</ref> |population = 498 |population_as_of = 2014 |population_footnotes =<ref name=numbers>{{cite web|title=Gotland i siffror 2015|trans-title=Gotland in numbers 2015|url=http://www.gotland.se/64224|website=www.gotland.se|publisher=[[Gotland Municipality]]|accessdate=25 May 2016}}</ref> }} '''Fårö''' ({{IPA-sv|²foːrøː}}) is a [[Baltic Sea]] island just off north of the island of [[Gotland]], itself off mainland Sweden's southeastern coast. It is the second-largest island in the province and it is a popular summer resort. It has its own dialect (''Faroymal'', a dialect of [[Gutnish]]). Formerly a [[socken]] which includes the [[Gotska Sandön]] island,<ref>The exact extent of the socken, now district, can be obtained by clicking on ''Kartinställningar'' and check the ''Socken'' box in the menu of [http://www.fmis.raa.se/cocoon/fornsok/search.html?parish=920&tab=2&page=1 this map] from the [[Swedish National Heritage Board]] database.</ref> on 1{{nbsp}}January 2016, it was reconstituted into the [[Registration districts in Sweden|administrative area]] Fårö District.<ref>{{cite web|title=Förordning om district|trans-title=Regulation of districts|url=http://rkrattsdb.gov.se/SFSdoc/15/150493.PDF|date=17 June 2015|publisher=[[Ministry of Finance (Sweden)|Ministry of Finance]]|accessdate=24 May 2016}}</ref>
==Geography== [[File:Gotland-Fårö-kyrka 01.jpg|thumb|175px|left|Fårö Church]] The island is separated from Gotland by the narrow Fårö-strait, and connected by two [[Ferry|car ferries]], operated by the [[Swedish Transport Administration]]. It has a total area of {{convert|111.35|sqkm|sqmi|2|abbr=off}}, of which {{convert|9.7|sqkm|sqmi|1|abbr=off}} are water areas or [[islet]]s.
On the islands of Fårö and Gotland are rock formations called "[[Stack (geology)|Rauk]]". They are a result of erosion during the [[Ice age]] and are unique to Gotland and Fårö.
The medieval [[Fårö Church]] is on Fårö.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Lagerlöf|first1=Erland|last2=Svahnström|first2=Gunnar|title=Gotlands kyrkor|trans-title=Gotland's Churces|language=Swedish|id={{LIBRIS|7232718}}|date=1973|publisher=[[Rabén & Sjögren]]|location=Stockholm|isbn=91-29-41035-5|pages=144}}</ref>
One of the [[asteroid]]s in the [[Asteroid belt]], [[List of minor planets: 9001–10000|9358 Fårö]], is [[List of Gotland related asteroids|named]] after the island.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=9358|title=9358 Faro (1992 DN7)|accessdate=6 June 2016|publisher=[[NASA]]}}</ref>
==Etymology== The name "Fårö" (in [[Modern Gutnish|Gutnish]] "Faroy") is derived from the words "ö", meaning island, and probably "far-", which is a [[word stem]] associated with travel like in the Swedish verb "fara" (to travel). The word Fårö probably means the island you have to travel to or the traveler's island. Mainland Swedes might misinterpret the name Fårö to be derived from ''får'', the (standard) Swedish word for [[sheep]], due to the many sheep on the island. That word is absent from [[Modern Gutnish]], which uses the word "lamm" (which in Swedish means "lamb").{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}}
==Military past== {{Main article|Military on Gotland}} Until the 1990s, Fårö and the North of Gotland were off-limits to foreigners because of a government military installation there.<ref name="travel.nytimes.com">{{cite news|url=http://travel.nytimes.com/2007/10/07/travel/07cultured.html?pagewanted=print|work=The New York Times|first=Danielle|last=Pergament|title=The Enchanted Island That Bergman Called Home|date=7 October 2007}}</ref> There were large, multilingual signs at the side of the roads informing visitors of this and the prohibition was strictly enforced. After the [[Cold War]] ended, the installation ([[Swedish Coastal Artillery]] regiment KA 3) was mostly shut down. A relic of the island's military past is a {{convert|203|m|ft}} tall radio mast at Holmudden at 57°57'33" N and 19°20'46" E.
==Cinematic heritage== Swedish filmmaker [[Ingmar Bergman]] lived and died on Fårö and several of his films were filmed there, among them ''[[Through a Glass Darkly (film)|Through a Glass Darkly]]'' (1961), ''[[Persona (1966 film)|Persona]]'' (1966), ''[[Hour of the Wolf]]'' (1968), ''[[Shame (1968 film)|Shame]]'' (1968), ''[[The Passion of Anna]]'' (1969), and ''[[Scenes from a Marriage]]'' (1972),<ref name="travel.nytimes.com"/> as well as [[Liv Ullmann]]’s ''[[Faithless (2000 film)|Faithless]]'' (2000), based on a Bergman screenplay. The [[Bergman Week]] is tribute to the filmmaker held on the island every June.<ref name=Boston>{{cite web|last1=Peary|first1=gerald|title=For movie fans, an island getaway beckons|url=http://www.boston.com/ae/movies/articles/2010/07/11/bergman_week_and_a_shrine_to_the_late_filmmaker_await_on_fr_sweden/|website=www.boston.com|publisher=[[The Boston Globe]]|accessdate=17 June 2014}}</ref>
[[Andrei Tarkovsky]] wanted to film ''[[The Sacrifice]]'' on Fårö but was denied access by the military. ''[[The Sacrifice]]'' was filmed further south on [[Gotland]] at [[När]].
==Tourism== An annual event on Fårö is "Fårönatta" (Fårö Night), held in September, during which restaurants and bars stay open all night, craft stands are set up and the church holds a midnight Mass.<ref name="travel.nytimes.com"/>
==Fårö districts== [[File:Sudersand.jpg|thumb|Sudersand]]
=== Digerhuvud === The Digerhuvud coast with Bjärge [[nature reserve]] is the largest [[Stack (geology)|stack]] area in Sweden, with hundreds of stacks along a {{convert|3.5|km|mi|abbr=on}} part of the coast. Close by is the Helgumannen fishing village.<ref>{{cite web|title=Digerhuvud|url=http://www.gotland.net/plats/digerhuvud|website=www.gotland.net|publisher=Gotlands Media AB|accessdate=6 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Enderborg|first1=Bernt|title=Helgumannen fiskeläge|url=http://www.guteinfo.com/?id=585|website=www.guteinfo.com|publisher=Guteinfo|accessdate=6 June 2016}}</ref> The coast is not suited for swimming due to its depth (up to {{convert|80|m|ft|abbr=off}} close to the shore), and its strong currents.
An [[asteroid]] in the [[Asteroid belt]], [[10102 Digerhuvud]], is [[List of Gotland related asteroids|named]] after the area.<ref>{{cite web|title=10102 Digerhuvud (1992 DA6)|url=http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=10102|publisher=NASA|accessdate=6 June 2016}}</ref>
===''Fårö Fyr'' (Fårö Lighthouse)=== The ''[[Fårö Lighthouse]]'' lies on the island's northeastern point. It is {{convert|30|m|ft|0|abbr=off}} high and was built between 1846 and 1847.
===Langhammars=== The Langhammars peninsula and the Langhammars nature reserve on north-western Fårö are rocky beaches with [[Ice age]] stone monoliths known as [[Stack (geology)|rauks]]. Langhammars was the setting for [[Ingmar Bergman]]'s film [[Shame (1968 film)|Shame]].<ref name="travel.nytimes.com"/>
===Sudersand=== The long, sandy Sudersand beach on north-eastern Fårö lies next to Sudersands Semesterby which rents cabins to tourists.

{{Infobox television |show_name = Getting Doug With High |image = GettingDoug.jpg |caption = |show_name_2 = |genre = [[Comedy]] |creator = [[Doug Benson]] |developer = |writer = |director = |starring = |voices = |theme_music_composer = |opentheme = |composer = |country = United States |language = English |num_seasons = 1 |num_episodes = 163 |executive_producer = |location = Los Angeles, CA |cinematography = |runtime = 45-60 minutes approx. |company = |distributor = |network = VPN |picture_format = |audio_format = |first_aired = {{start date|2013|10|02}} |last_aired = |website = http://videopodcastnetwork.com/ |italic_title = force |status = }}
'''''Getting Doug With High''''' is a video and audio [[podcast]] show hosted by [[United States|American]] [[stand-up comedian]] and actor [[Doug Benson]].
==Format== The show is typically broadcast live on [[YouTube]] 15 minutes after the hour, which gives enough time for the guests to get ready to start smoking [[cannabis]] when it is "4:20 somewhere," [[420 (cannabis culture)|a time associated with marijuana culture]].
Guests are invited onto the show to be interviewed while smoking marijuana alongside Benson. Each episode features different strains of ''sativa'' and ''indica'', and showcases a series of smoking implements of unusual design, often including pipes designed by Chameleon Glass.
The show features several recurring segments: * ''High History''—The guests talk about the first time they ever smoked marijuana * ''Pot Topics''—Doug talks about news related to cannabis, with a particular focus on which states have legalized and/or decriminalized marijuana or are close to passing a legislative or ballot initiative to do so. * ''Pot Quiz Hop Shot''—Doug asks the guests a series of cannabis-related trivia questions. * ''#HeavyMonkey''—Doug tries to get one of the guests to comment about the weight of a broken lighter shaped like a monkey. * ''Gabe Time (now canceled)''—To close out the show, Doug brings out magician Gabe Dylan to perform a magic trick for the guest, who by this point is usually very high.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/blogs/sideshow/behind-the-scenes-with-doug-benson-on-the-first-talk-show-for-celebrity-pot-smokers-191832737.html|title=Behind the scenes with Doug Benson on the first talk show for celebrity pot smokers|date=7 March 2014|work=Yahoo News}}</ref>
In 2016, Benson hosted an uninterrupted four hour and twenty minute version of the show at a festival hosted by [[Jash]] in [[Palm Springs, California]]. The show has also hosted live versions of the show, with at least five guests, in front of an audience in a theater.

{{Superherobox| |image=HerbiePopnecker.jpg |image_size=250 |caption=Herbie, from ''[[Forbidden Worlds]]'' #114 (Sept. 1963).
Art by [[Ogden Whitney]] |character_name=Herbie |real_name=Herbie Popnecker |publisher=[[American Comics Group]] |debut=''[[Forbidden Worlds]]'' #73 (Dec. 1958) |creators=[[Richard E. Hughes]] and [[Ogden Whitney]] |alliances= |aliases= Fat Fury |powers= Flying
Invisibility
Ability to talk to animals
Time travel |}} '''Herbie Popnecker''' is a fictional comic book character that first appeared in ''[[Forbidden Worlds]]'' #73 in December 1958, published by [[American Comics Group]]. He was created by [[Richard E. Hughes]] (using the [[pseudonym]] "Shane O'Shea")[http://www.toonopedia.com/herbie.htm Herbie] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/657G8ILtG?url=http://www.toonopedia.com/herbie.htm |date=2012-02-01 }} and [http://www.toonopedia.com/fatfury.htm The Fat Fury] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/66xEsWrRD?url=http://www.toonopedia.com/fatfury.htm |date=2012-04-16 }} at [[Don Markstein's Toonopedia]]. Archived ([https://www.webcitation.org/6CwAJtR4j?url=http://www.toonopedia.com/articles/herbie.htm Herbie] and [https://www.webcitation.org/66xEsWrRD?url=http://www.toonopedia.com/fatfury.htm The Fat Fury]) from the originals on December 14, 2012, and April 16, 2012, respectively. and [[Ogden Whitney]]. Herbie is an antithetical hero: short, obese, unstylish, and young. Deriving some of his powers from genetics and some from magical [[lollipop]]s from "the Unknown", Herbie can talk to animals and sometimes even inanimate objects (who all know him by name), fly at high enough speeds to quickly travel to other galaxies (by walking through the sky), become invisible, cast spells and summon spirits from other dimensions, quickly dispatch his enemies with apparent ease, and (once he got his own title) travel through time. Herbie is emotionless, terse, irresistible to women, consulted by world leaders, nearly [[omnipotent]], and more powerful than [[Satan]]. == Publication history == Herbie made several appearances in ''Forbidden Worlds'', in issues #73, #94, #110, #114, and #116—the final two issues with Herbie featured on the cover. Herbie also made a [[cameo appearance]]—albeit very much out of character—in ''Unknown Worlds'' #20, published in 1961. Herbie received his own title, ''Herbie'', in April 1964. The series ran for twenty-three issues until February 1967, shortly before the demise of American Comics Group. == Fictional character biography == Herbie's parents are unaware of his great powers and fame. His mother is reasonably supportive, however his father, Pincus Popnecker, repeatedly refers to him as a "little fat nothing" and wishes he had a son who "did something". Pincus believes himself to be a financial genius and, despite his wholesome and conservative "1950s dad" appearance, constantly engages in harebrained schemes; he inevitably fails in spectacular fashion and winds up in varying levels of trouble. Herbie is always obliged to bail him out in each circumstance, though the clueless Pincus never notices this and always takes the credit for victory himself. Herbie is practically always shown with a lollipop, and lollipops are the main subjects of several stories. Herbie can "bop" adversaries with his lollipops, immediately defeating them. Herbie intimidates his adversaries by asking them rhetorically, "You want I should bop you with this here lollipop?", which almost always results in them backing down. === Fat Fury === In ''Herbie'' #8 (March 1965), Herbie feels a need to become a costumed superhero, but after failing superhero school, he creates the Fat Fury by donning [[Union suit|full-body red underwear with a drop seat]], a blue cape, a blue plastic mask, and a [[plunger]] on his head. He is bare-footed. Herbie's obtuse father then begins to wish that his little fat nothing of a son could be more like the Fat Fury. As the Fat Fury, Herbie does not have any powers beyond the many he had before donning the costume. Although Herbie travels back in time, the Fat Fury never does. The Fat Fury was featured in even-numbered ''Herbie'' comics from #8 to #22. == Powers == * Hypnotic eyes that can defeat opponents by staring * Famous throughout history and able to depend on the help of others * By talking to animals, able to gather information and use animals' abilities * Powerful [[lollipop]]s (particularly hard-to-get [[cinnamon]]) provide [[superhuman strength]] and other special abilities * Punching, often very rapidly * Time travel (using a special lollipop and a [[grandfather clock]]) * Indestructibility—Herbie is often unaware he is even being attacked * Fly, but doing so by walking upright. In addition to being able to walk on air and through space, he can walk underwater. Herbie can also fly underground and often breaks through walls * Invisibility—early on, Herbie could become invisible, but stopped using that power by the third ''Herbie'' issue * Magic—visiting the Unknown, a mysterious spirit world == Recurring gags == There are many recurring gags in Herbie comics: * Herbie speaks very little. He is terse, leaving out many words. * Herbie is unemotional, in spite of everything around him, understating everything he says. Herbie's captions are free of exclamation points, except when his lollipops are threatened. * Women swoon over Herbie, loving his round physique. Sometimes women who first loved Herbie eventually run off with an animal (e.g., alien bug king, gorilla, camel). * Herbie encounters many [[look-alike]]s, most of whom he thinks are ugly. * Although very obese, Herbie does not eat much, especially in later issues, although he sometimes sleeps while he eats. He is always sleeping, much to the dismay of his father. * Herbie sometimes bites his adversaries, and sometimes they bite him. * Herbie wears many disguises, most of which are absurd. * Herbie often appears, to his embarrassment, in boxer shorts. * Herbie sometimes happens to have just the right item for the job: marshmallows in King Arthur's time, worms to drop in Mao's mouth, a bicycle pump in his pocket, or a blowtorch in the frozen north. ("Never mind where I got it from, either.")Hughes, Bob "The Popnecker Papers: A Herbie History," Amazing Heroes #173, November 1989. ==Critical analysis== In a review of the [[Dark Horse Comics]] collections ''Herbie: Volume One'' and ''Herbie: Volume Two'', ''[[The New York Times]]'' described Hughes' Herbie Popnecker as, {{quote|...a corpulent kid with half-lidded eyes, thick glasses and a hideous bowl cut. His father calls him a "little fat nothing", not realizing that Herbie is actually a colossus striding across the cultural landscape of his era. With the aid of his super-empowering lollipops, Herbie punches out [[Sonny Liston]], confronts [[Fidel Castro]] and gets sent on a secret mission by [[U Thant]]. Hughes took a while to perfect his stories' tone of deadpan absurdity, but Whitney’s slightly stiff, matter-of-fact artwork improves the gags by understating them.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/12/07/books/review/Wolk-t.html |work=[[The New York Times]] |first=Douglas |last=Wolk |authorlink=Douglas Wolk |date=December 5, 2008 |title=Holiday Books: Comics |accessdate=December 15, 2012 |archivedate=December 15, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CwFmR4vG?url=http://www.nytimes.com/2008/12/07/books/review/Wolk-t.html?_r=0 |deadurl=no |df= }}}} == Collections and revivals == In the 1990s, there were some attempts to revive Herbie. [[A-Plus Comics]] (which had purchased the [[American Comics Group]] reprint rights) published six black-and-white issues of reprints in 1991. [[Dark Horse Comics]] published two issues of a planned twelve in 1992, the first with a new story by [[John Byrne (comics)|John Byrne]]. ''[[Flaming Carrot Comics]]'' #31 (1994) featured an appearance by Herbie (words and pictures by [[Bob Burden]]). [[America's Comic Group]] (a publisher affiliated with A+ Comics) published a new story written by [[Roger Broughton]] with artwork by Dan Day. In 2008, [[Dark Horse Comics]] announced that they would reprint the original Herbie stories in a series of hardcover archive volumes. The first Herbie Archives came out in August 2008 ({{ISBN|978-1-59307-987-1}}) and collects Herbie stories from ''Forbidden Worlds'' #73, 94, 110, 114, 116, ''Unknown Worlds'' #20, and ''Herbie'' #1–5. The second came out in December 2008 ({{ISBN|978-1-59582-216-1}}), and collects issues #6–14. The third and final volume came out in April 2009 ({{ISBN|978-1-59582-302-1}}), and collects issues #15–23. ==Awards== Herbie comics received the [[Alley Award]] for Best Humor Comic Book 1964 and 1965. The Herbie Archives received the [[Eisner Award]] for Best Humor Publication in 2009. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://digitalcomicmuseum.com/preview/index.php?did=9243&page=3 First appearance of Herbie in Forbidden Worlds #73] * [https://archive.org/search.php?query=herbie+fat+fury&sort=publicdate Herbie Popnecker] at the [[Internet Archive]] * [http://www.comics.org/character/name/herbie%20popnecker/sort/chrono/ Herbie Popnecker] at the [[Grand Comics Database]] * [http://darkmark6.tripod.com/herbie.html DarkMark Summaries] * [http://www.internationalhero.co.uk/f/fatfury.htm International Catalogue of Superheroes: Fat Fury] * [http://herbiepopnecker.com HerbiePopnecker.com] (fan site) [[Category:1964 comics debuts]] [[Category:American comics characters|Popnecker, Herbie]] [[Category:Characters created by Richard E. Hughes|Popnecker, Herbie]] [[Category:Child characters in comics|Popnecker, Herbie]] [[Category:Male characters in comics|Popnecker, Herbie]] [[Category:Comics characters introduced in 1958|Popnecker, Herbie]] [[Category:Comics characters with superhuman strength|Popnecker, Herbie]] [[Category:Comics spin-offs]] [[Category:Dark Horse Comics superheroes|Popnecker, Herbie]] [[Category:Eisner Award winners for Best Humor Publication]] [[Category:Humor comics]] [[Category:Parody superheroes|Popnecker, Herbie]]

'''Hitlisten''', also known as '''Tracklisten''', is a [[Denmark|Danish]] top 40 [[record chart]] that is updated every Thursday [[midnight]] on the website hitlisten.nu. The weekly Danish singles chart [[Track Top-40]] combines the 40 best-selling tracks from [[Music download|legal music downloads]] and the sales of [[Single (music)|music singles]] on either [[Compact Disc|CD]] or [[Gramophone record|vinyl]]. The data are collected by [[Nielsen Company|Nielsen Music Control]], who also compile the chart on behalf of [[IFPI]] (International Federation of the Phonographic Industry).
== 1965–1993: early IFPI charts == This chart began in April 1965 as a monthly top 20 chart compiled by the Danish branch of the [[International Federation of the Phonographic Industry]] (IFPI). It was published in several major Danish newspapers. Prior to that several Danish charts were compiled by competing newspapers. From April 1969 it went weekly after Denmark's Radio stopped publishing their weekly top 20 chart.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=jigEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA64&lpg=PA64&dq=denmark+singles+chart+international+federation+of+the+phonographic+industry&source=bl&ots=Ul11Al9x3h&sig=5qX9fX3IXyJ4D7dr41Lt-pwbdxw&hl=en&sa=X&ei=gW8fT6raBsre0QGrg-wF&ved=0CD0Q6AEwBzgK#v=onepage&q&f=false Billboard: IFPI forms sales chart (May 3, 1969)]</ref> From May 1973 to December 1978 singles and albums were presented on the same chart due to a request from Denmark's Radio for variety in their chart show.<ref>[http://danskehitlister.dk/?hitlist_id=12&y=1973&hitlist_item_id=1361 The first mixed IFPI chart from May 1 1973]</ref> During this period only few singles reached the top. The formats were finally split again in January 1979.
== 1993–2001: Nielsen Music Control and IFPI == Danish IFPI continued producing single charts in the 1980s and 1990s even though not many singles were sold. From 1993 the Danish charts have been compiled by [[Nielsen Company|Nielsen Music Control]] (originally AC Nielsen).
== 2001–2007: Hitlisten == The Danish Singles Chart Hitlisten consisting of Single Top-20 and Download Top 20 was relaunched 1 January 2001 and served as official chart for Danish [[record sales]] until end of October 2007.
== 2007–present: Tracklisten/Hitlisten == The track list was established on 2 November 2007 replacing the Hitlisten charts that were discontinued end of October 2007.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pladebranchen.nu/?id=426 |title=Hit-nyt: Singlelisten bliver til Tracklisten |date=2007-10-23 |publisher=IFPI Danmark}} ([https://translate.google.com/translate?js=n&prev=_t&hl=da&ie=UTF-8&layout=2&eotf=1&sl=da&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.pladebranchen.nu%2F%3Fid%3D426 English translation])</ref> The chart is supervised by [[IFPI Denmark]] and contains three charts: *[[Track Top-40]] (for singles) *[[Album Top-40]] (for albums) *Streaming Top-20. (for singles)
Hitlisten also continues to publish specialised charts: *Compilation Top-10 *Bit Album Top-20 *Bit Track Top-20 *Ringtoner Top-10 *Airplay Top-20 (for radio airplays) *Musik DVD Top-10 *Entertainment DVD Top-10 *TV-serie DVD Top-20
Track list was also updated back to week 1, 2007, thus creating an overlap of sometimes differing chart #1s between Hitlisten and Tracklisten for the period 1 January 2007 and 2 November 2007 (weeks 1 to 42 / 2007). For this period, the Hitlisten charts continue to be considered as the official charts for singles record sales.{{Citation needed|date=May 2010}}
== See also == *[[List of number-one hits (Denmark)]]

{{Infobox company | name = Imperia Online JSC | logo = | type = [[Privately held company|Private]] | foundation = 2009 | location_city = [[Sofia]] | location_country = [[Bulgaria]] | key_people = Moni Dochev
Dobroslav Dimitrov | num_employees = 55+ | industry = [[Mobile games]], [[video game development]], [[multiplayer video game]]s, [[social network game]]s, [[browser game]]s | homepage = {{URL|www.imperiaonline.bg}} }} '''Imperia Online JSC''' is a Bulgarian game production and publishing company founded by Moni Dochev and Dobroslav Dimitrov.{{cite web|title=Official History of IO|url=http://www.imperiaonline.bg/company/from-hobby-to-professional-game-studio/|website=www.imperiaonline.bg|accessdate=13 January 2015}}{{cite web|title=Impeia Online's History in a Few Facts|url=http://www.imperiaonline.bg/company/our-history-in-a-few-facts/|website=www.imperiaonline.bg|accessdate=13 January 2015}} Based in [[Sofia]], [[Bulgaria]], the company originally concentrated primarily on browser-based games with their main title being [[Imperia Online]], but later started developing mobile games as well.{{cite web|title=Timeline of IO's games|url=http://www.imperiaonline.bg/company/timeline/|website=www.imperiaonline.bg}}{{cite news|title=Imperia Online and the Global Invasion of The Great People|url=http://launchub.com/imperia-online-and-the-global-invasion-of-the-great-people/|accessdate=13 January 2015}} As of January 2018 the company has more 25 games in its portfolio, and has several more in development. Imperia Online JSC now develops games for web browsers, [[iOS]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]], [[Windows Phone]], [[Steam (software)|Steam]] and social networks like [[Facebook]], [[Odnoklassniki]] and [[VK (social networking)|Vkontakte.]]{{cite web|title=Imperia Online Co-Founder Dobroslav Dimitrov - reddit AMA|url=https://www.reddit.com/r/IAmA/comments/2ne2ny/i_am_dobroslav_dimitrov_cofounder_and_lead_game/|website=reddit.com|accessdate=13 January 2015}} == History == Imperia Online JSC was officially founded in September 2009, but the idea for it was born along with its main product - the [[Massively multiplayer online real-time strategy game|MMORTS]] Imperia Online. Detailed research and crafting of the gameplay, mechanics and programming for the company's main product were done by the game’ and company's founders Dobroslav Dimitrov - Gameplay Designer, and Moni Dochev - Freelance Developer.{{cite news|title=Interview with Imperia Online: How to Build a Game for 25 Million Users?|url=http://80.lv/articles/interview-with-imperia-online-how-to-build-a-game-for-25-million-users/|accessdate=16 March 2015}} In January 2005 an idea grows into a concept and on August 23 Era 1 of Realm 1 of Imperia Online goes live and the story begins. In 2006 realms of 2 brand new upgraded Imperia Online's versions are officially live. The game is translated into 12 languages thanks to the freelance Community managers and translators the company assigned. In the same year the first of its kind Imperia Online tournament is held - Nomads Invasions. In 2007 Imperia Online JSC launched Galactic Imperia - a new web-based project with Modern Military context. Almost a whole year of conceptualizing complicated game mechanics leads to the final publication of Global Wars in March 2008. In 2009, Imperia Online JSC launched its first [[role-playing game]] - [[Imperial Hero]]. The [[Role-playing game|RPG]] was published after a year of conceptual and technical development. Again in 2009 Ludo was launched for [[iOS]] and [[Facebook]] - the classic turn-based board game now can be played with thousands of real players online. The next year - in 2010 - Imperia Online JSC launched Online Artillery - a turn-based cannon shooter. In 2011 Imperia Online's World Cup tournament was held for the first time with the Bulgarian national team winning the first place. In 2012 the second World Cup was held, won again by the Bulgarians. The medieval strategy got its official appearance in the Apple App Store.The same year Imperia Online JSC was among the exhibitors at On!Fest. In 2013 the third Imperia Online tournament was conducted and this time it was won by the Croatians. By that time there were already more than 100 people working in the company and the first of its kind school for game developers – Imperial Training Camp - was opened. Throughout the year Imperia Online kept spreading by getting released on [[iOS]] and in the largest Russian social network [[Odnoklassniki]]. It also became available for Android users. Later that year the newest - and current - version of Imperia Online is launched - Version 6, called ‘The Great People’ with brand new graphic design, enriched and diversified gameplay. Imperia Online JSC was among the exhibitors at [[Gamescom]], Dubai World Game Expo and On!Fest. In the same year the company sponsored Sofia Game Jam, Intergame, Tallinn and the #archHackaton and also the Bulgarian Boogie Woogie Dance team for the World Championship in Moscow, Russia. In 2014 ‘IO: The Great People’ is also launched for [[Android (operating system)|Android]], [[Windows Phone]],{{cite web|title=Imperia Online in Windows Store|url=http://www.windowsphone.com/en-us/store/app/imperia-online-free-medieval-strategy-game/4a7482e0-48e2-44f5-97fe-f29346198999|website=www.windowsphone.com|accessdate=13 January 2015}} and [[Facebook]]. [[Microsoft]] chose Imperia Online for its ‘Featured’ section in [[Windows Store]].{{cite web|title=Imperia Online in 'Featured' in Windows Store|url=http://blog.imperiaonline.bg/bg/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/10728735_10201851371125846_133683349_n.jpg|accessdate=13 January 2015}} In the second half of the year Imperia Online JSC launched several mobile games, starting with Mad Moles and Online Artillery 2 in August - both of them for [[iOS]] and [[Facebook]].{{cite web|title=Online Artillery Now Conquering Facebook|url=http://blog.imperiaonline.bg/en/?p=305|website=blog.imperiaonline.bg|accessdate=13 January 2015}} Later that year Mad Moles received an [[Android (operating system)|Android]] version as well. In October 2014 Rocket Chameleon was released for [[iOS]]{{cite web|title=Rocket Chameleon Available On The App Store|url=http://blog.imperiaonline.bg/en/?p=106|website=blog.imperiaonline.bg|accessdate=13 January 2015}} and later got an [[Android (operating system)|Android]] version as well.{{cite web|title=Rocket Chameleon Successfully Landed on Google Play|url=http://blog.imperiaonline.bg/en/?p=288|website=blog.imperiaonline.bg|accessdate=13 January 2015}} In November 2014 Imperia Online JSC released Egg Tales for [[iOS]].{{cite web|title=Start Your Eggciting Adventure With Egg Tales!|url=http://blog.imperiaonline.bg/en/?p=160|website=blog.imperiaonline.bg|accessdate=13 January 2015}} - a casual game that follows the adventures of an egg that tumbled out of the safety of its nest and landed deep in a terrifying cave. The arcade jumper quickly rose to the top of the Bulgarian App Store in the ‘Free’ category. In the meantime - from mid-October until the end of November 2014 the fourth Imperia Online World Cup was held, this time won by Brazil.{{cite news|title=Brazil Is The New World Champion Of Imperia Online!|url=http://blog.imperiaonline.bg/en/?p=254|accessdate=13 January 2015}} Imperia Online JSC sponsored the Black Sea Solo Kayak Expedition, HackFMI and is also one of the sponsors of Launchub. That year Imperia Online JSC was among the exhibitors at [[Gamescom]] and at Intergame Tallinn where Dobroslav Dimitrov took part in it as a speaker, giving a talk on 'Winning the War for Software Engineering Talent'. Imperia Online JSC is a member of BAIT (Bulgarian Association of Information Technologies) and BASSCOM (Bulgarian Association of Software Technologies). In 2015 Imperia Online JSC released a number of titles including the RPG Imperial Hero II - a remake of Imperial Hero, launched for Android, Facebook and web. Meanwhile, Imperia Online for Windows Phone was published by Game Troopers and became a featured mobile Xbox title by Microsoft. In January 2015 Imperia Online JSC released the medieval turn-based strategy [[Seasons of War (Mobile Strategy Game)|Seasons of War]] for [[Android (operating system)|Android]]{{cite web|title=‘Seasons of War’ Now Available On Google Play|url=http://blog.imperiaonline.bg/en/?p=258|website=blog.imperiaonline.bg|accessdate=13 January 2015}} and later for iOS too. The same month Jolly Join and Golem Wars are launched for iOS. The following month Robo Risk and Cluster Six are launched for iOS and EggTales is launched for Android. In June Imperia Online JSC released Ishi for Android. Two months after that the company was among the exhibitors at Gamescom. In October Imperia Online JSC released FlapOTron 3D for iOS and Ludo Blitz, the upgraded version of Ludo from 2009, for iOS, Android and Facebook. The same month the company's COO, Cvetan Rusimov visited Game Connection Paris, where he was a speaker at the conference.{{cite journal|title=Imperia Online goes to Game Connection 2015!|url=http://blog.imperiaonline.bg/en/game-connection-2015/|accessdate=17 September 2016}} The following month Online Artillery 2.0 is launched for Android and released in a 3D Touch Edition for iPhone 6s. In December 2015 Ishi GO is launched for iOS. At the end of the year Imperia Online JSC stepped into partnership with VKontakte and Imperia Online for Android and iOS was integrated into the game section of VK's platform. 2016 started with the team exhibiting at Casual Connect Amsterdam, having an Indie nomination for Online Artillery 2.{{cite journal|title=Casual Connect Amsterdam 2016|url=http://indieprize.org/europe/#entry-0/|accessdate=18 February 2016}} In April Imperia Online was launched on [[Steam (software)|Steam]]. That same month Dobroslav Dimitrov, Imperia Online's Co-Founder, took part in Webit 2016 in a panel discussion entitled ‘Introduction to Endeavor and lessons learned from leveraging global, local or no capital’. In May Imperia Online JSC released the game Viber Emperors for Android and [[iOS]]. The game got translated to 30 languages, featured modules like ‘Ask a Viber Friend’ and had its own custom sticker package. Moni Dochev, the other Co-Founder participated in the jury of the E-volution Awards by Forbes that month. Again in May Ludo Blitz is released in [[Windows Store]]. During the summer Cvetan Rusimov, the COO of Imperia Online JSC, took part as a speaker in the conferences Pocket Gamer Connects in Helsinki {{cite journal|title=How to use irrational thinking to boost your IAP revenue by 335%|url=http://www.pocketgamer.biz/video/64598/how-to-use-irrational-thinking-to-boost-your-iap-revenue-by-335/|accessdate=7 December 2016}} and Vancouver, Mobile Game Asia and Israel Mobile Summit 2016.{{cite journal|title=Irrational Thinking, how we tripled our revenue in one year|url= https://www.slideshare.net/IsraelMobileSummit/irrational-thinking-how-we-tripled-our-revenue-in-one-year-cvetan-rusimov-imperia-online|accessdate=22 June 2016}} Apart from that the company attended Electronic Entertainment Expo in Los Angeles, USA. In November Cvetan Rusimov, was a speaker at Game Connection Paris for a second consecutive year.{{cite journal|title =How to hack gamer’s brains|url=http://www.game-connection.com/how-hack-gamers-brains-and-what-imperia-looking-game-connection-europe-2016/|accessdate=4 July 2016}} From the end of October 2016 until mid-December the fifth Imperia Online World cup was held and it was won by Poland. In the beginning of 2017, in January, Cvetan Rusimov attended the International Mobile Gaming Awards (IMGA) in China where he was a member of the jury.{{cite journal|title =International Mobile Gaming Awards China|url=http://china.imgawards.com/en/jury/cvetan-rusimov/|accessdate= 12 January 2017}}{{cite journal|title=IMGA China|url=http://sanwen.net/a/rowxyqo.html|accessdate= 14 February 2017}} Immediately after that he attended the Mobile Games Forum in UK where he was a speaker.{{cite journal|title=Mobile Games Forum 2017|url=https://www.globalmgf.com/london/speakers/|accessdate=18 January 2017}} The next month the COO of the company, took part in the 4th GameFounders international investment program as one of the three mentors at Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. Also that month Imperia Online was the first web-based game to integrate ClanPlay{{cite journal|title=ClanPlay provides messaging platform for clan-based mobile games|url=https://venturebeat.com/2017/02/17/clanplay-provides-clan-based-multiplayer-platform-for-mobile-games/|accessdate=17 February 2017}} - a social app for better communication for players to use in-game. Meanwhile, the team attended Casual Connect in Berlin. In March Imperia Online JSC stepped into partnership with Play 3arabi - a mobile game publisher focused on the MENA region - releasing Kingdoms Online which is an adapted mobile version of Imperia Online for the Arabic-speaking players in the MENA region.{{cite journal|title=Kingdoms Online|url=https://www.play3arabi.com/games/kingdoms_online/|accessdate=1 March 2017}} The same month the company's COO, Cvetan Rusimov was one of the speakers at Global Mobile Game Confederation (GMGC) in Beijing.{{cite journal|title=Global Mobile Game Confederation 2017|url=http://en.beijing.gmgc.info/index.php#speakers|accessdate=17 March 2017}} He attended another conference later that month called Digital Games Conference (DGC) in Dubai - where he held another lecture.{{cite journal|title=Hacking the human brain. Irrational thinking will triple your revenue|url=http://www.dgcgames.com/#Schedule/|accessdate=21 March 2017}} At the end of March 2017 Imperia Online JSC, partnered with Huawei Company released their game Imperia Online on HiGame - Huawei's android mobile game platform. In April, Cvetan Rusimov was a speaker at Reboot Develop 2017. The COO, Cvetan Rusimov hit another speaking stage at Game Access in Czech Republic. The COO also joined Casual Connect Asia. Meanwhile, the studio became part of the 25 most valuable companies income-wise in Bulgaria's IT industry according to Capital Magazine's case study. Mariela Tzvetanova, CMO at Imperia Online, was one of the key speakers of Israel Mobile Summit, presenting the lecture Beauty and the Beast of Brand Diversification. At the end of June 2017, Cvetan Rusimov, was back on the stage during Pocket Gamer Connects in San Francisco with the session “Why US games can’t copy their own success in China - and how to fix this”. Meanwhile, Mariela Tzvetanova attended Game Development Summit (GDS) and presented: Beauty and the Beast of Brand Diversification. The MMO Game of Emperors was launched on Steam. Later on, in August, the COO, Cvetan Rusimov was a lector at Game Scope and a keynote speaker at Devcom in Cologne - where he held another lecture. In the beginning of September Cvetan Rusimov was a speaker at Dev.Play Conference. During that time the CMO, Mariela Tzvetanova was one of the speakers of Pocket Gamer Connects in Helsinki, presenting "Тop 10 Tips – How To Work With MENA Influencers". In October, as a premium partner of Huawei Mobile, the company was invited to the official announcement of HiApp Europe in Berlin. Right after, both Cvetan Rusimov and Mariela Tzvetanova gave separate talks at Game Connection in Paris. At the end of the year the studio's COO Cvetan Rusimov was a jury for a second time at IMGA China. At the end of 2017 Game of Emperors was launched on Windows. In January, 2018 Cvetan Rusimov was part of the Prize Judges of Indie Prize at Casual Connect America. The same month Mariela Tzvetanova gave a talk on: 'Social Media Manager vs. Community Manager: What's the Difference?' at Pocket Gamer Connects in London. == Figures == * As of January 2018 Imperia Online JSC, has more than 40 million registered users in its main product - Imperia Online. * The company and its games have nearly 650,000 fans across their [[Facebook]] pages. * The annual revenue of Imperia Online JSC for 2017 is 5,3 Million Euro. * The revenue for the period 2012-2017 is 33,2 Million Euro. * The game production company currently resides on 1,200 square meters of office space in Bulgaria's most luxurious office building - [http://www.buildingoftheyear.bg/en/buildings/view/299/Infinity-Tower.html Infinity Tower].{{cite web|title=National Contest BUILDING OF THE YEAR |url=http://www.buildingoftheyear.bg/en/buildings/view/299/Infinity-Tower.html|accessdate=13 January 2015|language=Bulgarian}} * As of January 2018 Imperia Online JSC has more than 55 employees. * Imperia Online JSC and its products are popular in more than 194 countries. == Games == {| class="wikitable" |- ! real-time strategy game|MMORTS]] |Adapted mobile version of Imperia Online for the Arabic-speaking players in the MENA region. |} == Training and education == In 2013 Imperia Online JSC established the first tuition-free school for game developers in Bulgaria. It was originally named Imperial Training Camp and its first season prepared 40 enthusiasts for the professional [[PHP]]/[[MySQL]] and [[Java (programming language)|Java]]/[[Android (operating system)|Android]] fields. 20 of those 40 graduates were hired by Imperia Online JSC, and the rest were recommended to other software companies. In 2014 the second season of IO's Training Camp drew even higher interest and this time there were 80 students, divided into 4 groups of 20: 62 graduated, of which 30 were hired by Imperia Online JSC. For the third season Imperia Online JSC was joined by another Bulgarian company - Trader.bg - and the school was renamed to “IT Talents Training Camp”. By that time the courses are [[PHP]]/ [[MySQL]], [[Java (programming language)|Java]]/ [[Android (operating system)|Android]], [[JavaScript]], [[Objective-C]]/[[iOS]], and [[Java SE]] / [[Java EE]]. In January 2015 the third season ended with a big part of the 115 participants getting hired. Every year, there are 180 cadets successfully graduated from the academy. IT Talents Training Camp is already partnering with over 80 companies in the IT industry, to provide them qualified IT specialists. The initiative registers more than 2000 applications per season, from which around 200 most motivated candidates are allowed to enter the intensive 5-month courses. IT Talents is an NGO since 2016 and is provided with Google Ad Grants, enabling free AdWords campaigns. As of November 2017, The Municipality of Burgas organizes a 5-month program in cooperation with IT Talents. The training is again completely free and the applications are done by filling in a short registration form. == Outsourcing == In May 2015 Imperia Online JSC founded a private company for IT outsourcing called Imperia Mobile Ltd. Till the end of the year the new unit led by Radoslav Gaydarski had already successfully released more than 10 major projects. The outsourcing company offers a full range of services to execute a technical project and overcome any challenges, relying on the full capacity of over 165 professional developers, designers, artists, QA specialists and business developers. In January 2017 Imperia Mobile Ltd. started a rebranding process to the new name of Upnetix, which was completed in April 2017. The company has over 50 released projects and know-how in more than 10 industries. == Awards and nominations == Imperia Online JSC was awarded in the ‘Corporate and Social Responsibility’ Category and nominated for the ‘Education’ Category of BAIT's 2014 Awards.{{cite web|url=http://www.whoiswho.bg/en/charts/bait_awards_for_2014_the_winners/|title=List of winners |accessdate=6 February 2015}} Imperia Online JSC was proclaimed ‘A Rising Star’ in [[Deloitte]]’s Fastest Growing IT companies ranking for 2014 with a growth of 498%.{{cite journal|title=Technology Fast 50 Powerful connections|journal=Deloitte: Technology Fast 50 Powerful connections|url=http://www2.deloitte.com/content/dam/Deloitte/global/Documents/About-Deloitte/CE_FAST50_2014.pdf|accessdate=13 January 2015}}{{cite web|title=Deloitte: Mnemonica AD and Imperia Online are Bulgaria’s fastest growing technology company|url=http://www2.deloitte.com/bg/en/pages/finance/articles/tf50-2014-bg.html|website=www2.deloitte.com|accessdate=13 January 2015}} Imperia Online JSC was nominated in three categories of the 2014|url=http://blog.imperiaonline.bg/en/?p=155|website=blog.imperiaonline.bg|accessdate=13 January 2015}} In 2015 Imperia Online JSC was awarded by [[Deloitte]] as the 14th fastest growing IT company in Central Europe, having 592% revenue growth from 2011 to 2014.{{cite journal|title=Technology Fast 50 Powerful Connections 2015|journal=Deloitte: Technology Fast 50 Powerful
