Seasons of War got nominated for Indie Prize at Casual Connect in Berlin.{{cite journal|title= Casual Connect Berlin 2017 2017|url=http://indieprize.org/berlin2017/index.html#entry-105|accessdate=5 January 2017}} In February Imperia Online's game Viber Emperors was nominated at the 13th International Mobile Game Awards.{{cite journal|title=IMGA 2017|url=http://www.imgawards.com/news/13th-international-mobile-gaming-awards-global-nominations-announced/|accessdate=2 February 2017}} In April Imperia Online's Kingdoms Online received a nomination for E-volution Awards by Forbes Bulgaria for the category "Going Abroad".{{cite web|title=E-volution Awards|url=http://forbesbulgaria.bg/forbes-e-volution-awards/|accessdate=28 April 2017}} The same month Viber Emperors won the prize in "Best Gaming App" Category at the Webit Awards 2017 held in Sofia, Bulgaria.{{cite web|url=http://www.manager.bg/pr-i-sbitiya/webit-razdade-godishnite-si-nagradi|title=13-th Webit Awards 2017|accessdate=28 April 2017}} Company's CEO, Dobroslav Dimitrov was а finalist at the 10th edition of “Manager of the Year” contest for Bulgaria organized by Manager Magazine.{{cite web|url=https://mng.manager.bg/|title=“Manager of the Year”|accessdate=26 February 2018}} In September 2017, the flagship title of the company - Imperia Online was among the nominated games for favourite Strategy at TIGA Awards.{{cite web|url=https://tiga.org/awards/2017-winners|title=TIGA Awards|accessdate=26 February 2018}} A month later, Imperia Online JSC got a nomination at The Global Entrepreneurship Monitor (GEM) for the category Partnerships for the cooperation with Game Troopers on Windows platform.{{cite web|url=http://gemorg.bg/gem-bulgaria-awards-2017/|title=The Global Entrepreneurship Monitor (GEM)|accessdate=26 February 2018}} In December, Imperia Online JSC was announced as one of the finalists at the National contest “Innovative Enterprise of the Year”.{{cite web|url=http://enterprise-europe-network.bg/bg/topic/news/?nid=18097|title=Innovative Enterprise of the Year|accessdate=26 February 2018}} At the end of 2017, Imperia Online JSC won three awards at Forbes Business Awards in the following categories:{{cite web|url=http://forbesbulgaria.bg/2017/12/14/%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B5%D0%B4%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%BB%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B5-%D0%B2%D1%8A%D0%B2-forbes-business-awards-2017-%D1%81%D0%B0-%D0%B8%D0%B7%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%B8/|title=Forbes Business Awards|accessdate=26 February 2018}} * Business Development, * Client Policy, * Human Resources. Imperia Online JSC was awarded in the ‘Best Bulgarian ICT Product’ Category of BAIT's 2017 Awards for the game Kingdoms Online - fully localized in Arabic. {{cite web|url=https://bait-awards.bg/pages/English/|title=BAIT Awards 2017|accessdate=28 February 2018}} In January 2018 Imperia Online JSC was among the finalists at “Europеan Business Awards" "One to Watch" List for Bulgaria in International Expansion category.{{cite web|url=https://www.businessawardseurope.com/vote/detail-new/31/22956|title=Europеan Business Awards|accessdate=26 February 2018}} ==References== {{reflist}} == External links== * {{Official website|www.imperiaonline.bg}} [[Category:Browser-based game websites]] [[Category:Video game development companies]] [[Category:Video game publishers]] [[Category:Video game companies of Bulgaria]]

{{Otheruses|Mission: Impossible (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox video game | title = Impossible Mission II | image = Impossible Mission II Coverart.png | caption = | developer = [[Appaloosa Interactive|Novotrade]] | publisher = [[Epyx]] | designer = | series = | engine = | released = [[1988 in video gaming|1988]] | genre = [[Action game|Action]] | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]] | platforms = [[Amiga]], [[Amstrad CPC]], [[Apple IIe]], [[Apple IIc]], [[Apple IIgs]], [[Atari ST]], [[Commodore 64]], [[DOS]], [[NES]], [[ZX Spectrum]] }}
'''''Impossible Mission II''''' is a 1988 [[computer game]] developed by [[Appaloosa Interactive|Novotrade]] and published by [[Epyx]]. It was released for the [[Commodore 64]], [[ZX Spectrum]], [[Amstrad CPC]], [[Enterprise 128|Enterprise 64 and 128]], [[Nintendo Entertainment System]], [[MS-DOS]] based PCs, [[Atari ST]], [[Apple IIe]] with at least 128K, [[Apple IIc]], [[Apple IIGS]] and [[Amiga]] computers. In 2004, it was one of the games featured on the [[C64 Direct-to-TV]].
''Impossible Mission II'' is a direct sequel to Epyx's 1984 game ''[[Impossible Mission]]''. The game follows directly from the same plot, with Elvin Atombender seeking revenge, and the player having to stop him. The overall game structure and basic gameplay is mostly similar, but there are a few differences and new features.
==Gameplay== The game takes place in Elvin's [[fortress]], which consists of nine [[tower]]s.<ref name="Retro122">{{cite news | last = Bevan | first= Mike | date = December 2013 | title = The History of... Impossible Mission | work = [[Retro Gamer]] | issue = 122 | pages = 44–49 | publisher = [[Imagine Publishing]]}}</ref> Each of the eight outer towers has a specific theme, such as [[computer]]s, [[automobile]]s, [[furniture]] and so on. Each tower consists of several rooms connected by two vertical corridors with [[elevator]]s and two horizontal corridors leading to other towers. The corridors leading between different towers are locked, and can only be unlocked by figuring out a numerical puzzle.
Each tower contains the numbers zero through nine in three different colors. The computer interface allows the player to try various number combinations to see if they are correct.
The elevator to the central tower is unlocked by finding a [[password]], which is encoded in a piece of [[music]]. Each of the eight outer towers has a musical piece locked inside a safe.<ref name="Retro122"/> The final password consists of six distinct musical pieces. Two of the pieces in the towers are duplicates. The player must rewind the tape so that the next musical piece records over the duplicate, erasing it.
The main addition over the previous game is the addition of new types of enemy [[robot]]s and devices for the player to use. Whereas the original game only included security bots and a special flying [[ball]] robot, ''Impossible Mission II'' has the following types of robots: * Security bot, like in the previous game. * Shovel bot, tries to push the player character over the edge of a platform. * Suicide bot, like a shovel bot, but also jumps off the edge itself. * Mine bot, lays deadly [[land mine]]s on the floor. * Pest bot, is harmless to the touch, but rides around on the lifts, foiling the player's designs. * Squat bot, springs up from the floor, sending the player character onto a higher floor or crushing him against the ceiling. The "ball" type robot is no longer present.
As well as snoozes that temporarily freeze the robots and lift resets, the player can now collect [[bomb]]s and mines that can be used to blow up holes in the floor, or to open [[safe]]s. Bombs explode after a specific time, whereas mines explode if the player or an enemy robot touches them.
==Development== Unlike most computer game sequels of the time, ''Impossible Mission II'' did not use any code from the original game.<ref name="Retro122"/> The graphics were remade from scratch using a [[raster graphics|bitmap]] animation tool called Film Director.<ref name="Retro122"/> The lead platform was the [[Atari ST]], with work on the [[Commodore 64]] and [[ZX Spectrum]] ports being started once the Atari ST version was nearly complete.<ref name="Retro122"/> All the rooms in ''Impossible Mission II'' were redesigned for the ZX Spectrum version.<ref name="Retro122"/>
According to Novotrade programmer László Szenttornyai, who coded the Spectrum version, the [[NES]] version of the game "almost wasn't released because of the strict situation between [[Epyx]] and [[Nintendo]]."<ref name="Retro122"/>
==Reception== {{Video game reviews | YSinclair = 9/10<ref name="YSinc">{{cite news | last = David | first = McCandless | date = September 1988 | title = Impossible Mission II review | url = http://www.ysrnry.co.uk/articles/impossiblemissionii.htm | work = [[Your Sinclair]] | issue = 33 | page = | publisher = [[Dennis Publishing]]}}</ref> | CRASH = 84%<ref name="Crash">{{cite news | last = | first = | date = | title = Reviews: Impossible Mission II | url = http://www.worldofspectrum.org/showmag.cgi?mag=Crash/Issue55/Pages/Crash5500016.jpg | work = [[Crash (magazine)|Crash]] | issue = 55 | page = 16 | publisher = [[Newsfield Publications]]}}</ref> | SUser = 46%<ref name="SUser">{{cite news | last = Dillon | first = Tony | date = September 1988 | title = Games Review: Impossible Mission 2 | url = http://www.worldofspectrum.org/showmag.cgi?mag=SinclairUser/Issue078/Pages/SinclairUser07800064.jpg | work = [[Sinclair User]] | issue = 78 | page = 64 | publisher = [[EMAP]]}}</ref> | CVG = 90%<ref name="CVG">{{cite news | last = | first = | date = | title = Impossible Mission II review | url = http://www.worldofspectrum.org/showmag.cgi?mag=C+VG/Issue106/Pages/CVG10600060.jpg | work = [[Computer and Video Games]] | issue = 106 | page = 60 | publisher = [[Future Publishing]]}}</ref> | rev2 = ''[[ACE (games magazine)|ACE]]'' | rev2Score = 785<ref name="ACE">{{cite news | last = Conner | first = Pete | date = June 1988 | title = Impossible Mission 2 review | url = http://www.worldofspectrum.org/showmag.cgi?mag=ACE/Issue09/Pages/ACE0900058.jpg | work = [[ACE (games magazine)|ACE]] | issue = 9 | page = 58 | publisher = [[Future Publishing]]}}</ref> | rev3 = ''[[The Games Machine]]'' | rev3Score = 73%<ref name="GMach">{{cite news | last = | first = | date = | title = Version Update: Impossible Mission II | url = http://www.worldofspectrum.org/showmag.cgi?mag=TheGamesMachine/Issue10/Pages/TheGamesMachine1000044.jpg | work = [[The Games Machine]] | issue = 10 | page = 44 | publisher = [[Newsfield Publications]]}}</ref> | rev1 = ''[[Zzap!64]]'' | rev1Score = 96%<ref name="ZZap">{{cite web|url=http://www.zzap64.co.uk/zzap100/100thspec5.html |title=Zzap!64 100th Issue Pull-Out Special Page 5 |publisher=Zzap64.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-02-11}}</ref> | award1Pub = Zzap!64 | award1 = Gold Medal<ref name="ZZap"/> }} The game received mixed reviews from critics. Common criticisms were the game's overt similarity to and lack of improvement from the original ''Impossible Mission''<ref name="ACE"/><ref name="GMach"/> and the extremely limited sound.<ref name="SUser"/><ref name="GMach"/> However, the challenging puzzles,<ref name="YSinc"/><ref name="ACE"/><ref name="Crash"/> impressive player character animations,<ref name="Crash"/><ref name="YSinc"/><ref name="CVG"/> and the tension of playing against the clock<ref name="Crash"/><ref name="CVG"/> were all praised by multiple critics.
==Sequels== ''Impossible Mission'' and ''Impossible Mission II'' were followed by ''[[Impossible Mission 2025]]'', an Amiga exclusive. ''Impossible Mission 2025'' abandoned the corridor layout of different rooms and instead includes one big room. The player also has the choice of three different characters: the normal secret agent, a female [[gymnast]], and an [[Android (robot)|android]].

[[File:Nadya park design center building.JPG|200px|right|thumb|International Design Centre Nagoya]] The {{nihongo|'''International Design Center NAGOYA and Design Museum'''|国際デザインセンター|Kokusai Dezain Sentā}}, abbreviated as ''IdcN'', is a museum and exhibition hall located in [[Sakae, Nagoya]], central [[Japan]].
== History == Located in the downtown area of Sakae, the museum was established in 1992 and is housed in the Nadya Park skyscraper. Exhibited are leading designers and artists of conceptualisation, form and function. The pieces range from the [[Art Deco]] to the present. Works by [[Isamu Noguchi]] and [[Arne Jacobsen]] are included, as well as product design icons such as the [[Mini Cooper]].
The Loft department store for shoppers interested in design is also located in Nadya Park.
Access by public transport is [[Yabachō Station]] on the [[Meijō Line]].
== External links == * [http://www.idcn.jp/ Homepage of the IdcN]

{{Infobox company | name = Iron Crown Enterprises | logo = Ironcrownclassic.png | logo_size = 250px | caption = ICE's "Classic" logo | successor = [[Aurigas Aldebaron]] LLC, [[Guild Companion Publications]] | foundation = 1980 | location = Virginia | industry = Gaming | key_people = [[Pete Fenlon]], [[S. Coleman Charlton]], Bruce Neidlinger, Rick Britton, [[Terry K. Amthor]] | products = ''[[MERP]]'', [[Rolemaster]], [[High Adventure Role Playing]] (HARP), HARP SF, HARP SF Xtreme, [[Shadow World (role playing game)|Shadow World]], Spacemaster | num_employees = | parent = }} '''Iron Crown Enterprises''' ('''ICE''') has produced role playing, board, miniature, and collectible card games since 1980. Many of ICE's better-known products were related to [[J. R. R. Tolkien]]'s world of [[Middle-earth]], but the ''[[Rolemaster]]'' rules system, and its science-fiction equivalent, ''Spacemaster'', have been the foundation of ICE's business.
==History== In college in the late 1970s, while running a six-year ''[[Dungeons & Dragons]]'' campaign set in J.R.R. Tolkien's Middle-earth, [[Pete Fenlon]], [[S. Coleman Charlton]], and [[Kurt Fischer (game designer)|Kurt Fischer]] began to develop a set of unique house rules; after most of them had graduated from the [[University of Virginia]] in 1980, many of the group's principals decided to turn their rules into a business and formed Iron Crown Enterprises (ICE), named after a regalia of Middle-earth.<ref name="designers">{{Cite book|author=Shannon Appelcline|title=Designers & Dragons|publisher=Mongoose Publishing|year=2011| isbn= 978-1-907702-58-7}}</ref>{{rp|133}} Besides Felon and Charlton, the original ICE also included [[Rick Britton|Richard H. Britton]], [[Terry K. Amthor]], [[Bruce Shelley]], [[Bruce Neidlinger]], Kurt Fischer, [[Heike Kubasch]], Olivia Fenlon, and a few others.<ref name="designers"/>{{rp|133}}
ICE was incorporated in 1980, shortly after the youngest of the principal founders graduated from the [[University of Virginia]]. Among the founders were [[Pete Fenlon]] (then in Law school), [[Rick Britton]], [[S. Coleman Charlton]], Bruce Neidlinger, [[Terry K. Amthor]], Kurt Fischer, [[Bruce Shelley]], and [[Heike Kubasch]]. The company originally only had a few full-time staff, relying on volunteer work from the other founders. But as income increased, it brought more on as employees.<ref>http://www.escapistmagazine.com/articles/view/tabletop/columns/days-of-high-adventure/7337-Rolemaster-Puppetmaster-Catan-Master-Pete-Fenlon</ref>
ICE quickly published three products: ''[[Arms Law]]'' (1980), ''The Iron Wind'' (1980), and ''Manassas'' (1981).<ref name="designers"/>{{rp|133}} ''Arms Law'' was the first release of the house rules from the University of Virginia days, and thus became the start of ''[[Rolemaster]]'', although at that time ''Rolemaster'' was not seen as a standalone RPG but was offered as an alternative combat system for ''AD&D''.<ref name="designers"/>{{rp|133}} ''The Iron Wind'' was a system-generic campaign centered on a fantastic island, and although it was unsupplemented for years it would eventually be recognized as the first release in ICE's ''Loremaster'' campaign setting.<ref name="designers"/>{{rp|133}} ''Manassas'' was a Civil War era [[Miniature wargaming|wargame]] set in ICE's home state of Virginia.<ref name="designers"/>{{rp|133}}
ICE began by publishing a series of rules supplements, beginning with "Arms Law", which were intended to serve as modular add-ons to other RPG systems offering greater detail. This was followed by "Spell Law" and Character/Campaign Law." In time, these supplements were tied together to form an RPG system of their own, ''[[Rolemaster]]''. Concurrent with the rules supplements, ICE began releasing world campaign content materials in what was originally called the "Loremaster" series, beginning with "Iron Wind".
''Rolemaster'' had grown out of a Middle-earth game, so ICE approached [[Tolkien Enterprises]] seeking a license to ''The Hobbit'' and ''The Lord of the Rings'', which Tolkien Enterprises granted because no one else had ever asked.<ref name="designers"/>{{rp|134}} Tolkien Enterprises signed an exclusive, worldwide license with ICE in 1982, and ICE started the Middle-earth line off with a generic sourcebook that could be used with AD&D or other games, called ''A Campaign and Adventure Guidebook for Middle-earth'' (1982).<ref name="designers"/>{{rp|134}}
The company enjoyed a sudden jump in status when it acquired the license to produce an official fantasy RPG based upon [[J. R. R. Tolkien]]'s world of [[Middle-earth]], which would come to be known as ''MERP'' ("[[Middle-earth Role Playing]]"). According to some interpretations, at the time of its publication ICE's ''Middle-earth Role Playing'' was the second best selling fantasy RPG after [[TSR, Inc.|TSR]]'s ''[[Dungeons & Dragons]]''.
ICE then added the science fiction RPGs ''[[Spacemaster]]'' and ''[[Cyberspace (role-playing game)|Cyberspace]]'' to its line, and, with the rise of [[collectible card game]]s, the ''[[Middle-earth Collectible Card Game]]''. ICE also published a moderately successful space miniatures battle game called ''[[Silent Death]]'', based on ''Spacemaster'' but with simpler mechanics. ''Silent Death'' was released in two major editions, with supplemental books and a fair number of paintable lead miniatures.<ref name="bh8">{{cite web |last=Appelcline |first=Shannon |coauthors= |title= #8: ICE, Part One: 1980-1992 |url=http://www.rpg.net/columns/briefhistory/briefhistory8.phtml |date=2006-11-21 |work=A Brief History of Game |publisher=RPGnet |accessdate=10 July 2009}}</ref> ICE also expanded its original Loremaster supplements into a full-blown fantasy world to support [[Rolemaster]], called the [[Shadow World (role playing game)|Shadow World]], supported by dozens of adventures and sourcebooks. ICE signed in 1986 a publication contract to take over [[Hero Games]]' production and distribution. Later with Hero Games staff leaving for other jobs, ICE took over the creative reins of Hero's products.<ref name="bh8"/>
Iron Crown branched out into the solo gaming books under the Tolkien Quest (later called Middle-earth Quest) and Sherlock Holmes Solo Mysteries book lines.<ref name="bh8"/> Unknown to ICE at the time, the Middle-earth Quest books violated ICE and Tolkien Enterprises' contract with Tolkien's book publishing licensee, George Allen & Unwin. (ICE and TE considered the books to be games, and so fall under their license, but the format came too close to being literary books). ICE was forced to recall and destroy the whole line of books, at devastating cost. Meanwhile, ICE sued the Narnia licensor as they turned out to not have the necessary rights to license Narnia to ICE. That company went bankrupt from the legal settlement and was unable to pay ICE their damages. ICE reached terms in 1988 for a gamebook license with the estate of J.R.R. Tolkien and George Allen & Unwin for four new Middle-earth Quest books, beginning with "Spy in Isengard". However, the solo game book market was going soft by this time. ICE canceled all solo game book lines, with dozens of books still in development. Returns were high on the [[Sherlock Holmes]] Solo Mysteries line. All this brought ICE to near bankruptcy in a "voluntary-type of receivership".<ref name="bh8"/>
Despite ICE's many successes and overcoming many setbacks over 17 years, in 1997 ICE suffered financial difficulties from a rapid decline in its distribution net; nearly 70% of ICE's distributors either went bankrupt or became moribund. There has been some debate over whether Tolkien Enterprises forced ICE into bankruptcy in order to get the gaming license in anticipation of the upcoming new movie franchise.<ref name="rpg.net">https://www.rpg.net/columns/briefhistory/briefhistory9.phtml</ref>
The company entered bankruptcy and filed for [[Chapter 7, Title 11, United States Code|Chapter 7]] in October 2000. This bankruptcy cost ICE the Middle-earth license, ending both the [[MERP]] and [[Collectible card game|CCG]] lines. Many of the authors and illustrators were not paid for substantial amounts of work.<ref name="rpg.net"/>
===Aurigas Aldebaron=== [[File:Ironcrownenterprises.png|thumb|right|ICE's logo since relaunch]] In December 2001, ICE's assets were purchased by [[Aurigas Aldebaron]] LLLC, an [[intellectual property]] ownership company backed by several wealthy individuals. The new owners licensed the Iron Crown Enterprise name and other assets to [[Mjolnir LLC]] until 2011. Starting in January 2011, licensing was transferred to Guild Companion Publications Ltd.
In 2016 Aurigas Alderbaron merged with Guild Companion Publications Ltd to create a single company: Guild Companion Publications. This company both holds the Iron Crown Enterprises intellectual property and produces and sells Iron Crown products.
==Publications==

The Dwarven City (1984)'' *''[[Middle-earth Role Playing|MERP]] - Middle-earth Role Playing'' (1984) **''Bree and the Barrow-Downs'' (1984) **''Dark Mage of Rhudaur'' (1989) **''Lords of Middle-Earth'' (1986) **''Minas Tirith'' (1988) **''Minas Ithil'' (1991) **''Palantir Quest'' (1994) **''Kin-Strife'' (1995) **''Hands of the Healer'' (1997) *''[[Rolemaster]]'' - a historical setting source book for Rolemaster'' (1991) ** ''At Rapier's Point - a historical setting source book for Rolemaster'' (1993) ** ''Oriental Companion - a historical setting source book for Rolemaster'' (1993) ** ''Shadow World: The Cloudlords of Tanara'' (1982, 2013) ** ''Shadow World Master Atlas (4th Edition)'' (2003, 2011) ** ''Shadow World Master Atlas (3rd Edition)'' (2001, 2011) ** ''Shadow World powers of Light and Darkness'' (2003, 2011) ** ''Demons on the Burning Night'' (1989, 2011) ** ''Islands of the Oracle'' (1989, 2011) ** ''Kingdom of the Desert Jewel'' (1989, 2011) ** ''Quellbourne: Land of the Silver Mist'' (1989, 2011) *''[[Spacemaster]]'' - An adaption of ''Rolemaster'' in a sci-fi setting. first edition (1985), second edition (1988) ** ''Future Law'' (1985) ** ''Tech Law'' (1985) ** ''Action On Akaisha Outstation'' (1985) ** ''Imperial Crisis'' (1985) ** ''Spacemaster Companion'' (1986) ** ''Lost Telepaths'' (1986) ** ''Beyond The Core'' (1987) ** ''The Cygnus Conspiracy'' (1987) ** ''Tales From Deep Space'' (1988) ** ''War on a Distant Moon'' (1988) ** ''The Durandrium Find'' (1989) ** ''Disaster on Adanis III'' (1989) ** ''Raiders from the Frontier'' (1989) ** ''Spacemaster Companion I'' (1990) ** ''Dark Space'' (1990) ** ''Aliens & Artifacts'' (1991) ** ''Time Riders'' (1992) ** ''Spacemaster Companion II'' (1994) *''[[Cyberspace (role-playing game)|Cyberspace]]'' (1989) ** ''Cyberspace Core Rulebook'' (1989) ** ''Sprawlgangs & Megacorps'' (1990) ** ''Edge On'' (1990) ** ''Cyber Rogues'' (1990) ** ''The Body Bank'' (1990) ** ''Death Valley Free Prison'' (1990) ** ''Death Game 2090'' (1990) ** ''Cyberskelter'' (1991) ** ''Chicago Arcology'' (1991) ** ''Cyber Europe'' (1991) *''Campaign Classics'' line - dual statted for ''Hero System'' and ''Rolemaster'': ** ''Robin Hood'' (1987) ** ''Mythic Greece'' (1988) ** ''Vikings'' (1989) ** ''Pirates'' (1989) ** ''Mythic Egypt'' (1990) ** ''Arabian Nights'' (1994) (actually a "Rolemaster Genre Book" without ''Hero System'' stats) *''[[Lord of the Rings Adventure Game]]'' (1991) * ''[[High Adventure Role Playing]]'' (2003, 2004, 2011) ** ''HARP College of Magics'' (2004, 2013) ** ''HARP Martial Law'' (2003, 2004, 2013)

revision.comment: self-published family trees are not reliable sources
revision.text:
'''Jacob's Inn''' was a notable 18th century inn located in [[Thompson, Connecticut]].
The inn was founded by Nathaniel Jacobs, who was born in [[Hingham, Massachusetts]] in 1683. He bought two large properties in Thompson in for $5400 in 1742, and stayed there for the rest of his life. He was an important member of the [[Congregational Church]] He died in 1772 at age 90, and the inn was taken over by his son John Jacobs after his death.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Cutter|first1=William Richard|title=New England Families, Genealogical and Memorial: A Record of the ..., Volume 1}}</ref> John Jacobs was known as 'Landlord Jacobs.' The Inn was called a Halfway House because it was approximately halfway between [[Hartford]] and [[Boston]].
The inn was notable because both [[George Washington]] and the [[Marquis de Lafayette]] spent time there. Washington once wrote in his journal that he apparently did not enjoy a breakfast that he had at the inn.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Thompson Historical Society Newsletter|url=http://www.thompsonhistorical.org/Newsletters/2001_WINTER.PDF|website=The Thompson Historical Society}}</ref> Once, Washington's coach left the inn without him, but he was able to overtake it on foot. Also notably, Lafayette left his masonic apron at the Inn, and it was passed down through the Jacobs family. <ref>{{cite book|last1=Carleton|first1=Hiram|title=Genealogical and Family History of the State of Vermont: A Record ..., Volume 1}}</ref>

{{multiple issues| {{unsourced|date=June 2015}} {{plot|date=August 2015}} }} {{Infobox film |name = Kickboxer 5: The Redemption |image = Kickboxer 5.jpg |caption = DVD cover |director = [[Kristine Peterson]] |producer = Michael S. Murphey |writer = Rick Filon |starring = [[Mark Dacascos]]
[[James_Ryan_(actor)|James Ryan]] |music = [[John Massari]] |cinematography = Paul Michelson |editing = Kert Vandermeulen |studio = Kings Road Entertainment |distributor = [[Trimark Pictures|Vidmark Entertainment]] |released = {{Film date|1995|8}} |runtime = 87 minutes |country = United States |language = English |budget = |gross = }} '''''Redemption: Kickboxer 5''''' (also known as '''''Kickboxer 5: The Redemption''''' and simply as '''''The Redemption''''' on the opening title card) is a 1995 [[direct-to-video]] American [[martial arts film]] starring [[Mark Dacascos]] and directed by Kristine Peterson. The film is the fifth entry in the [[Kickboxer (film series)|''Kickboxer'' franchise]] and the first to have a plot that does not revolve around a member of the Sloane family. It instead revolves around a character named Matt Reeves, said in dialogue to be a friend of the Sloane family. ==Plot== Negaal is a South African former kickboxer turned promoter who is gearing up to start his own kickboxing organization. When American champion David Sloane refuses to join, Negaal sends his men Moon, Bull, and Pinto to eliminate Sloane. Seen in a bluescreen opening credit sequence, Sloane manages to break Moon's leg but is ultimately killed by Bull and Pinto. Matt Reeves is a former kickboxer turned martial arts teacher. As a friend of Sloane's, he is shocked to learn of his death. That night, his one-time student Johnny Styles is competing for the now vacant United States Championship. When Johnny wins the title, he is approached by Moon, Bull, and Pinto to join the Negaal Kickboxing Federation. Johnny decides to meet with the trio but Matt is suspicious. When his friend Charlie informs him that the three men also talked to David just two days before he was found murdered, Matt races to find Johnny. Johnny refuses the offer from Negaal and is forced to fight Bull and Pinto who overwhelm him and break his back. Matt arrives to fend them off but he is too late to help Johnny. When Negaal gets word of what has happened, he wants Matt dead. Bollen, Negaal's right hand man, recruits Paul Croft, a former member of Negaal's organization who is freed from prison on the condition he kills Matt. That night, Matt is confronted by Paul, who instead of killing him, warns him about Negaal. Matt decides to head to Johannesburg, South Africa to find Negaal. Paul finds out Matt is on the plane and the two end up sitting next to each other. When they arrive at the airport, Moon is awaiting Paul, who hides Matt in an attempt to prove he did his job. However, Paul attempts to escape and is confronted by Negaal's thugs until Matt arrives to help. Shocked by the turn of events, Moon escapes as does the thugs. Matt and Paul part ways and when Matt finds an address, he goes there to find a regular shop. When he inquires the shopkeeper about Negaal, Bollen just happens to be there and both he and his men attempt to go after Matt. Returning the favor from the airport incident, Paul arrives to help Matt. It is also revealed that it was Bollen who sent Paul to prison in the first place and Paul wants revenge. The duo fight off the thugs, but then find themselves arrested for causing trouble at the shop when Bollen forces the shopkeeper to rat on them. Meanwhile, Negaal has been presenting champions from all over the world with an ultimatum: join his federation or die. Fearing for his life, the French Champion reluctantly joins. After the two incidents involving Matt and Paul, Negaal confronts Moon, Bull, and Bollen and proceeds to shoot Bull in the head with a hunting rifle. When the German Champion refuses to join the federation, he challenges Negaal to a fight on the lawn. Negaal kills the German Champion with the "tiger claw", an illegal strike that he had used on the Dutch Champion years ago when he was a kickboxer, resulting in him getting a lifetime ban from the sport. With the help of fellow prisoner Joseph, Matt and Paul escape when one of the guards was revealed to be one of Negaal's men. The trio make their escape and separate with Matt and Paul catching up to Angie, who is revealed to be Paul's younger sister. She is wondering what is going on and is unhappy when it is revealed that Negaal is the reason. While Paul served his prison sentence, the patriarch of the Croft family had died. Matt and Paul convince Angie that they must stop Negaal once and for all if they are to ever be happy again. Both men begin to train with Matt discovering a way to counter Negaal's fatal blow when he breaks an arrow using his neck muscles to show that a fatal blow can in fact, be countered. As they learn Negaal is planning a major party, they decide to crash it along with Angie, who defies Matt and Paul and goes undercover as well. When Paul finally confronts Bollen in the backyard, Matt sees Negaal at the roulette table and begins to win, angering Negaal. When Negaal learns that the man who is winning is the one he's been after this whole time, Matt finally exposes Negaal to everyone for who he really is. The goons arrive and Matt defeats them all and finally is ready to take on Negaal. As the two begin their fight, they go from Negaal's office to the lawn. When Negaal attempts the "tiger claw" to Matt's neck, Matt uses his counter technique and unleashes a "tiger claw" of his own hitting Negaal right in the heart. Negaal falls and Matt proceeds back to the office, where he grabs the United States Championship belt. Negaal returns to grab the belt back. Repeating "It's mine", Matt's "tiger claw" finally takes its effect and Negaal finally dies. Matt retrieves the belt as he, Paul, and Angie walk off as police sirens are heard. ==Cast== *[[Mark Dacascos]] as Matt Reeves *[[James Ryan (actor)|James Ryan]] as Mr. Negaal *Geoff Meed as Paul Croft *Tony Caprari as Moon *Greg Latter as Bollen *Duane Porter as Bull *Georoge Moolman as Pinto *Rulan Booth as Angie Croft *Robert Whitehead as Tito *Denney Pierce as Johnny Styles *John Hussey as Chalky *Dale Cutts as Trainer *[[Gavin Hood]] as German Champion *Burton Richardson as Jack ==External links== *{{IMDb title|0110256}} {{Kickboxer}} {{Kristine Peterson}} [[Category:1995 films]] [[Category:1990s martial arts films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American martial arts films]] [[Category:Direct-to-video sequel films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films shot in South Africa]] [[Category:Kickboxer films]] [[Category:Kung fu films]] [[Category:Mixed martial arts films]] [[Category:Sequel films]]

{{Infobox person | name = Linda and Terry Jamison | image = Psychic_Twin_Photo_for_Book.jpg | caption = Linda and Terry Jamison, 2007 |residence = [[Los Angeles]], [[California]],
[[United States]] | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1965|1|12|mf=yes}} | birth_place = [[West Chester, Pennsylvania]],
[[United States]] |alma_mater = [[Temple University]] |parents = Jane Jamison
[[Philip Jamison]] | occupation = Psychics }} '''Linda and Terry Jamison''' (born January 12, 1965) are [[United States|American]] identical twins based in [[Los Angeles]], [[California]] who perform as [[psychic]]s. The Jamisons predictions have been featured in [[Tabloid journalism|tabloid newspapers]], and they have appeared in various media. They claim to have [[Mediumship|channeled]] the spirits of dead celebrities and predicted future events such as the [[September 11 attacks]], however critics question the accuracy of their predictions. == Education and background == The Jamisons grew up in [[West Chester, Pennsylvania]]. Their parents, Jane and [[Philip Jamison]], were writers and painters.{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Nightline/beyondbelief/psychic-twins-predictions-include-elections-911-attacks/story?id=13886759|title='Psychic Twins' Say Their Predictions Include Elections, 9/11 Attacks|last2=Matthews|first2=Theresa|website=abcnews.com|last3=Brown|first3=Tim|last1=Chang|first1=Juju|accessdate=29 November 2016}} The Jamisons attended [[Temple University]], and later worked as painters and performance artists. == Career as "The Psychic Twins" == After leaving West Chester, they moved to [[Los Angeles]] and refocused their career as [[psychic]]s, calling themselves "The Psychic Twins", reportedly charging more than $500 per person for psychic readings. According to the Jamisons, they have predicted the future and contacted spirits of the dead, such as [[Lady Diana]], [[Natalie Wood]] and [[Michael Jackson]].{{cite web|last1=Myall|first1=Steve|last2=Roberts|first2=Anna|title=These 'psychic' twins claim they predicted 9/11 and talk to Princess Diana|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/real-life-stories/psychic-twins-claim-predicted-911-6056128|website=Daily Mirror|publisher=Mirror Company|accessdate=14 January 2017}}{{cite web|last=Gardner|first=Chris|title=What the Psychic Twins Think Is in Store for This Year|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/what-psychic-twins-think-is-852418|website=Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=14 January 2017}} The Jamisons predictions have often been featured in tabloid newspapers such as ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'',{{cite web|last=Emery|first=Gene|title=Psychic Predictions 2004|url=http://www.csicop.org/specialarticles/show/psychic_predictions_2004|website=CSICOP|accessdate=14 January 2017}} and according to the Jamisons, they have made numerous appearances in print, television, and on stage with "major stars". The Jamisons widely claim to have predicted the [[September 11 attacks]] on the [[World Trade Center (1973–2001)|World Trade Center]] during a November 2, 1999 interview on the [[Art Bell]] radio show. However, according to show transcripts, their actual statement was: "We are seeing terrorist attacks on Federal Government, excuse me, federal buildings. Particularly South Carolina or Georgia, by July 2002 and also the New York Trade Center, the World Trade Center in 2002." The September 11 attack occurred in 2001, not 2002, and it was common knowledge that the buildings had been previously attacked by terrorists in the [[1993 World Trade Center bombing]], calling into question the Jamisons' claims.{{cite web|title=How psychic twins predicted 9/11 terrorist attacks|url=https://au.news.yahoo.com/a/9878867/how-psychic-twins-predicted-9-11-terrorist-attacks/#page1|website=[[Yahoo7]]|accessdate=29 November 2016}} [[Leon Jaroff]], in [[Time (magazine)|''Time'']], pointed out that the Jamison twins were also frequently incorrect. For example, in December 2003, the Twins predicted that [[Saddam Hussein]] would be killed by U.S. troops in early 2004, and that [[Pope John Paul II]] would die in June 2004 (he actually died in April 2005). They also incorrectly predicted that the Bush/Gore election would be a "crashing bore", and that actress [[Jennifer Lopez]] would announce that she was pregnant by June 2005.{{cite web|last=Jaroff |first=Leon |title=So Far, Psychics Are Batting .000 |url=http://www.time.com/time/columnist/jaroff/article/0,9565,1012261,00.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130831010526/http://content.time.com/time/world/article/0%2C8599%2C1012261%2C00.html |archive-date=31 August 2013 |website=Time.com |accessdate=29 November 2016 |deadurl=yes}} The Jamison twins maintain a YouTube channel on which YouTube stars [[Shane Dawson]] and [[Trisha Paytas]] have appeared. As of 2016 the twins were criticized for their inaccuracy in the Clinton/Trump election, claiming that [[Hillary Clinton|Hillary]] would win. This created a lot of backlash and controversy on YouTube. ==Books== * {{Cite book|author=Linda Jamison, Terry Jamison|title=Separated at Earth: The Story of The Psychic Twins|year=2007|publisher=Booklocker Inc|isbn=978-1-60145-109-5}} * {{Cite book|author=Linda Jamison, Terry Jamison|title=Psychic Intelligence: Tune in and Discover the Power of Your Intuition|year=2011|publisher=Grand Central Life and Style(Hachette)|isbn=978-0-446-56342-0}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{official website|psychictwins.com}} * {{IMDb name|id=3535347}}{{Authority control}} [[Category:1965 births|Jamison]] [[Category:Psychics|Jamison]] [[Category:Living people|Jamison, Linda]] [[Category:Identical twins|Jamison]] [[Category:People from West Chester, Pennsylvania|Jamison]] [[Category:Temple University Tyler School of Art alumni|Jamison]] [[Category:Performance artists|Jamison]] [[Category:Writers from Los Angeles|Jamison]] [[Category:American YouTubers]] [[Category:Comedians from California]]

page.title: List of Family Guy home video releases

revision.comment: /* Region 2 (UK and Ireland) and Region 4 (Australia and New Zealand) */
revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:List of ''Family Guy'' home video releases}} {{Refimprove|list|date=December 2009}} This is a list of [[English language]] '''''[[Family Guy]]'' DVDs''' from [[DVD region code|regions]] 1, 2, and 4. ==Season releases== ===Region 1 (U.S. and Canada)=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |- !Title!!Release date!!Episodes!!Season(s) |- |align=left |'''''Volume One'''''||April 15, 2003||28||[[Family Guy (season 1)|1]] & [[Family Guy (season 2)|2]] |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"|This four-disc box set includes all 28 episodes from Seasons 1 and 2 ("[[Death Has a Shadow]]" – "[[Fore Father]]"). Special features include 8 audio commentary tracks, Internet promo spots, and a featurette. Also available on [[Universal Media Disc|UMD]]. |- |align=left|'''''Volume Two'''''||September 9, 2003||22||[[Family Guy (season 3)|3]] |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"|This three-disc box set includes all 21 episodes from Season 3 ("[[The Thin White Line]]" – "[[Family Guy Viewer Mail 1|Family Guy Viewer Mail #1]]"), plus the previously un-aired episode, "[[When You Wish Upon a Weinstein]]". Special features include 6 audio commentary tracks, deleted scene animatics, the complete seven minute pilot pitch, and two featurettes. Also available on UMD. |- |align=left|'''''Volume Three'''''||November 29, 2005||13||[[Family Guy (season 4)|4A]] |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"|This three-disc box set includes the first 13 episodes from Season 4 ("[[North by North Quahog]]" – "[[Jungle Love (Family Guy)|Jungle Love]]"). Special features include 10 audio commentary tracks, 2 featurettes, deleted scene animatics, multi-angle table reads, storyboard/animatic comparisons, and unrated audio. |- |align=left|'''''Volume Four'''''||November 14, 2006||14||[[Family Guy (season 4)|4B]] |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"|This three-disc box set includes the remaining 14 episodes from Season 4 ("[[PTV (Family Guy)|PTV]]" – "[[The Griffin Family History]]"), excluding the three that make up ''[[Stewie Griffin: The Untold Story]]''. Special features include commentary on every episode, multi-angle scene studies, deleted scenes, 3 featurettes, unrated audio, and a DVD-ROM link to exclusive content. |- |align=left|'''''Volume Five'''''||September 18, 2007||13||[[Family Guy (season 5)|5A]] |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"|This two-disc box set includes the first 13 episodes from Season 5 ("[[Stewie Loves Lois]]" – "[[Bill and Peter's Bogus Journey]]"). Special features include commentary on every episode, 3 animatic episodes with optional commentary, deleted scenes, 2 featurettes, and unrated audio. |- |align=left|'''''Volume Six'''''||October 21, 2008||12||[[Family Guy (season 5)|5B]] & [[Family Guy (season 6)|6A]] |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"|This three-disc set includes the remaining five episodes of Season 5 and seven episodes of Season 6 ("[[No Meals on Wheels]]" – "[[McStroke]]"), excluding ''[[Blue Harvest (Family Guy)|Blue Harvest]]''. Special features include commentary on every episode, deleted scenes, featurettes, the original televised version of each episode, unrated audio, 3 animatic episodes with optional commentary, and the "Family Guy 100th Episode Special". |- |align=left|'''''Volume Seven'''''||June 16, 2009||13||[[Family Guy (season 6)|6B]] & [[Family Guy (season 7)|7A]] |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"|This three-disc set includes the remaining four episodes of Season 6 and the first nine episodes of Season 7 ("[[Back to the Woods (Family Guy)|Back to the Woods]]" – "[[The Juice Is Loose]]"). Special features include commentaries on every episode, deleted scenes, and featurettes including footage from Comic-Con 2008. |- |align=left|'''''Volume Eight'''''||June 15, 2010||15||[[Family Guy (season 7)|7B]] & [[Family Guy (season 8)|8A]] |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"|This three-disc set includes the remaining seven episodes of Season 7 and the first eight episodes of Season 8 ("[[Fox-y Lady]]" – "[[Dog Gone (Family Guy)|Dog Gone]]"). Special features include commentaries on select episodes, deleted scenes, and karaoke musical sing-a-longs from past musical moments in the show. The [[Best Buy]] version includes ''[[#Compilations|Stewie Griffin: Best Bits Uncovered]]''. The [[Target Corporation|Target]] version includes a Q&A with Seth MacFarlane and friends at PaleyFest 2010. |- |align=left|'''''Volume Nine'''''||December 13, 2011||14||[[Family Guy (season 8)|8B]] & [[Family Guy (season 9)|9A]] |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"|This three-disc set includes the remaining eleven episodes of Season 8 and the first three episodes of Season 9 ("[[Business Guy]]" – "[[Welcome Back, Carter]]"), excluding ''[[Something, Something, Something, Dark Side]]''. Special features include commentaries on select episodes, deleted scenes, side-by-side animatics, featurettes including footage from Comic-Con 2010, and ''[[The Cleveland Show]]'' episode "The Way the Cookie Crumbles" with a special introduction from [[Mike Henry (voice actor)|Mike Henry]]. |- |align=left|'''''Volume Ten'''''||September 25, 2012||14||[[Family Guy (season 9)|9B]] |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"|This three-disc set includes the remaining fourteen episodes of Season 9 ("[[Halloween on Spooner Street]]" – "[[Foreign Affairs (Family Guy)|Foreign Affairs]]"), excluding ''[[It's a Trap!]].'' Special features include commentaries on select episodes, deleted scenes, side-by-side animatics, and featurettes including ''Adam West Star Ceremony''. |- |align=left|'''''Volume Eleven'''''||September 24, 2013{{cite web|url=http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/news/Family-Guy-Volume-11/18695|title=Family Guy - Fox Home Entertainment Schedules a Release Date for {{'}}''Volume 11''{{'}}|work=TV Shows on DVD|last=Lambert|first=David|date=July 12, 2013|accessdate=July 13, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130715224715/http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/news/Family-Guy-Volume-11/18695|archivedate=July 15, 2013|df=}} ||23||[[Family Guy (season 10)|10]] |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"|This three-disc set includes all twenty three episodes of Season 10 ("[[Lottery Fever]]" – "[[Internal Affairs (Family Guy)|Internal Affairs]]"). Special features include commentaries on select episodes, deleted scenes, side-by-side animatics, and featurettes including ''Looking Back to the Pilot''. |- |align=left|'''''Volume Twelve'''''||December 17, 2013{{cite web|url=http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/news/Family-Guy-Volume-12/19063|title=Family Guy - Fox Announces 'Volume 12': Street Date, Pricing, Bonus Material|work=TV Shows on DVD|last=Lambert|first=David|date=October 10, 2013|accessdate=October 10, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131013184736/http://tvshowsondvd.com/news/Family-Guy-Volume-12/19063|archivedate=October 13, 2013|df=}} ||22||[[Family Guy (season 11)|11]] |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"|This three-disc set includes all twenty two episodes of Season 11 ("[[Into Fat Air]]" – "[[No Country Club for Old Men]]"). Special features include commentaries on select episodes, deleted scenes, side-by-side animatics, and featurettes including ''200 Episodes Later''. |- |align=left|'''''Season Twelve'''''||December 9, 2014{{cite web|url=http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/news/Family-Guy-Volume-13/20399|title=Family Guy - 'Volume 13' Announced: Street Date, Pricing, and Front Cover Art|work=TV Shows on DVD|last=Lambert|first=David|date=October 17, 2014|accessdate=October 17, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141020015435/http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/news/Family-Guy-Volume-13/20399|archivedate=October 20, 2014|df=}} ||21||[[Family Guy (season 12)|12]] |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"|This three-disc set includes all twenty one episodes of Season 12 ("[[Finders Keepers (Family Guy)|Finders Keepers]]" – "[[Chap Stewie]]") Special features include commentaries on select episodes, deleted scenes, a full episode animatic for "[[Christmas Guy]]", and featurettes including ''Brian Griffin: In Memoriam... Sort of''.{{cite web|url=http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/news/Family-Guy-Volume-13/20415|title=Family Guy - Contents, Including Special Features, for 'Volume 13' on DVD|work=TV Shows on DVD|last=Lambert|first=David|date=October 23, 2014|accessdate=November 3, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141104051433/http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/news/Family-Guy-Volume-13/20415|archivedate=November 4, 2014|df=}} The volume title has been changed to "Season Twelve" instead of "Volume Thirteen."{{cite web|url=http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/news/Family-Guy-Season-12/20540|title=Family Guy - Fox Press Release Shows Title Change from 'Volume 13' to 'SEASON 12'|work=TV Shows on DVD|last=Lambert|first=David|date=December 3, 2014|accessdate=December 5, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141207140734/http://tvshowsondvd.com/news/Family-Guy-Season-12/20540|archivedate=December 7, 2014|df=}} |- |align=left|'''''Season Thirteen'''''||December 8, 2015 ||18||[[Family Guy (season 13)|13]] |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"|This three-disc set includes all eighteen episodes of Season 13 ("[[The Simpsons Guy]]" – "[[Take My Wife (Family Guy)|Take My Wife]]"). Special features include commentaries on select episodes, deleted scenes, a full episode animatic for "[[Stewie, Chris, & Brian's Excellent Adventure]]", and featurettes including ''On the Road to Springfield: The Making of "The Simpsons Guy"''.{{cite web|url=http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/news/Family-Guy-Season-13/21584|title=Family Guy - Official Fox Press Release for 'Season 13': Date, Extras, New Packaging!|work=TV Shows on DVD|last=Lambert|first=David|date=September 29, 2015|accessdate=October 6, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151005002038/http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/news/Family-Guy-Season-13/21584|archivedate=October 5, 2015|df=}} |- |align=left|'''''Season Fourteen'''''|| December 6, 2016 ||20||[[Family Guy (season 14)|14]] |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"|This three-disc set includes all twenty episodes of Season 14 ("[[Pilling Them Softly]]" – "[[Road to India (Family Guy)|Road to India]]"). Specials features include deleted scenes, commentaries on select episodes, The Art of ''Family Guy'' featurette and a full episode animatic for "[[A Lot Going on Upstairs]]".{{cite web|url=http://tvshowsondvd.com/news/Family-Guy-Season-14/22727|title=Family Guy DVD news: Press Release for Season 14|work=TV Shows on DVD|last=Lambert|first=David|date=October 11, 2016|accessdate=October 11, 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161012151949/http://tvshowsondvd.com/news/Family-Guy-Season-14/22727|archivedate=October 12, 2016|df=}} |- |align=left|'''''Season Fifteen'''''|| November 7, 2017{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Family-Guy-Season-15/dp/B01LTICM8O|title=Family Guy Ssn 15|date=7 November 2017|publisher=|via=Amazon}} ||20||[[Family Guy (season 15)|15]] |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"|This three-disc set includes all twenty episodes of Season 15 ("[[The Boys in the Band (Family Guy)|The Boys in the Band]]" – "[[A House Full of Peters]]"). Special features include deleted scenes, ''Family Guy'' Remembers [[Carrie Fisher]], and an [[Adam West]] tribute. |- |align=left|'''''Season Sixteen'''''|| December 4, 2018{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Family-Guy-Season-16-DVD/dp/B0766BPBV9/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1531389805&sr=8-1&keywords=family+guy+season+16|title=Family Guy: Season 16|date=4 December 2018|publisher=|via=Amazon}} ||20||[[Family Guy (season 16)|16]] |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"|This three-disc set will include all twenty episodes of Season 16 ("[[Emmy-Winning Episode]]" – "Are You There God? It’s Me, Peter"). |} ===Region 2 (UK and Ireland) and Region 4 (Australia and New Zealand)=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |- !rowspan=2|Title!!colspan=2|Release dates!!rowspan=2|Episodes!!rowspan=2|Broadcast
Season(s)!!colspan=4|Classifications |- !Region 2 (UK/ROI)!!Region 4 (AUS/NZ)!![[British Board of Film Classification|BBFC]]!![[Irish Film Classification Office|IFCO]]!![[Office of Film and Literature Classification (Australia)|OFLC (AUS)]]!![[Office of Film and Literature Classification (New Zealand)|OFLC (NZ)]] |- |align=left|'''''Season One'''''||November 12, 2001||October 20, 2003||14||1 & 2A|| '''15''' || '''15''' ||M||M |- | colspan="9" style="text-align:left;"|This two-disc set contains 14 of the 15 episodes from the first production season ("[[Death Has a Shadow]]" – "[[Holy Crap]]", "[[Love Thy Trophy]]" – "[[The King Is Dead (Family Guy)|The King Is Dead]]", "[[If I'm Dyin', I'm Lyin']]", and "[[Running Mates (Family Guy)|Running Mates]]"), excluding "[[There's Something About Paulie]]". The episodes are presented in their original production order, though the latter 7 were initially aired as part of the second broadcast season. No special features. The discs are also available separately in region 4. |- |align=left|'''''Season Two'''''||January 27, 2003||August 2, 2004||15||2B & 3A|| '''15''' || '''15''' ||M||M |- | colspan="9" style="text-align:left;"|This two-disc set contains the remaining 14 episodes from the second broadcast season ("[[Da Boom]]", "[[Brian in Love]]", "[[I Am Peter, Hear Me Roar]]", and "[[A Picture Is Worth a 1,000 Bucks]]" – "[[Fore Father]]"), including "There's Something About Paulie". The episodes are presented in broadcast order, followed by the previously un-aired episode "[[When You Wish Upon a Weinstein]]". No special features. The discs are also available separately in region 4. |- |align=left|'''''Season Three'''''||July 21, 2003||May 2, 2005||21||3B||  '''15'''  || '''15''' ||M||M |- | colspan="9" style="text-align:left;"|This three-disc set contains all 21 episodes from the third broadcast season ("[[The Thin White Line]]" – "[[Family Guy Viewer Mail 1|Family Guy Viewer Mail#1]]"), excluding "When You Wish Upon a Weinstein", which was initially delayed from the second season. The episodes are presented in neither broadcast, nor production order. No special features. The discs are also available separately in region 4. |- |align=left|'''''Season Four'''''||April 24, 2006||May 5, 2006||13||4A||  '''15'''  || '''15''' ||MA15+||M |- | colspan="9" style="text-align:left;"|This three-disc set includes the first 13 episodes from Season 4 in broadcast order ("[[North by North Quahog]]" – "[[Jungle Love (Family Guy)|Jungle Love]]"). Special features include 10 audio commentary tracks, 2 featurettes, deleted scene animatics, multi-angle table reads, and storyboard/animatic comparisons. |- |align=left|'''''Season Five'''''||October 30, 2006||November 1, 2006||14||4B||  '''15'''  || '''15''' ||M||M |- | colspan="9" style="text-align:left;"|This three-disc box set includes the remaining 14 episodes from Season 4 in broadcast order ("[[PTV (Family Guy)|PTV]]" – "[[Untitled Griffin Family History]]"), excluding the three that make up ''[[Stewie Griffin: The Untold Story]]''. Special features include commentary on every episode, and over 40 deleted scenes. |- |align=left|'''''Season Six'''''||October 15, 2007||October 17, 2007||13||5A||  '''15'''  || '''15''' ||MA15+||M |- | colspan="9" style="text-align:left;"|This three-disc box set includes the first 13 episodes from Season 5 in broadcast order ("[[Stewie Loves Lois]]" – "[[Bill and Peter's Bogus Journey]]"). Special features include commentary on every episode, 3 animatic episodes with optional commentary, deleted scenes, and 2 featurettes. |- |align=left|'''''Season Seven'''''||November 10, 2008{{cite web|url=http://www.play.com/DVD/DVD/-/55/70/-/5889561/Family-Guy-Season-7/Product.html?searchtype=genre |title=Family Guy: Season 7 - DVDs at Play.com (UK) |publisher=Play.com |date= |accessdate=2011-08-17}}||December 10, 2008||12||5B & 6A||  '''15''' || '''15''' ||MA15+||M |- | colspan="9" style="text-align:left;"|This three-disc set includes the remaining five episodes of Season 5 and seven episodes of Season 6 in production order ("[[No Meals on Wheels]]" – "[[McStroke]]"), excluding ''[[Blue Harvest (Family Guy)|Blue Harvest]]''. Special features include commentary on every episode, deleted scenes, featurettes, the original televised version of each episode, 3 animatic episodes with optional commentary, and the "Family Guy 100th Episode Special". |- |align=left|'''''Season Eight'''''||November 2, 2009||September 29, 2009{{cite web|url=http://www.ezydvd.com.au/item.zml/806205 |title=Buy Family Guy - Season 8 (3 Disc Set) @ EzyDVD |publisher=Ezydvd.com.au |date= |accessdate=2014-03-24}}||13||6B & 7A||  '''15'''  || '''15''' ||MA15+||R13 |- | colspan="9" style="text-align:left;"|This three-disc set includes the remaining four episodes of Season 6 and the first nine episodes of Season 7 in broadcast order ("[[Back to the Woods (Family Guy)|Back to the Woods]]" – "[[The Juice is Loose]]"). Special features include commentaries on every episode, deleted scenes, and featurettes including footage from Comic Con 2008.{{cite web |url=http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/news/Family-Guy-Volume-7/11465 |title=Family Guy DVD news: Announcement for Family Guy - Volume 7 |publisher=TVShowsOnDVD.com |date= |accessdate=2014-03-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140324142058/http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/news/Family-Guy-Volume-7/11465 |archivedate=2014-03-24 |df= }} |- |align=left|'''''Season Nine'''''||November 1, 2010||August 17, 2010||15||7B & 8A||  '''15'''  || '''15''' ||MA15+||R13 |- | colspan="9" style="text-align:left;"|This three-disc set includes the remaining seven episodes of Season 7 and the first eight episodes of Season 8 ("[[FOX-y Lady]]" – "[[Dog Gone (Family Guy)|Dog Gone]]"). Special features include commentaries on every episode, deleted scenes, and two featurettes: "The Multiverse Effect" and "Family Guy Sings-A-Long Karaoke".[http://www.whsmithentertainment.co.uk/dvd/family-guy-season-9/10074474.html WHSmith Entertainment: Family Guy - Season 9 DVD] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20100306183228/http://www.whsmithentertainment.co.uk/dvd/family-guy-season-9/10074474.html |date=2010-03-06 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.asda-entertainment.co.uk/dvd/family-guy-season-9/10074474.html |title=Buy Family Guy - Season 9 DVD from |publisher=Asda Entertainment |date= |accessdate=2014-03-24}} |- |align=left|'''''Season Ten'''''||May 9, 2011||June 15, 2011{{cite web |url=http://www.ezydvd.com.au/item.zml/818764 |title=Buy Family Guy - Season 10 (3 Disc Set) @ EzyDVD |publisher=Ezydvd.com.au |date= |accessdate=2014-03-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110810102811/http://www.ezydvd.com.au/item.zml/818764 |archivedate=2011-08-10 |df= }}||15||8B & 9A||  '''15'''  || '''18''' ||MA15+||R13 |- | colspan="9" style="text-align:left;"|This three-disc set includes the remaining 12 episodes of Season 8 and the first 3 episodes of Season 9 ("[[Business Guy]]" – "[[Welcome Back, Carter]]"), excluding ''[[Something, Something, Something, Dark Side]]'' but including the banned episode "[[Partial Terms of Endearment]]". Commentary on six episodes, deleted scenes, animatics, three featurettes and the ''[[American Dad!]]'' episode "[[Tearjerker (American Dad!)|Tearjerker]]" comprise the special features.[http://hcc.techradar.com/playback/dvd/weekend-watch-family-guy-season-ten-dvd-14-05-11 Weekend Watch: Family Guy: Season Ten (DVD) | Home Cinema Choice: AV, surround sound and TV reviews] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110515102918/http://hcc.techradar.com/playback/dvd/weekend-watch-family-guy-season-ten-dvd-14-05-11 |date=May 15, 2011 }} Also available as a special edition featuring alternative cover art with a bonus T-shirt and script from the season.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B004LROKFY |title=Family Guy - Season 10 150th Episode Anniversary Edition with T-Shirt and Script DVD: Amazon.co.uk: Seth MacFarlane, Alex Borstein, Seth Green, Mila Kunis: Film & TV |publisher=Amazon.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2014-03-24}} Also, this is the first ''Family Guy'' DVD to receive an 18 certificate in Ireland, but this is due to the content in the bonus features, not the episodes.http://www.ifco.ie/website/IFCO/ifcoweb.nsf/web/SearchResults?opendocument&Start=1&Type=by%2Bvideo&Query=family+guy+-+season+10*http://www.ifco.ie/website/IFCO/ifcoweb.nsf/Web/SearchResults?OpenDocument&Start=11&Type=by%2Bvideo&Query=family+guy+-+season+10* |- |align=left|'''''Season Eleven'''''||November 7, 2011{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B004S676ZE |title=Family Guy - Season 11 [DVD]: Amazon.co.uk: Seth MacFarlane, Alex Borstein, Seth Green, Mila Kunis: Film & TV |publisher=Amazon.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-04-23}}||February 29, 2012||14||9B||  '''15'''  || '''15''' ||MA15+||R13 |- | colspan="9" style="text-align:left;"|This three-disc set includes the remaining 15 episodes of Season 9 ("[[Halloween on Spooner Street]]" – "[[Foreign Affairs (Family Guy)|Foreign Affairs]]"). Excluding ''[[It's a Trap!]]''. The special features are animatics for the episodes "[[Baby, You Knock Me Out]]" and "[[Trading Places (Family Guy)|Trading Places]]". It also contains deleted scenes, 20 "Clips-to-Go" and ''[[The Cleveland Show]]'' episode "[[Beer Walk!]]". |align=left|'''''[[Stewie Griffin: The Untold Story]]'''''||September 25, 2005||October 24, 2005||January 25, 2006|| '''15''' || '''15''' ||M||M |- | style="text-align:left;" colspan="8"|This is a direct-to-DVD movie in which Stewie tries to find his real father after a life-changing incident. Special features include an unrated audio track, full-length commentary by cast and crew, animatic comparisons, and previews for ''Family Guy'' and ''[[American Dad!]]''. Also available on [[Universal Media Disc|UMD]]. |- |align=left|'''''[[Blue Harvest (Family Guy)|Blue Harvest]]'''''||January 15, 2008||January 21, 2008||February 8, 2008|| '''15''' || '''15''' ||MA15+||M |- | style="text-align:left;" colspan="8"|This is the special hour-long ''[[Star Wars]]'' parody season six premiere, featuring extended scenes and an unrated audio track. Special features include a full-length commentary, an interview with [[Seth MacFarlane]] and [[George Lucas]], an "Introduction to Family Guy" featurette, and the animatics of the episode. Exclusive to the special edition release are an exclusive brochure, collectable packaging, 3-D glasses and footage, a themed T-shirt and trading cards. Easter eggs include table reads and a teaser trailer for ''Something, Something, Something, Dark Side''. Also included is an extra DVD with a digital copy. This release received a 15 rating from the BBFC due to the bonus featurette and the audio commentary track, but the episode itself was only rated 12, as was the [[Universal Media Disc|UMD]] release.{{citation needed|date=December 2011}} |- |align=left|'''''[[Something, Something, Something, Dark Side]]'''''||December 22, 2009{{cite web |url=http://tvshowsondvd.com/news/Family-Guy-Something-Something-Something-Dark-Side/12484 |title=Family Guy DVD news: Announcement for Family Guy - Something, Something, Something Dark Side |publisher=TVShowsOnDVD.com |date= |accessdate=2014-03-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/66qzxyjRK?url=http://tvshowsondvd.com/news/Family-Guy-Something-Something-Something-Dark-Side/12484 |archivedate=2012-04-11 |df= }}||December 26, 2009{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B002KFZT5E |title=Family Guy - Something Something Something Dark Side DVD: Amazon.co.uk: Seth MacFarlane, Alex Borstein, Mila Kunis, Seth Green: Film & TV |publisher=Amazon.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2014-03-24}}||December 23, 2009|| '''15''' || '''15''' ||MA15+||M |- | style="text-align:left;" colspan="8"|The special hour-long parody of ''[[The Empire Strikes Back]]'', and sequel to ''Blue Harvest''. Special features include a pop-up video, a featurette, the animatics of the episode, deleted scenes, and a sneak peek of ''It's a Trap!''. This is also the first ''Family Guy'' episode/special to be released on High Definition [[Blu-ray]].{{cite web |url=http://tvshowsondvd.com/news/Family-Guy-Something-Something-Something-Dark-Side/12511 |title=Family Guy DVD news: Extras for Family Guy - Something, Something, Something Dark Side |publisher=TVShowsOnDVD.com |date= |accessdate=2014-03-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140324142250/http://tvshowsondvd.com/news/Family-Guy-Something-Something-Something-Dark-Side/12511 |archivedate=2014-03-24 |df= }} |- |align=left|'''''[[It's a Trap!]]'''''||December 21, 2010{{cite web |url=http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/news/Family-Guy-star-wars-parody-3-announced/14140 |title=Family Guy - The Final Star Wars Parody Announced - 'It's a Trap!' |publisher=TVShowsonDVD.com |accessdate=July 23, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100729033010/http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/news/Family-Guy-star-wars-parody-3-announced/14140 |archivedate=July 29, 2010 |df= }}||27 December 2010{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B0048EJVMM |title=Family Guy - It's a Trap (DVD + Digital Copy): Amazon.co.uk: Seth MacFarlane, Alex Borstein, Seth Green: Film & TV |publisher=Amazon.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2014-03-24}}||December 21, 2010|| '''15''' || '''15''' ||M||M |- | style="text-align:left;" colspan="8"|The special hour-long parody of ''[[Return of the Jedi]]'', and sequel to ''Something, Something, Something, Dark Side''. {{Infobox film | name = Marriage Counselor Tora-san | image = Marriage Counselor Tora-san.jpg | caption = Theatrical poster for ''Marriage Counselor Tora-san'' (1984) | director = [[Yoji Yamada]] | producer = | writer = Yoji Yamada
Yoshitaka Asama | starring = [[Kiyoshi Atsumi]]
Rie Nakahara | music = Naozumi Yamamoto | cinematography = Tetsuo Takaba | editing = Iwao Ishii | distributor = [[Shochiku]] | released = {{film date|1984|8|4}} | runtime = 102 minutes | country = Japan | language = Japanese | budget = | gross = }} {{nihongo|'''''Marriage Counselor Tora-san'''''|男はつらいよ 夜霧にむせぶ寅次郎|Otoko wa Tsurai yo: Yogiri ni Musebu Torajirō}} is a 1984 Japanese comedy film directed by [[Yoji Yamada]]. It stars [[Kiyoshi Atsumi]] as Torajirō Kuruma (Tora-san), and Rie Nakahara as his love interest or "Madonna".{{cite web |url=http://www.tora-san.jp/toranomaki/movie33/madonna.html|title=男はつらいよ 夜霧にむせぶ寅次郎 (Madonna)|accessdate=2010-01-30|publisher=[http://www.tora-san.jp/ www.tora-san.jp]|language=Japanese}} (official site) ''Marriage Counselor Tora-san'' is the thirty-third entry in the popular, long-running ''[[Otoko wa Tsurai yo]]'' series. ==Synopsis== In Shibamata, Tokyo, Tora-san's family prepares for a wedding. Meanwhile, the traveling Tora-san meets an old acquaintance in Iwate Province. Tora-san refuses to drink with him, afraid that the acquaintance, now settled and married, will again become attracted to Tora-san's wandering existence. Tora-san becomes attracted to a female barber, but must break off their relationship so that she too can live a secure life. She instead gets into an abusive relationship with a motorcyclist.{{cite web|url=http://www.kinejun.jp/cinema/id/17482|script-title=ja:男はつらいよ 夜霧にむせぶ寅次郎|accessdate=2010-01-30|language=Japanese|publisher=[[Kinema Junpo]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324083428/http://www.kinejun.jp/cinema/id/17482|archivedate=2012-03-24|df=}}{{cite web |first=Stuart |last=Galbraith IV |authorlink= Stuart Galbraith IV|url=http://www.dvdtalk.com/reviews/28077/tora-san-33-tora-sans-marriage-counselor/|title=Tora-san 33: http://www.molodezhnaja.ch/torasan33.htm (Region 3) |date=2007-05-15|accessdate=2010-01-30|publisher=[[DVD Talk]]}} ==Cast== * [[Kiyoshi Atsumi]] as Torajirō{{cite web |url= http://www.jmdb.ne.jp/1984/dh002820.htm|script-title=ja:男はつらいよ 夜霧にむせぶ寅次郎|accessdate=2010-01-30|language=Japanese|publisher=[[Japanese Movie Database]]}} * [[Chieko Baisho]] as Sakura * Rie Nakahara as Fūko Kogure * [[Tsunehiko Watase]] as Tony * [[Jun Miho]] as Akemi * [[Shimojo Masami]] as Kuruma Tatsuzō * [[Chieko Misaki]] as Tsune Kuruma (Torajiro's aunt) * [[Gin Maeda]] as Hiroshi Suwa * [[Hidetaka Yoshioka]] as Mitsuo Suwa * [[Hisao Dazai]] as Boss (Umetarō Katsura) * [[Gajirō Satō]] as Genkō * [[Chishū Ryū]] as Gozen-sama ==Critical appraisal== [[Stuart Galbraith IV]] writes that ''Marriage Counselor Tora-san'' is a better entry in the ''[[Otoko wa Tsurai yo]]'' series, though it differs considerably from other films in the series, both formally and thematically. Tora-san's wandering life is portrayed harshly, rather than light-heartedly, and his family's stable life is shown in the more positive light. Galbraith concludes, "With its darker tone and atypical structure, ''Tora-san's Marriage Counselor'' is like a breath of fresh air following a series of recent, somewhat repetitive entries." The German-language site molodezhnaja gives ''Marriage Counselor Tora-san'' three and a half out of five stars.{{cite web |url=http://www.molodezhnaja.ch/torasan33.htm|title=Tora-San's Marriage Counselor|accessdate=2010-01-30|publisher=[http://www.molodezhnaja.ch/ www.molodezhnaja.ch]|language=German}} ==Availability== ''Marriage Counselor Tora-san'' was released theatrically on August 4, 1984.{{cite web|url=http://www.japanese-cinema-db.jp/details/14058|title=男はつらいよ 夜霧にむせぶ寅次郎|accessdate=2010-01-30|publisher=Japanese Cinema Database ([[Agency for Cultural Affairs]])|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140415211015/http://www.japanese-cinema-db.jp/details/14058|archivedate=2014-04-15|df=}} In Japan, the film has been released on videotape in 1987 and 1996, and in DVD format in 2005 and 2008.{{cite web |url=http://www.allcinema.net/prog/show_c.php?num_c=149116|script-title=ja:男はつらいよ　夜霧にむせぶ寅次郎 (1984)|accessdate=2010-01-30|publisher=allcinema.net|language=Japanese}} ==References== ;Notes {{reflist}} ;Bibliography ;;English * {{cite web |url=http://www.citwf.com/film257100.htm|title=OTOKO WA
