Venereal Diseases Past and Present in Norway with Special Reference to Olso.Br J Vener Dis. 1956 June; 32(2): 86-90.] == External links == * [https://feministire.wordpress.com/tag/norway/ Wendy Lyon. The latest on Norway’s sex purchase ban. Feminist Ire, 13 May 2013] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20140819085242/http://www.sexogsamfunn.no/For-fagfolk/Artikler/Prostitusjon-Nei-det-sp%C3%B8r-vi-ikke-om.../ Ulla Edith Bjørndahl. ”Prostitusjon? Nei, det spør vi ikke om…” Sex og samfunn, senter for ung seksualitet] *{{cite encyclopedia|encyclopedia=Store norske leksikon|editor-last=Henriksen|editor-first=Petter |publisher=Kunnskapsforlaget|location=Oslo|url=https://snl.no/ |language=Norwegian|year=2014|accessdate=30 August 2014|ref=harv}} ** [https://snl.no/.search?query=Prostitusjon&x=19&y=13 [[Store norske leksikon]] articles on ''Prostitusjon''] {{no icon}} === Legal and regulatory === * [http://www.regjeringen.no/nb.html?id=4 Government of Norway] * [http://www.regjeringen.no/nb/dep/jd.html?id=463 Justice Ministry] * [http://prosentret.no/en/lovverk/ Norwegian Prostitution Law. Pro-Sentret] * [http://www.lovdata.no [[Lovdata]]] Norwegian laws === Research === * [https://web.archive.org/web/20140102193522/http://fafo.no/prostitution/ FAFO: Prostitution] * [https://www.stir.ac.uk/arts-humanities/research/areas/politics-research/nppr/ Nordic Prostitution Policy Reform] === Support === * [http://prosentret.no/ Pro Sentret] Advocacy organization. Norwegian and English * [http://pion-norge.no/ PION] * [http://www.bymisjon.no/Virksomheter/Nadheim/English/ Nadheim: Kirkens Bymisjon] * [http://www.rosa-help.no/ ROSA (Reetablering Oppholdssteder Sikkerhet Assistanse)] {{Europe in topic|Prostitution in}} {{Norwegian political parties}} {{Norway topics}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Prostitution In Norway}} [[Category:Prostitution in Norway| ]] [[Category:Norwegian society]] [[Category:Sex industry in Norway]] [[Category:Women's rights in Norway]] [[Category:Norwegian law]]

{{no footnotes|date=December 2009}} The '''Pussycat Theaters''' were a chain of [[Adult movie theater]], operating between the 1960s and the 1980s. Pussycat Theaters had 30 locations in California and were known for their cat-girl logo.
==History== [[David F. Friedman]] and [[Dan Sonney]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dl0EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA30&lpg=PA30&dq=Pussycat|title=Los Angeles Magazine|first=Emmis|last=Communications|date=1 May 2002|publisher=Emmis Communications|accessdate=28 April 2018|via=Google Books}}</ref> founded Pussycat Theaters. Dan Sonney invented the name, based on Woody Allen film ''[[What's New Pussycat?|What's New Pussycat]]''. Friedman has also cited the Pink Pussycat burlesque club on Santa Monica Boulevard as having previously established the word "pussycat" in relation to "pink" porn, since the early 1960s. The first Pussycat Theater opened in March 1966 on 444 South Hill Street, [[Los Angeles]]. Within two years, there were almost a dozen locations, from [[San Diego]] to [[San Francisco]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.seeing-stars.com/Locations/LethalWeapon3.shtml|title=Lethal Weapon Filming Locations - Part 3|first=Gary|last=Wayne|date=|website=www.seeing-stars.com|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ebay.com/itm/NEW-VIEW-THEATRE-1970-photo-6656-HOLLYWOOD-BLVD-original-still-DONALD-SUTHERLAND/310595974200|title=NEW-VIEW THEATRE 1970 photo 6656 HOLLYWOOD BLVD original still DONALD SUTHERLAND - eBay|author=|date=|website=eBay|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://hollywoodhistoricphotos.com/product_info.php/products_id/3862|title=Hollywood Historic Photos - News-View Theatre 1944|author=|date=|website=hollywoodhistoricphotos.com|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://losangelestheatres.blogspot.com/2017/02/ritz-theatre.html|title=Ritz Theatre|author=|date=|website=losangelestheatres.blogspot.com|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref>
In 1968, Vince Miranda<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1985-06-05/news/mn-15735_1_family-oriented-theaters|title=Pussycat Theater Founder Miranda Dies|first=BURT A.|last=FOLKART|date=5 June 1985|publisher=|accessdate=28 April 2018|via=LA Times}}</ref> bought a 50% share of the company. Miranda was unable to prevent those outside California from using the Pussycat name. Miranda spent $1 million to improve the decor of the theaters. They were known for being cleaner and fancier than other such places. The interiors featured red and gold [[carpet]]ing, [[velveteen]] fixtures, beveled glass, mirror walls, [[chandelier]]s, [[oil painting]]s, [[mural]]s, and merchandise bearing the Pussycat logo. Some Pussycat theaters sold [[popcorn]] from the [[box office]] to pedestrians on the sidewalk, with no obligation to buy a ticket.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gettyimages.com/detail/news-photo/view-of-the-pussycat-theater-formerly-known-as-the-sunset-news-photo/627234754|title=The Pussycat Theater|author=|date=|website=gettyimages.com|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7nK1MvP2L_IC&pg=PA153&lpg=PA153&dq=Pussycat|title=Charles Bukowski: Locked in the Arms of a Crazy Life|first=Howard|last=Sounes|date=1 December 2007|publisher=Grove/Atlantic, Inc.|accessdate=28 April 2018|via=Google Books}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://sites.google.com/site/losangelesmoviepalaces/lakewood|title=Lakewood Theatre - [more] Los Angeles Movie Palaces|author=|date=|website=sites.google.com|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref>
Vince Miranda and George Tate (who were lovers) shared ownership of Walnut Properties, the company that owned the Pussycat Theaters. Miranda may have had exclusive California license to show ''[[Deep Throat (film)|Deep Throat]]'', a hugely lucrative film. His main competitors were the [[Mitchell brothers]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nightflight.com/filmmaker-gregory-dark-his-fallen-angels-and-the-other-side-of-hollywood/|title=Filmmaker Gregory Dark, his “Fallen Angels,” and the other side of Hollywood|author=|date=|website=nightflight.com|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref>
Residents who lived near the theaters complained to the city governments that children could see the images of women on posters, ads, and cardboard stand-ups. Community members wanted the theaters to close. The citizens groups and government sued Walnut Properties under a variety of laws, including [[obscenity]], [[public nuisance]], [[Zoning|rezoning]], [[eminent domain]], The [[Red Light Abatement Act]], and the US Supreme Court's "preponderance" redefinition of porn theaters. Walnut Properties was served with over 100 civil lawsuits filed between 1973 and 2005. Between 1977 and 1994, at the Pussycat Theater in Santa Monica, "the Los Angeles Police Department made 2000 arrests for [[Sexual misconduct|lewd conduct]] on the premises." In 1981, an ordinance was passed banning adult movie theaters in [[Santa Monica, California|Santa Monica]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://timeline.com/rise-fall-porn-theater-172c45c7065f|title=Watching porn in public: The rise and fall of the adult movie house|author=|date=12 August 2016|website=timeline.com|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://losangelestheatres.blogspot.com/2017/01/hollywood-theatres-overview.html|title=Los Angeles Theatres: Historic Hollywood Theatres: an overview|first=B.|last=Counter|date=|website=losangelestheatres.blogspot.com|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://obrag.org/2010/09/the-strand-theater-part-1-the-year-the-porno-theater-was-blocked/|title=The Strand Theater-Part 1: the Year the Porno Theater Was Stopped|author=|date=|website=obrag.org|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gettyimages.com/detail/news-photo/patron-buys-a-ticket-at-the-pussycat-theatre-may-3-1995-in-news-photo/813922114|title=Pussycat Theater In Buena Park, California|author=|date=|website=gettyimages.com|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.adsausage.com/freep3/|title=ADSAUSAGE - vintage advertising library.|author=|date=|website=www.adsausage.com|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref>
In 1983, pornographic [[videotape]] sales began to compete with adult theaters, reducing theater attendance. At the age of 52, Vince Miranda died of complications related to cancer in 1985. George Tate and his new paramour Jonathan Cota inherited Walnut and the Pussycat Theaters. The IRS imposed a federal tax lien of $6,047,760 on Miranda's estate. The theaters were losing money fast. Many theaters are given to debtors in lieu of money, and/or converted to general admission theaters.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/427/50/case.html|title=Young v. American Mini Theatres, Inc., 427 U.S. 50 (1976)|author=|date=|website=justia.com|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref>
By 1990, fewer than 20 California Pussycats remained, and by 1992, only a dozen were still open. In 1994, Walnut Properties filed for bankruptcy, claiming liabilities of $17.7 million. George Tate spent all the money and died the same year. Jonathan Cota inherited Walnut and its debts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cinematreasures.org/theaters/22225|title=Del Mar Theatre in Fontana, CA - Cinema Treasures|author=|date=|website=cinematreasures.org|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://cinematreasures.org/theaters/2361|title=Studs at the Pussycat Theatre in West Hollywood, CA - Cinema Treasures|author=|date=|website=cinematreasures.org|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://cinematreasures.org/theaters/2364|title=Hologram USA Hollywood Theater in Los Angeles, CA - Cinema Treasures|author=|date=|website=cinematreasures.org|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://cinematreasures.org/theaters/2800|title=Ritz San Jose in San Jose, CA - Cinema Treasures|author=|date=|website=cinematreasures.org|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://cinematreasures.org/theaters/3211|title=Whittier Village Cinemas in Whittier, CA - Cinema Treasures|author=|date=|website=cinematreasures.org|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://cinematreasures.org/theaters/3592|title=Esquire IMAX Theatre in Sacramento, CA - Cinema Treasures|author=|date=|website=cinematreasures.org|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://cinematreasures.org/theaters/37|title=Fox Performing Arts Center in Riverside, CA - Cinema Treasures|author=|date=|website=cinematreasures.org|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://cinematreasures.org/theaters/3834|title=Miracle Theatre in Inglewood, CA - Cinema Treasures|author=|date=|website=cinematreasures.org|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://cinematreasures.org/theaters/4374|title=Star Theatre in Oceanside, CA - Cinema Treasures|author=|date=|website=cinematreasures.org|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://cinematreasures.org/theaters/5007|title=Cinema L'Amour in Montreal, CA - Cinema Treasures|author=|date=|website=cinematreasures.org|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://cinematreasures.org/theaters/7363|title=Plaza Playhouse Theater in Carpinteria, CA - Cinema Treasures|author=|date=|website=cinematreasures.org|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://cinematreasures.org/theaters/9573|title=Sunshine Brooks Theater in Oceanside, CA - Cinema Treasures|author=|date=|website=cinematreasures.org|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://cinematreasures.org/theaters/9677|title=Lido Theatre in Riverside, CA - Cinema Treasures|author=|date=|website=cinematreasures.org|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://sites.google.com/site/lamoviepalaces/sfvalley|title=San Fernando Valley Theatres - [more] L.A. Movie Palaces|author=|date=|website=sites.google.com|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://cinematreasures.org/theaters/2154|title=Guild Theatre in Los Angeles, CA - Cinema Treasures|author=|date=|website=cinematreasures.org|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://sites.google.com/site/lamoviepalaces/coast|title=Theatres Along The Coast - [more] L.A. Movie Palaces|author=|date=|website=sites.google.com|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://sites.google.com/site/lamoviepalaces/wardman|title=Wardman Theatre / Whittier Village Cinemas - [more] L.A. Movie Palaces|author=|date=|website=sites.google.com|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://sites.google.com/site/lamoviepalaces/north|title=Theatres North of Downtown - [more] L.A. Movie Palaces|author=|date=|website=sites.google.com|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://sites.google.com/site/lamoviepalaces/south|title=South, South Central and Southeast Theatres - [more] L.A. Movie Palaces|author=|date=|website=sites.google.com|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://sites.google.com/site/lamoviepalaces/sgvalley|title=San Gabriel Valley, Pomona, and Whittier Theatres - [more] L.A. Movie Palaces|author=|date=|website=sites.google.com|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://jerrygarciasbrokendownpalaces.blogspot.com/2011/12/california-theater-1122-fourth-and-c-st.html|title=Jerry's Brokendown Palaces: California Theater, 1122 Fourth and C St., San Diego, CA|first=Jerry's Brokendown|last=Palaces|date=14 December 2011|website=jerrygarciasbrokendownpalaces.blogspot.com|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://cinematreasures.org/theaters/9809|title=Gaiety Burlesk in New York, NY - Cinema Treasures|author=|date=|website=cinematreasures.org|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://cinematreasures.org/theaters/49033|title=Pussycat 2 Cinema in New York, NY - Cinema Treasures|author=|date=|website=cinematreasures.org|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://whenporntheatersinvadedconnecticut.blogspot.com/|title=When Porn Theaters Invaded Connecticut – a detailed history of 1970s-1980s east coast porn empires|author=|date=|website=whenporntheatersinvadedconnecticut.blogspot.com|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref>
By 2003, all the theaters were lost except one at 7734 Santa Monica Boulevard. Filmmaker [[Roger Corman]] saved the last Pussycat Theater by brokering a deal with an unnamed buyer. In 2004, Cota threatened to file a lawsuit against the [[The Pussycat Dolls|Pussycat Dolls]], for trademark infringement on the Pussycat name. The [[United States Patent and Trademark Office|U.S. Patent and Trademark Office]] declared the Pussycat trademark to be "abandoned" and the case was dismissed. Today, Cota runs the last Pussycat Theater, which now shows homosexual pornography. The name was changed to the Tomkat, then to Studs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://studswesthollywood.com/|title=Studs at the Pussycat|author=|date=|website=studswesthollywood|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.sandiegoreader.com/weblogs/bands/2008/aug/07/pussycat-theater-history-when-cathouses-ruled-ca-n/ Pussycat Theater History 2008 - San Diego Reader] *[http://www.sandiegoreader.com/weblogs/bands/2010/jun/29/pussycat-theaters-a-comprehensive-history-of-a-cal/ Pussycat Theater History 2010 by Jay Allen Sanford - San Diego Reader] *[http://www.PussycatTheaterHistory1.blogspot.com/ Pussycat Theaters - the Inside Story Part One] [http://www.PussycatTheaterHistory2.blogspot.com/ Parts Two-Fifteen], 2014 *[https://web.archive.org/web/20130808075302/http://mimlay.com/blog1/2012/05/27/pussycat-pussycat-where-have-you-been/ Pussycat, Pussycat, Where Have You Been?] *[https://encrypted.google.com/search?num=100&hl=en&lr=&as_qdr=all&q=%22Pussycat+Theater%22+-intitle%3AComments+site%3Acinematreasures.org Pussycat Theatre - Cinema Treasures] *[https://encrypted.google.com/search?num=100&hl=en&safe=off&q=%22Pussycat+Theater%22+site%3Anews.google.com%2Fnewspapers Pussycat Theater - Google Newspapers] *[https://encrypted.google.com/search?q=%22Pussycat+Theater%22&num=100&hl=en&safe=off&source=lnms&tbm=bks&sa=X&biw=1022&bih=436 Pussycat Theater - Google Books]

revision.text:
{{Use South African English|date=December 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{Infobox lottery |name = South African National Lottery |image =ithuba-logo.jpg |alt = |caption =Logo used 2015 - present |region = [[South Africa]] |launch_date = {{Start date|2000|03|11|df=y}} |final_date = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> |operator = Ithuba |regulator = National Lotteries Commission |highest = R145,469,799 |odds = {{Plainlist| * 20,358,520 to 1 (Lotto) * 20,358,520 to 1 (Lotto Plus) * 24,435,180 to 1 (PowerBall) * 24,435,180 to 1 (PowerBall Plus) * 531,441 to 1 (SportStake) * 4 to 1 (EAZiWIN) }} |games = 6 |broadcaster = [[E.tv]], [[SABC 2]] |url = {{URL|www.nationallottery.co.za}} }}
'''The National Lottery''' is operated by ITHUBA Holdings, to whom the licence was granted in 2015. The lottery is regulated by the National Lottery Commission, and was established in 2000.
Lottery tickets may be bought only by people of at least 18 years of age.
In the 2007 fiscal year transaction values totalled R3.972 billion, with an average of five million transactions per week. In the 2012 National lottery generated R4.7 billion in sales of Lotto and Powerball tickets.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.pwc.co.za/en/assets/pdf/gambling-outlook-2013.pdf|title=Betting on Africa. 2nd annual edition, November 2013. Gambling Outlook: 2013-2017 (South Africa - Nigeria - Kenya)|last=|first=|date=2013|website=|publisher=PwC South Africa|access-date=5 July 2016}}</ref>
Lotto is the most popular type of [[gambling in South Africa]]<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.nlb.org.za/upload/AnnualReports/Annual%20Report%202007.pdf |title = National Lotteries Board Annual Report, 2007 |publisher = National Lotteries Board |accessdate = 9 September 2008 }}{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> but Powerball has been the faster-growing for last years due to its high payouts.<ref name=":0" />
==History== The National lottery was introduced to South Africa on 11 March 2000. At the time it was run by Uthingo.
After a marketing effort that aimed to reach 80 percent of South African homes directly<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dispatch.co.za/2000/02/26/easterncape/BLOTTERY.HTM |title=National Lottery geared up to start on Thursday |publisher=The Daily Dispatch |accessdate=9 September 2008 }}</ref> more than 800,000 tickets were sold in the first day of availability<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dispatch.co.za/2000/03/03/southafrica/ALOTTERY.HTM |title=R2m lottery tickets sold |publisher=The Daily Dispatch |accessdate=9 September 2008 }}</ref> Nearly R70 million worth of tickets were sold in the first three weeks of operation.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iol.co.za/?set_id=1&click_id=13&art_id=ct20000331222225352L300187 |title=R32m won in lottery – so far |publisher=Independent Online |accessdate=9 September 2008 }}</ref>
In October 2002 operator [[Uthingo]] suggested a daily lottery to supplement the weekly draw. The concept, called Keno, was rejected by the trade and industry ministry in March 2003.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?click_id=13&art_id=vn20030304053645945C232389&set_id=1 |title=No tata ma chance everyday, rules Erwin |publisher=Independent Online |accessdate=9 September 2008 }}</ref> In November 2003 the Lotto Plus game was launched, acting as a supplementary weekly lottery available on the purchase of a primary lottery ticket, with an entry fee of R1.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?click_id=196&art_id=vn20031125144914534C284680&set_id=1 |title=Big plus for Lotto punters – at just R1 a pop |publisher=Independent Online |accessdate=9 September 2008 }}</ref>
In July 2006 the [[Gidani]] consortium, featuring Greek company [[Intralot]] as a technical partner, was judged the preferred bidder to operate the lottery for seven years starting April 2007. The operating licence was awarded in October 2006.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iol.co.za/?set_id=1&click_id=13&art_id=qw1159971840266B243 |title=Operator for national lottery awarded |publisher=Independent Online |accessdate=9 September 2008 }}</ref> In March 2007 the [[High Court of South Africa|Pretoria High Court]] set aside that award on application by incumbent Uthingo, finding that the failure to adequately investigate the shareholders in some bidding consortia left room for conflicts of interest.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=14&click_id=6&art_id=nw20070309175548633C746692 |title=Lottery shareholders under scrutiny |publisher=Independent Online |accessdate=9 September 2008 }}</ref>
Following the final draw by incumbent Uthingo, the lottery was indefinitely suspended in April 2007.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=13&art_id=vn20070401083645812C149811 |title=Lotto debacle leaves public high and dry |publisher=Independent Online |accessdate=9 September 2008 }}</ref>
In September the operating licence was awarded to Gidani again.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mg.co.za/article/2007-09-21-gidani-gets-green-light-for-lottery |title=Gidani gets green light for lottery |publisher=Mail&Guardian |accessdate=9 September 2008 }}</ref> When ticket sales re-opened in October more than 200,000 tickets were sold within the first three hours.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=13&art_id=vn20071006075706996C798816 |title=Lotta mania hits SA |publisher=Independent Online |accessdate=9 September 2008 }}</ref> Gidani introduced scratch cards, but they were discontinued for several months when they lost their licence to Ithuba.
In 2015, Lotto licences were awarded to ITHUBA. In 2015, 2 new games were introduced by Ithuba: EAZiWIN, an instant win game consisting of four types of indigenous inspired games; ''Morabaraba, Fafi Fortune''',''' 4 Siya Wina and Popa Feela'' and PowerBall Plus.
==Eligibility== * Players must be 18 years or older * Tickets may be bought in person at approved retailers, handheld partners and participating banks in South Africa. * Online purchase of tickets are only available to people who have an ABSA, FNB, Nedbank and Standard Bank account or have registered on the South African National Lottery [https://www.nationallottery.co.za website] and are residents of South Africa with a South African ID.
==Games==
8 games operate under the South African National Lottery brand:
===Current games===
===LOTTO=== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:96%; float:right;" |+LOTTO and LOTTO PLUS odds ! style="width:100px;" | Match ! style="width:100px;" | Odds of winning !'''% of total winning pool''' |- |2 and bonus||1 : 96 |Lotto R20.00, Lotto Plus R15 |-|- |3||1 : 72 |Lotto R50.00, Lotto Plus R25 |- |3 and bonus||1 : 1028 |7.3% |- |4||1 : 1,371 |8.4% |- |4 and bonus||1 : 30,161 |5.0% |- |5||1 : 75,402 |4.0% |- |5 and bonus |1 : 3,393,087 |2.3% |- |All 6 |1 : 20,358,520 |73.0% |}
[[File:Lotto.png|left|thumb|Lotto and Lotto Plus coupon 2015 - present]] Players buy tickets with their choice of six different numbers between 1 and 52; there is provision for random numbers to be generated automatically for those who do not wish to choose, known as 'Quick Pick'.
In the draw, six numbered balls are drawn without replacement from a set of 52 balls numbered from 1 to 52. A further ''Bonus Ball'' is also drawn, which affects only players who match five numbers.
Prizes are awarded to players who match at least three of the six drawn numbers, with prizes increasing for matching more of the drawn numbers. All players who match all six drawn numbers win equal shares of the [[progressive jackpot|jackpot]]; the chance of doing so is 1 in 20,358,520. If four, five, or six balls are matched, the relevant prize is divided equally between all who match that many balls. If no player matches all six numbers, the jackpot is added to that of the next Lotto draw—a ''Rollover''.
The entry fee to the LOTTO draw is set at R5.00 per board.
The draw is conducted on Wednesdays and Saturdays on [[SABC 2]] at 20:56. {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:96%; float:right;" |+PowerBall and PowerBall PLUS odds ! style="width:100px;" | Match ! style="width:100px;" | Odds of winning !'''% of total winning pool''' |- |PowerBall ||1 : 37 |Fixed (R10 for PowerBall/ R5 for Power Ball Plus) |- |1 ball and PowerBall ||1 : 53 |Fixed (R15 for PowerBall/ R7.50
for Power Ball Plus) |- |2 balls and PowerBall ||1 : 247 |5.1% |- |3 balls ||1 : 165 |7.6% |- |3 balls and PowerBall ||1 : 3,133 |8.9% |- |4 balls |1 : 6,430 |9.3% |- |4 balls and PowerBall |1 : 122,176 |4.9% |- |5 balls |1 : 1,286,062 |9.7% |- |All balls including PowerBall |1 : 24,435,180 |54.4% |}
====LOTTO PLUS 1====
LOTTO PLUS 1 is exactly the same as LOTTO, but gives the player a second chance to win. When buying a LOTTO ticket, the player must pay an extra R2.50 per board to enter the LOTTO PLUS 1 draw. Odds are the same, while prizes are usually slightly lower.
The draw is conducted on Wednesdays and Saturdays on [[SABC 2]] at 20:56.
====LOTTO PLUS 2====
LOTTO PLUS 2 is exactly the same as LOTTO, but gives the player a third chance to win. When buying a LOTTO ticket, the player must pay an extra R2.50 per board to enter the LOTTO PLUS 2 draw. Odds are the same, while prizes are usually slightly lower.
The draw is conducted on Wednesdays and Saturdays on [[SABC 2]] at 20:56.
====PowerBall==== [[File:Powerball.jpg|left|thumb|227x227px|Powerball and Powerball Plus coupon 2015 - present]] The PowerBall jackpot draw requires players to pick five main numbers from 1 to 45 and one 'PowerBall' number from 1 to 20 for an entry fee of R5 per board. Prizes may be won by matching the main numbers, with matches of the PowerBall number winning higher prizes. The top prize of the game is won by matching all five main numbers as well as the PowerBall. Draws take place on Tuesdays and Fridays on [[E.tv]] at 21:00.
After 28 November 2015, odds were as more possibilities to win were introduced. An example of the recent additions were, if the player matched only the Powerball, he or she would win money, while before, that ticket would not win anything.
The record prize for any Lottery game in South Africa was in PowerBall at R102,016,595. This prize was won in the [[Free State (province)|Free State]] but never collected. The highest claimed prize was also from PowerBall at R91,068,427
==== PowerBall PLUS ====
PowerBall PLUS is exactly the same as PowerBall, but gives the player a second chance to win. When buying a PowerBall ticket, the player must pay an extra R2.50 per board to enter the PowerBall PLUS draw. Odds are the same, while prizes are usually slightly lower.
Powerball PLUS was a more recent game added by the National Lottery of South Africa and is currently the newest game. It was introduced on 28 November 2015.
Draws take place on Tuesdays and Fridays on [[E.tv]] at 21:00.
==== SPORTSTAKE 13 ==== [[File:Sportstake.jpg|left|thumb|Sportstake coupon 2015 - present]] A player can play SPORTSTAKE 13 by predicting outcomes of 13 predetermined match fixtures drawn from English and other identified professional soccer fixtures.
For each fixture the player chooses their prediction by marking on the bet slip;
[1] – for a home win
[x] – for a draw
[2] – for a home loss (Away win)
{| class="wikitable" !Prize division !Theoretical odds of winning !Pool % |- |Match 13 |1:1,594,323 |30% |- |Match 12 |1:62,320 |15% |- |Match 11 |1:5110 |20% |- |Match 10 |1:697 |35% |}
** You can select a single or multiple outcomes result for each fixture. ** A valid wager must consist of at least one selection per fixture. ** A minimum price per wager per board is R2.00 vat incl, and a maximum wager per Betslip is R2000.00 ** Each wager will cost you R2.00 vat incl. ** You can play PROPICK™ as a quick play option ** There is no Multi Draw option. ** SPORTSTAKE 13 fixture results are considered as the final score after 90 minutes of play or after extra time where applicable, however excludes penalty shoot-out. {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:96%; float:right;" |+EAZiWIN odds !Name of Game !Game based on !Price of Card !Highest Prize !Odds of winning |- |Popa Feela |Unknown |R3 |R30,000 | rowspan="4" |1 : 4 |- |4 Siya Wina |Unknown | rowspan="3" |R5 | rowspan="3" |R100,000 |- |Fafi Fortune |[[Fafi]] |- |Morabaraba |[[Morabaraba]] |}
====EAZiWIN==== [[File:Lottoeaziwin.jpg|left|thumb|All 4 EAZiWIN play cards]] As well as tickets for the Draw Games, the National Lottery also sells instant win digital scratch cards.
They are digital scratch cards, where a card is compared against a slip and not scratched like traditional scratchcards. These are called 'EAZiWIN and are based on traditional African games.
Cards range from R3 to R5.
===PICK 3=== Lotto's newest game was announced to launch on 3 December 2016. It will be a daily game with a top prize of R10,000.
===Discontinued games===
====Wina Manje==== Wina Manje was a scratchcard game that consisted of many types of scratch cards. This was replaced by EAZiWIN in 2015.
====Raffle==== South African National Lottery announced that there would be a once-off raffle for Christmas 2016. The draw took place on 30 December 2016. It was officially named "Raffle". Prizes included R1,000, R10,000, R100,000, with the top prize being a [[Mercedes Benz C-Class|Mercedes Benz C200 Cabriolet]]
==Other ways to play== As well as by purchasing a ticket at a shop, tickets can be purchased many other ways.
===Online=== All National Lottery games can be played online after registering. There are two ways of playing the lotto online.
'''FNB & Nedbank:''' LOTTO, LOTTO PLUS 1, LOTTO PLUS 2, PowerBall and PowerBall PLUS are available for play through the bank's apps.
'''National Lottery website:''' LOTTO, LOTTO PLUS 1, LOTTO PLUS 2, PowerBall, PowerBall PLUS and SPORTSTAKE 13 are available for play through the South African National lottery website.
== Record Jackpots == Below lists the highest 11 jackpots from the National Lottery of South Africa. {| class="wikitable" !Rank !Jackpot !Game !Draw number !Date !Notes |- |1 |R145,469,799.30<ref>https://www.nationallottery.co.za/results/lotto/?game_number=1783-lotto</ref> |Lotto |1783 |2018-01-27 |4 Winners won R27.5 million each |- |2 |R102,016,595.00 |PowerBall |166 |2011-06-03 |Not collected |- |3 |R91,068,427.00 |PowerBall |32 |2010-02-12 |Highest collected jackpot |- |4 |R70,031,306.00 |PowerBall |N/A |2018-01-15 | |- |5 |R69,542,295.00 |PowerBall |74 |2010-07-13 | |- |6 |R64,547,102.00 |PowerBall |100 |2010-10-12 | |- |7 |R62,996,195 |PowerBall |N/A |2016-09-18 | |- |8 |R61,261,924.29 |PowerBall |632 |2015-12-11 | |- |9 |R60,432,313.00 |PowerBall |429 |2013-12-20 | |- |10 |R51,844,047.00 |PowerBall |564 |2015-04-14 | |- |11 |R44,941,661.00 |PowerBall |483 |2014-07-01 | |}
== Operators == {| class="wikitable" !Operator !Year begun !Year stopped |- |Ithuba |2015 |Present |- |Gidani |2007 |2015 |- |Utingo |2000 |2007 |}
== Socio-economic impact == In June 2003 it was reported that 27 percent of lottery players were unemployed<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?click_id=13&art_id=vn20030606070354272C897629&set_id=1 |title='The Gambling Board must come to its senses' |publisher=Independent Online |accessdate=9 September 2008 }}</ref> and that 43 percent of players earned less than R2,000 a month.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.capetimes.co.za/index.php?fSectionId=271&fArticleId=162182 |title=Lotto ticket sales coin R80m each week – research |publisher=Cape Times |accessdate=9 September 2008 }}</ref> It was also reported that legalised gambling had created 50 673 jobs in 2000, although it may have redirected spendings from other industries.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.busrep.co.za/index.php?fSectionId=561&fArticleId=163860 |title=Parliament worries about gambling's growth |publisher=Business Report |accessdate=9 September 2008 }}</ref>
2006 research found that 82 percent of South Africans played the lottery once a week and that 53 percent of the population did not engage in any other form of gambling. The average player spent R81 per month on the lottery.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=139&art_id=vn20060704110644806C771759 |title=SA starting to gamble sensibly, says report |publisher=Independent Online |accessdate=9 September 2008 }}</ref>
==Revenue distribution== Under the current operator, Ithuba, 34 percent of revenue is paid to a central charitable distribution fund, up from an initial 28 percent.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=15&art_id=vn20070303104345199C447691 |title=Gidani set for lotto high stakes |publisher=Independent Online |accessdate=15 September 2008 }}</ref> Six percent of revenue is paid as retail commission, ten percent is retained as operational costs and 50 percent is paid in prizes.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=196&art_id=vn20071217050216249C970783 |title=Gidani boss strikes family off Lotto roll |publisher=Independent Online |accessdate=15 September 2008 }}</ref>
==Previous lotteries in South Africa== The now defunct homeland of [[Ciskei]] established a lottery in 1984 and operated by Score-A-Lot. In 1991 Score-A-Lot was the first Lottery in Africa to operate Video Lottery Terminals (VLT) in Africa and the first totally cashless operation using smart card technology. After lengthy negotiations with South Africans "Department of Trade and Industry" (DTI) Score-A-Lot closed in Dec 2001<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nlb.org.za/upload/AnnualReports/LottoAnnualReport2003.pdf |title=Annual Report of the National Lotteries Board, 2003 |publisher=National Lotteries Board |accessdate=9 September 2008 }}</ref> <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nlb.org.za/upload/AnnualReports/Annual%20Report%202004.pdf |title=Annual Report of the National Lotteries Board, 2004 |publisher=National Lotteries Board |accessdate=9 September 2008 }}</ref>
A lottery was established by decree in the former homeland of [[Transkei]] in 1989 and operated by Score-A-Lot. In 1991 Score-A-Lot was the first Lottery in Africa to operate Video Lottery Terminals (VLT) in Africa and the first totally cashless operation using smart card technology. After lengthy negotiations with South Africans "Department of Trade and Industry" (DTI) Score-A-Lot closed in Dec 2001<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dispatch.co.za/1999/04/12/easterncape/AAJUDGE.HTM |title=Judge calls for action on illegal gambling |publisher=The Daily Dispatch |accessdate=9 September 2008 }}</ref>
The Natal Lotto (also referred to as the KZN Lotto) was launched in the [[KwaZulu-Natal]] province in 1992.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=13&art_id=ct20010720085509798N343800 |title=KZN wishes it took a chance with old Lotto |publisher=Independent Online |accessdate=9 September 2008 }}</ref> During eight years of operation it raised R869 million and paid R345 million to charities and R448 million in prize money.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=13&art_id=ct20011102192953495K543172 |title=Lotto KZN lives on in its charitable work |publisher=Independent Online |accessdate=9 September 2008 }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Uthingo]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://www.nlb.org.za National Lotteries Board]

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2018}} {{italic title}} {{Infobox play | name = The Anarchist | image = FelicityHuffmanHWoFMar2012.jpg | alt = | caption = Felicity Huffman played one of the lead roles in the 2015 revival of Mamet's play ''The Anarchist'' (photo 2014). | writer = [[David Mamet]] | chorus = | characters = | mute = | setting = [[Prison]] [[parole]] review office | premiere = 2012<!-- {{Start date|df=yes|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | place = [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] | orig_lang = English | series = | subject = | genre = [[Drama]] | web = }} '''''The Anarchist''''' is a two-person 2012 play by [[David Mamet]] that opened in New York on Broadway and starred [[Patti LuPone]] and [[Debra Winger]].<ref name=Brantley/> The "anarchist" of the title has its origin related to and perhaps based upon members of the [[Weather Underground]], [[Judith Clark]] and [[Kathy Boudin]], former members of the Weather Underground, who took part in the [[Brink's robbery (1981)]].<ref name=Lahr>{{cite news|last1=Lahr|first1=John|title=Rough Justice|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2012/12/10/rough-justice|accessdate=29 July 2015|publisher=The New Yorker|date=10 December 2012}}</ref>
==Plot==
The play is set in the office of a prison parole review officer who is seen questioning and conducting an extended interview with a long-term prisoner incarcerated for a [[Weather Underground]]-type crime during which she killed two police officers.<ref name=Brantley>{{cite news|last1=Brantley|first1=Ben|title=War of Wills, Vocabularies and Virtues|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/03/theater/reviews/david-mamets-anarchist-at-the-golden-theater.html|accessdate=29 July 2015|publisher=New York Times|date=2 December 2012}}</ref><ref name=Nichols/> The outcome denies the long-term prisoner access to parole based on the harsh nature of the crime and the lack of remorse shown for her crimes.
==Reception==
The New York production of the play was not well-received by critics.<ref name=Trueman>{{cite news|last1=Trueman|title=David Mamet's The Anarchist bombs on Broadway|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2012/dec/05/david-mamet-anarchist-broadway|accessdate=29 July 2015|publisher=The Guardian|date=5 December 2012}}</ref> Writing in his ''[[The New York Times|New York Times]]'' review of 2 December 2012, [[Ben Brantley]] wrote: "Mr. Mamet has always been preoccupied with words both as power tools and as camouflage. That’s true whether the language is lowdown (as in 'Glengarry' and '[[American Buffalo (play)|American Buffalo]]') or high-flown (as in '[[Oleanna (play)|Oleanna]]'). This has often involved a certain verbal self-consciousness among his characters. But it has never been as acute as in 'The Anarchist,' in which both women are especially aware of words as instruments of misdirection and what Cathy calls the opacity of human motives. Theatergoers must really furrow their brows here just to follow the basic arguments, never mind the layers of motivation woven into them. And without giving away too much, I think it’s fair to reveal 'Anarchist' basically concludes that all those polysyllabic words mean nothing, when you come right down to it. Right is right, and wrong is wrong. When you reach the end of 'Anarchist,' you may feel you’ve traveled an unnecessarily winding road to get there."
Having officially opened on Sunday 2 December 2012, producers posted closing notices the following Wednesday and cut the run short on 16 December, after only 23 previews and 17 performances.<ref>https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2012/dec/05/david-mamet-anarchist-broadway</ref>
The play opened in Madrid at the same time<ref name="teatroespanol.es">http://teatroespanol.es/descargas/dossier_la_anarquista%5B2%5D.pdf</ref> to positive reviews.<ref>http://cultura.elpais.com/cultura/2013/01/14/actualidad/1358180341_938232.html</ref> ''La anarquista'' was directed by José Pascual with [[Magüi Mira]] as Cathy (the anarchist) and Ana Wagener as Ann (the prison officer).<ref name="teatroespanol.es"/>
The play had a 2015 production in Los Angeles, directed by [[Marja-Lewis Ryan]] with [[Felicity Huffman]] and [[Rebecca Pidgeon]].<ref name=Nichols>{{cite news|last1=Nichols|first1=David|title='Anarchist's' artful words don't make satisfying drama|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/arts/la-et-cm-review-the-anarchist-at-theatre-asylum-20150428-story.html|accessdate=29 July 2015|publisher=LA Times|date=30 April 2015}}</ref><ref name=Ng>{{cite news|last1=Ng|first1=David|title='The Anarchist' by David Mamet coming to L.A. with Felicity Huffman|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/arts/culture/la-et-cm-anarchist-david-mamet-felicity-huffman-rebecca-pidgeon-20150309-story.html|accessdate=29 July 2015|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=9 March 2015}}</ref>
The play had its Ohio premiere on July 1 and 2, 2017, at the Van Fleet Theatre in Columbus.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://digital.olivesoftware.com/Olive/ODN/ColumbusDispatch/Default.aspx|title=The Anarchist|last=Grossberg|first=Michael|date=29 June 2017|work=The Columbus Dispatch: Weekender|access-date=3 July 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> It was produced by Stage Right Theatrics, the country's only conservative theatre [http://conservativefestivaloh.com organization], and was chosen because of Mamet's much publicized conversion to conservatism in 2008.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.villagevoice.com/2008/03/11/david-mamet-why-i-am-no-longer-a-brain-dead-liberal/|title=David Mamet: Why I am No Longer a 'Brain-Dead Liberal.'|last=Mamet|first=David|date=11 March 2008|website=The Village Voice|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=3 July 2017}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2012}} {{Infobox album | italic_title = force | name = The Book of Mormon:
Original Broadway Cast Recording | type = Cast | artist = [[Andrew Rannells]], [[Josh Gad]], [[Rory O'Malley]], [[Nikki M. James]], and Original Broadway Cast | cover = The Book of Mormon soundtrack.jpg | border = yes | alt = | released = May 17, 2011 | recorded = March 21, 22 and 28, 2011 at [[Right Track Recording|MSR Studios]] (Studio A), (New York City) | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Showtunes]], [[musical comedy]] | length = 67:54 | label = [[Ghostlight Records]] | producer = [[Stephen Oremus]], [[Trey Parker]], [[Robert Lopez]], [[Matt Stone]], Anne Garefino, [[Scott Rudin]] and [[Kurt Deutsch]] ([[executive producer|exec.]]) | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} '''''The Book of Mormon: Original Broadway Cast Recording''''' contains the songs from the American musical ''[[The Book of Mormon (musical)|The Book of Mormon]]'', with music, lyrics, and book by Trey Parker, Robert Lopez, and Matt Stone. It was recorded by the musical's original Broadway cast and released on May 17, 2011 to digital outlets. The album saw a physical release on June 7, 2011, in a deluxe package with liner notes provided by former ''[[The New York Times]]'' theatre critic [[Frank Rich]], as well as full lyrics and a synopsis of the musical. ''The Book of Mormon'' was named best musical theater album at the [[2012 Grammy Awards]].{{cite news|last=Kennedy|first=Gerrick D.|title=Grammys 2012: Backstage with 'Book of Mormon' winner Trey Parker|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/culturemonster/2012/02/grammy-awards-2012-backstage-with-trey-parker-book-of-mormom.html|accessdate=February 14, 2012|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=February 13, 2012}} Parker, Lopez, and Stone wrote the musical progressively over a period of six years, beginning in 2004. The recording for the album took place over three days, with the orchestra recording for one and the cast recording for another. [[Stephen Oremus]], Parker, Lopez, and Stone were the primary producers of the album. ''The Book of Mormon'' original cast recording was recorded at [[MSR Studios]], Studio A in New York City. The record has received positive reviews. The recording received substantial commercial success after its initial digital release broke [[iTunes Store]] records and the subsequent album made a relatively strong debut on the US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] chart. After the show's success at the [[2011 Tony Awards]] and an aggressive marketing campaign, the recording skyrocketed to number 3 on the chart and became the highest charting Broadway cast album in over four decades. A [[Gramophone record|vinyl]] version is planned.{{Cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/article/the-book-of-mormon-is-going-vinyl|title=The Book of Mormon Is Going Vinyl|last=Gans|first=Andrew|date=June 23, 2016|website=Playbill|access-date=2016-06-24}} ==Recording and post-production== The cast recording for ''The Book of Mormon'' was recorded on March 21, 22 and 28, 2011.{{cite AV media notes |title=The Book of Mormon |titlelink=The Book of Mormon (musical album) |others=the Original Broadway Cast |year=2011 |type=booklet |publisher=[[Ghostlight Records]] |id=B004X1M4DS |location=New York City }} The two former dates were shortly before the show officially opened and the latter was days afterward.{{cite news|first = Peggy Fletcher|last = Stack|authorlink = Peggy Fletcher Stack|url = http://www.sltrib.com/sltrib/news/51314880-78/mormon-lds-book-mormons.html.csp|title = ‘Book of Mormon’ musical called surprisingly sweet|publisher = [[The Salt Lake Tribune]]|date = February 25, 2011}} The record was recorded at Studio A in MSR Studios (formerly [[Right Track Recording]]) in New York City. The show's creators, Trey Parker, Matt Stone, and Robert Lopez, served as producers for the album, as did ''The Book of Mormon'' producers Anne Garefino and [[Scott Rudin]]. In addition, [[Stephen Oremus]] (music director for ''[[Wicked (musical)|Wicked]]'') and [[Kurt Deutsch]] (co-founder of [[Sh-K-Boom Records]], owner of Ghostlight Records) also served as producer and executive producer, respectively. Because of payment schedules imposed by union rules, Broadway cast recordings are traditionally recorded over a single 15-hour day, with all instruments and vocals tracked together. In addition to reducing costs, this approach enables the singers to control the tempo of the songs. But according to Frank Filipetti, who both recorded and mixed the album, ''The Book of Mormon'''s complex vocal arrangements called for a different strategy in which the instrumental tracks were recorded first, followed by a separate day dedicated to the cast. Filipetti said that the arrangements had "vocal parts within vocal parts within vocal parts. Trying to do all of that with the principal singers, rhythm section, orchestra, all in two or three takes in an all-day session wasn’t going to work." He credited Oremus and drummer Sean McDaniel for being able to anticipate the singers' phrasing. Other mixing challenges included "creating enough air and clarity for all the vocalists while still maintaining the vibrancy of [Lopez's] orchestral arrangements", as well as dealing with the score's wide range of musical styles.{{cite news|last=Weiss|first=David|title=Inside “The Book of Mormon” Cast Recording: Frank Filipetti Breaks Broadway’s Rules|url=http://www.sonicscoop.com/2011/06/08/inside-the-book-of-mormon-cast-recording-frank-filipetti-breaks-broadways-rules/|accessdate=July 7, 2011|newspaper=Sonicscoop|date=June 8, 2011}} Oremus and Lopez were heavily involved in the orchestra recording, whereas Stone and Parker were more invested in the vocal session. According to Filipetti, their main concern was making sure the jokes were coming across. The album was recorded to [[Pro Tools]] as to allow for multiple tracks of recordings to be present in the final cut. Mixing and mastering were done in April at Filipetti's studio in [[West Nyack, New York]]. The album was mastered by [[Scott Hull (mastering engineer)|Scott Hull]].{{cite web|title=Book of Mormon [Original Broadway Cast]|url=http://albumcredits.com/Album/2191672#/Album/ProductionCredits/2191672|publisher=albumcredits.com|accessdate=26 July 2012}} Filipetti set up Source Connect to enable the core producers—Oremus, Lopez, Parker and Stone—to listen in on the session in real time from Manhattan, with [[Skype]] providing an audio/video connection between the two locations. ==Track listing== {{Tracklist | all_writing = [[Trey Parker]], [[Robert Lopez]], [[Matt Stone]] | extra_column = Performer(s) | title1 = Hello! | extra1 = [[Andrew Rannells]], [[Josh Gad]], [[Rory O'Malley]], Scott Barnhardt, Justin Bohon, Kevin Duda, Clark Johnsen, Benjamin Schrader, Brian Sears, Jason Michael Snow, [[Lewis Cleale]] | length1 = 2:51 | title2 = Two By Two | extra2 = Andrew Rannells, Josh Gad, Rory O'Malley, Scott Barnhardt, Justin Bohon, Kevin Duda, Clark Johnsen, Benjamin Schrader, Brian Sears, Jason Michael Snow, Lewis Cleale | length2 = 4:30 | title3 = You and Me (But Mostly Me) | extra3 = Andrew Rannells, Josh Gad | length3 = 2:41 | title4 = Hasa Diga Eebowai | extra4 = Michael Potts, Andrew Rannells, Josh Gad, Michael James Scott, Lawrence Stallings, Rema Webb, Maia Nkenge Wilson, Tommar Wilson, Darlesia Cearcy, John Eric Parker, Ta'Rea Campbell, [[Tyson Jennette]], [[Brian Tyree Henry]] | length4 = 4:23 | title5 = Turn It Off | extra5 = Rory O'Malley, Andrew Rannells, Josh Gad, Scott Barnhardt, Justin Bohon, Kevin Duda, Clark Johnsen, Benjamin Schrader, Brian Sears, Jason Michael Snow | length5 = 5:00 | title6 = I Am Here for You | extra6 = Andrew Rannells, Josh Gad | length6 = 2:02 | title7 = All-American Prophet | extra7 = Andrew Rannells, Josh Gad, Rory O'Malley, Scott Barnhardt, Justin Bohon, Kevin Duda, Clark Johnsen, Benjamin Schrader, Brian Sears, Jason Michael Snow, Lewis Cleale, [[Jared Gertner]], Graham Bowen, Nick Spangler, Michael James Scott | length7 = 6:12 | title8 = Sal Tlay Ka Siti | extra8= [[Nikki M. James]] | length8 = 3:38 | title9 = Man Up | extra9 = Josh Gad, Company | length9 = 4:02 | title10 = Making Things Up Again | extra10 = Josh Gad, Lewis Cleale, Nikki M. James, Rory O'Malley, Scott Barnhardt, Asmeret Gebremichael, John Eric Parker, Michael James Scott, Brian Sears, Rema Webb, Ensemble | length10 = 4:16 | title11 = Spooky Mormon Hell Dream | extra11 = Benjamin Schrader, Kevin Duda, Brian Tyree Henry, Maia Nkenge Wilson, Lewis Cleale, Andrew Rannells, Michael Potts, Ensemble | length11 = 4:28 | title12 = I Believe | extra12 = Andrew Rannells, Ensemble | length12 = 4:42 | title13 = Baptize Me | extra13 = Josh Gad, Nikki M. James | length13 = 4:15 | title14= I Am Africa | extra14 = Rory O'Malley, Scott Barnhardt, Justin Bohon, Kevin Duda, Josh Gad, Clark Johnsen, Benjamin Schrader, Brian Sears, Jason Michael Snow | length14 = 2:21 | title15 = Joseph Smith American Moses | extra15 = Nikki M. James, Michael Potts, Michael James Scott, Lawrence Stallings, Rema Webb, Maia Nkenge Wilson, Tommar Wilson, Darlesia Cearcy, John Eric Parker, Ta'Rea Campbell, Tyson Jennette, Brian Tyree Henry | length15 = 6:12 | title16 = Tomorrow Is a Latter Day | extra16 = Andrew Rannells, Josh Gad, Nikki M. James, Company | length16 = 6:02 }} ===Song parody sources=== In the recording's liner notes, [[Frank Rich]] wrote that ''The Book of Mormon'' "scrupulously follows the old testament of Broadway circa 1945–1965, A.D., even while fondly spoofing it". He compares "I Believe” to “[[I Have Confidence]]” from ''[[The Sound of Music]]'', the opening number "Hello!" to “The Telephone Hour” in ''[[Bye Bye Birdie (musical)|Bye Bye Birdie]]'', and “Turn It Off” to “I’ll Never Be Jealous Again” from ''[[The Pajama Game]]''. Other songs, he writes, owe much to the parodies of [[Tom Lehrer]].{{cite web|last=Rich|first=Frank|title=Frank Rich’s Liner Notes for ''The Book of Mormon''|url=http://www.playbill.com/playblog/2011/05/frank-richs-liner-notes-for-the-book-of-mormon/|work=Playbill|accessdate=June 20, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110625214159/http://www.playbill.com/playblog/2011/05/frank-richs-liner-notes-for-the-book-of-mormon/|archivedate=June 25, 2011|df=mdy-all}} Kristin Rawls, in her critique of the score, draws several parallels to other musicals. She likens "I Believe" to "I Have Confidence" from ''The Sound of Music'', citing similarities in their lyrics. She also makes a comparison between the Ugandans' version and presentation of Joseph Smith's story in "Joseph Smith American Moses" to "Uncle Tom's Cabin" from ''[[The King and I]]'', as well as the recalling and overlap of previous numbers in "Man Up" to ''[[Les Misérables (musical)|Les Misérables]]'''s "One Day More".{{cite web|last=Rawls|first=Kristin|title=The Mormons Take Manhattan: ''The Book of Mormon'' soundtrack on God, Broadway and Africa|url=http://globalcomment.com/2011/the-book-of-mormon-soundtrack-on-god-broadway-and-africa/}} Other observers have made other comparisons, arguing, for example, that "You and Me (But Mostly Me)" references "The Wizard and I" from ''[[Wicked (musical)|Wicked]]'', that "All-American Prophet" is a throw-back to ''[[The Music Man]]''{{'}}s "[[Ya Got Trouble]]"; and that "Hasa Diga Eebowai" spoofs "[[Hakuna Matata (song)|Hakuna Matata]]" from ''[[The Lion King (musical)|The Lion King]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.ology.com/arts/album-review-book-mormon |title=Album Review: ''The Book of Mormon''|publisher=Ology.com|date=June 2, 2011 |accessdate=June 8, 2011}} ==Release== As the audio was being [[Audio mixing (recorded music)|mixed]], the musical's popularity exploded, giving the show a much higher profile than when the album was first recorded. The cast album was promoted through advertisements running during Parker and Stone's ''[[South Park]]'' on [[Comedy Central]]. A free preview of the entire recording was released on [[NPR]] starting on May 9, 2011.{{cite web |url= http://www.playbill.com/news/article/150631-NPR-Now-Offering-Free-Listen-to-Entire-Original-Cast-Recording-of-The-Book-of-Mormon |title= NPR Now Offering Free Listen to Entire Original Cast Recording of The Book of Mormon |work= Playbill |date= May 9, 2011 |accessdate= May 19, 2011 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110516001532/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/150631-NPR-Now-Offering-Free-Listen-to-Entire-Original-Cast-Recording-of-The-Book-of-Mormon |archivedate= May 16, 2011 |df= mdy-all }}{{cite web |url=http://sh-k-boom.com/bookofmormon.shtml |title=The Book of Mormon – Original Cast Recording – CD | Sh-K-Boom & Ghostlight Records |publisher=Sh-k-boom.com |accessdate=May 19, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110515134116/http://sh-k-boom.com/bookofmormon.shtml |archivedate=May 15, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite web |url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/150224-The-Book-of-Mormon-Cast-Album-Will-Get-Digital-Release-May-17-In-Store-to-Follow-in-June |title=The Book of Mormon Cast Album Will Get Digital Release May 17; In-Store to Follow in June |work=Playbill |accessdate=May 19, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110616111618/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/150224-The-Book-of-Mormon-Cast-Album-Will-Get-Digital-Release-May-17-In-Store-to-Follow-in-June |archivedate=June 16, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} Excerpts from the cast recording are featured in an extended ''[[Fresh Air]]'' interview. ===Commercial performance=== During its first week of its [[iTunes Store]] release, the recording became "the fastest-selling Broadway cast album in iTunes history", according to representatives for the production, ranking No. 2 on its day of release on the iTunes Top 10 Chart.{{cite web|url=http://broadwayworld.com/article/BOOK-OF-MORMON-Cast-Recording-Named-Fastest-Selling-Ever-20110525 |title=''The Book of Mormon'' Cast Recording Named Fastest Selling Digital Release |publisher=BroadwayWorld.com |date=May 25, 2011 |accessdate=May 28, 2011}} According to ''[[Playbill]]'', "It's a rare occurrence for a Broadway [[cast album]] to place among the iTunes best sellers. The cast album for the [[Green Day]] musical ''[[American Idiot (musical)|American Idiot]]'' also ranked among the top 10 when it debuted in 2010."{{cite web |url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/151019-The-Book-of-Mormon-Cast-Album-Debuts-on-iTunes-Top-10-Chart |title=The Book of Mormon Cast Album Debuts on iTunes Top 10 Chart |author=Adam Hetrick |work=Playbill |date=May 19, 2011 |accessdate=May 19, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110522165628/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/151019-The-Book-of-Mormon-Cast-Album-Debuts-on-iTunes-Top-10-Chart |archivedate=May 22, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} The album debuted at number 31 on the US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] chart, with first-week sales of 13,000. The start for ''The Book of Mormon'' was also the best debut sales week for a cast set since ''[[The Little Mermaid (musical)|The Little Mermaid]]'' cast album in 2008. The cast album also started at No. 1 on the Top Cast Albums chart – the 24th topper since the list began in 2006.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/470971/the-book-of-mormon-cast-album-scores-impressive-chart-debut|title=''The Book of Mormon'' Cast Album Scores Impressive Chart Debut|author=Keith Caulfield|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=May 26, 2011 |accessdate=June 8, 2011}} After its initial success, the record fell to number 124 on the ''Billboard'' 200 with only 4,000 copies sold, and soon fell off the chart. However, after the show's success at the [[2011 Tony Awards]], ''The Book of Mormon'' cast album broke sales records again when it skyrocketed up the ''Billboard'' charts back to number 3 on the ''Billboard'' 200 on June 15, making it the highest charting Broadway cast album–and first top 10–since 1969, when ''[[Hair (Original Broadway Cast Recording)|Hair]]'' spent 13 straight weeks at No. 1.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/470542/adele-reclaims-no-1-on-billboard-200-book-of-mormon-makes-history|title=Adele Reclaims No. 1 on ''Billboard'' 200, ''Book of Mormon'' Makes History|author=Keith Caulfield|work=Billboard |date=June 15, 2011 |accessdate=June 15, 2011}} It sold over 61,000 copies, the largest sales week for any cast album since [[Nielsen SoundScan]] began tracking data in 1991. The previous best sales week for a cast set belonged to the original London cast recording of ''[[The Phantom of the Opera (1986 musical)#Recordings|Highlights from The Phantom of the Opera]]'', which sold 54,000 over the Christmas week of 1992.{{cite web|url=http://www.nypost.com/p/entertainment/music/book_of_mormon_cast_album_breaks_I24Y3jOIIzVrPRWhZml2cM|title=''Book of Mormon'' cast album breaks sales record|work=New York Post |date=June 15, 2011 |accessdate=June 15, 2011}} Many news outlets attributed its chart success not only to its physical release on June 7 and publicity from the Tony Awards, but to [[Amazon MP3]]'s sale pricing of the digital album.{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/on-the-charts-amazon-gives-book-of-mormon-soundtrack-a-huge-boost-20110615|title=On the Charts: Amazon Gives ''Book of Mormon'' Soundtrack a Huge Boost|author=Steve Knopper|work=Rolling Stone |date=June 15, 2011 |accessdate=June 15, 2011}} The retailer offered it at just $1.99 for three days during the sales tracking week that ended on Sunday (the night of the Tony broadcast). Amazon MP3 promoted the record aggressively through Twitter and through a commercial in the Tony Awards telecast. As a result, 85 percent of the sales were digital downloads, a much higher ratio than usual.{{cite web|url=http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/06/15/from-tonys-to-billboard-chart-good-week-for-book-of-mormon/|title=From Tonys to Billboard Chart: Good Week for ''Book of Mormon''|author=Ben Sisario|work=The New York Times |date=June 15, 2011 |accessdate=June 15, 2011}} ===Critical reception=== Matthew Perpetua of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' complimented the recording's witty lyrics and memorable songs and stated the album would leave listeners "desperate to score tickets to see the actual show".{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/listen-to-the-hilarious-and-ridiculously-catchy-book-of-mormon-20110526 |title=Listen to the Hilarious and Ridiculously Catchy ''Book of Mormon''|last=Perpetua |first=Matthew |work=Rolling Stone |date=May 26, 2011 |accessdate=May 28, 2011}} David Jeffries of [[Allmusic]] stated that the music's style was vivid but traditional and the songs were "inspired" and provided a mixture of the "satirical, controversial, and the musical", but noted their coarse and blasphemic nature in his recommendation.{{cite web|last=Jeffries|first=David|title=The Book of Mormon – Review|publisher=Allmusic|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/the-book-of-mormon-r2191672/review|accessdate=June 15, 2011}} ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{Trey Parker and Matt Stone}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Book of Mormon Cast Recording}} [[Category:Cast recordings]] [[Category:Latter Day Saints in popular culture]] [[Category:2011 soundtracks]] [[Category:Theatre soundtracks]] [[Category:Works by Trey Parker and Matt Stone]]

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/101.164.190.70|101.164.190.70]] ([[User talk:101.164.190.70|talk]]): This name is correct. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
[[File:Twistaplot.jpg|thumb|The cover for the first book in the series, written by [[R. L. Stine]].]] '''Twistaplot''' is a series of [[children's literature|children's]] [[gamebooks]], that were published by [[Scholastic Corporation|Scholastic]] from 1982 to 1985. Books #1, #4, #9 and #14 were written by [[R.L. Stine]], who would go on to write the ''[[Fear Street]]'' series, and the ''[[Goosebumps]]'' series, which in turn, spawned the gamebook spin-off series, ''[[Give Yourself Goosebumps]]''. The remaining books were written by various authors including [[Louise Munro Foley]]. They were [[Scholastic Corporation|Scholastic]]'s response to the ''[[Choose Your Own Adventure]]'' series. After the success of the ''[[Goosebumps]]'' series, the books which were written by [[R. L. Stine]] were reissued with new covers in 1994 and 1995.
==Style and gameplay== Twistaplot covers a wide variety of genres, including [[science fiction]], [[fantasy]], and [[Horror fiction|horror]]. Similar to the ''[[Give Yourself Goosebumps]]'' series, they are [[novels]] with branching plots. The books are written from the second-person perspective, in present-tense form. The protagonist in each book is never referred to by name, and the protagonist's gender is ambiguous. Thus the reader can easily imagine himself/herself as the protagonist of the storyline. But unlike the ''[[Give Yourself Goosebumps]]'' series, the books have interior illustrations.
==Spin-offs== After the success of Twistaplot, the series spawned a series of computer games for Scholastic's electronic magazine, ''Microzine''. It also spawned another gamebook spin-off titled ''Pick-a-Path'', which was intended for a younger audience.
==Books== ===Twistaplot=== #''The Time Raider'' #''The Train of Terror'' #''The Formula for Trouble'' #''Golden Sword of Dragonwalk'' #''The Sinister Studios of KESP-TV'' #''Crash Landing!'' #''The Video Avenger'' #''Race into the Past'' #''Horrors of the Haunted Museum'' #''Mission of the Secret Spy Squad'' #''Camp-Out on Danger Mountain'' #''Journey to Vernico 5'' #''Midnight at Monster Mansion'' #''Instant Millionaire'' #''Spellcaster'' #''Secrets of the Lost Island'' #''Ghost Riders of Goldspur'' #''Calling Outer Space''
===Pick-a-Path=== #''The Dandee Diamond Mystery'' #''The Roller Coaster Ghost'' #''The Great Baseball Championship'' #''The Amazing Bubblegum Caper'' #''The Super Trail Bike Race'' #''Mystery at Mockingbird Manor'' #''The Fantastic Journey of the Space Shuttle Astra'' #''The Magic Top Mystery'' #''Jungle Adventure'' #''The Mystery of the Missing Mummy'' #''Dinosaur Adventure'' #''The Ballerina Mystery'' #''The Secret of 13'' #''RIM, The Rebel Robot'' #''The Hot Dog Gang Caper'' #''Adventure at Camp Schoonover'' #''Murf the Monster''
==See also== * [[R. L. Stine]] * ''[[Give Yourself Goosebumps]]'' * ''[[Choose Your Own Adventure]]'' * [[Scholastic Corporation]] * [[Parachute Press]] * [[Louise Munro Foley]]
==External links== *[http://www.gamebooks.org/show_series.php?id=319 Twistaplot at Gamebooks.org]
[[Category:Gamebooks]] [[Category:Series of children's books]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Yisrael Poliakov | image = Yisrael Poliakov.jpg | imagesize = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = July 7, 1941 | birth_place = [[Jerusalem]], [[Israel]] | death_date = {{death date and age|mf=yes|2007|10|30|1941|07|07}} | death_place = [[Petah Tikva]], [[Israel]] | othername = | yearsactive = 1964–2007 | spouse = Shoshana | website = | imdbid = 0689082 }} '''Yisrael "Poli" Poliakov''' ([[Hebrew]]: ישראל פוליאקוב) (July 7, 1941 – October 30, 2007) was an [[Israel]]i [[comedian]] and actor. Poliakov was born in [[Jerusalem]], and grew up in [[Tel Aviv]]. He became one of the three members of the Israeli comedy group, [[HaGashash HaHiver]] (The Pale Tracker).{{cite news |first= Shelly |last= Paz |title= Comic icon Yisrael 'Poli' Poliakov dies at 66 |url= https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/jpost/access/1375448841.html?did=1375448841&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT |publisher= (Note: free summary links to full, fee-based article) [[Jerusalem Post]] |date=October 31, 2007 |accessdate=December 3, 2007}} ==Career== Poliakov originally chose a career as a farmer and studied at the [[HaKfar HaYarok|Kfar HaYarok]] agricultural high school. This changed when he was spotted at a school party by members of [[Nahal Brigade]]'s entertainment [[:wikt:troupe|troupe]], and he was soon recruited by the group. In 1961, he joined the original singing band [[Hatarnegolim]] (The Roosters) that had been founded by [[Naomi Polani]], the original cast of which broke up in 1964.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=B9RV5UFtPNMC&pg=PA513&dq=Neomi+Polani#v=onepage&q=peloni&f=false |title=The World Encyclopedia of Contemporary Theatre: Europe |publisher= |year=1999 |author=Don Rubin |accessdate=July 31, 2011|isbn=9780415251570 }}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=kAxLAn6sOb4C&pg=PA111&dq=Naomi+Polani#v=onepage&q=Naomi%20Polani&f=false |title=Popular music and national culture in Israel |publisher= |year= 2004|author= Motti Regev, Edwin Seroussi |accessdate=July 31, 2011|isbn=9780520236547 }}{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/jpost/access/42396744.html?dids=42396744:42396744&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=Jun+13%2C+1999&author=Ury+Eppstein%2C+Michael+Ajzenstadt&pub=Jerusalem+Post&desc=These+chicks+have+got+to+grow&pqatl=google |title=These chicks have got to grow |work=The Jerusalem Post |date=June 13, 1999 |author=Ury Eppstein, Michael Ajzenstadt |accessdate=July 31, 2011}} Poliakov appeared in a number of famous Israeli films, often with members of HaGashash HaHiver. His film credits include ''[[The Hit (Israeli film)|Schlager]]'' (The Hit) in 1979; ''Krav al Hava'ad'' (The House Committee) in 1986; and ''Givat Halfon Eina Ona'' (Halfon Hill Doesn't Answer) in 1975. He appeared in a number of Israeli television roles, and produced and acted in his daughter's television show, ''[[It's All Honey]]''. Poliakov began working on stage as a theater actor in 2000. His credits include ''[[The Israeli Family]]'', ''[[The Rubber Merchants]]'', ''God's Finger'', ''[[Mother Courage]]'' and ''The Return of Moris Shpigelman''. ===HaGashash HaHiver=== [[Abraham Deshe|Abraham "Pashanel" Deshe]], a producer and [[Talent agent|agent]] who died of cancer in 2004 at age 78, started HaGashash HaHiver in late 1963. The group was composed of three members – Poliakov, [[Yeshayahu Levy|Yeshayahu "Shaike" Levy]] and [[Gavriel Banai|Gavriel "Gavri" Banai]]. They created a "unique Israeli comedy group," according to the Jerusalem Post. Their jokes, which included the best and worst of [[Demography of Israel|Israeli society]], often achieved a [[cult status]] among fans. In 2000, the group and its three members were awarded the [[Israel Prize]] for lifetime achievement & special contribution to society for their work.{{Cite web| title = Israel Prize Official Site (in Hebrew) – Recipients’ C.V. | url = http://cms.education.gov.il/EducationCMS/Units/PrasIsrael/Tashas/Hagashas/KorotHayimGashash.htm}} The judges wrote of their award decision:
The uniqueness of HaGashash HaHiver is in its two faces: On the one hand, it reflects the life and the culture that were created in Israel during its first 50 years and in the course of wars, immigration absorption and the struggle for its existence. On the other hand, it has taken an active role in shaping this culture, creating its language and sketching its identity.... Their language, Gashashit, and the images they created broke the walls of the inflexible Hebrew language and became standard idiomatic phrases, so much so that he who doesn't know them doesn't know a large part of the culture that has sprouted here. Phrases such as, 'Drive in peace, the keys are inside,' 'There was an engine?' [referring to a mechanic who cheats a client], 'Israbluff' and many others that became part of our everyday language.{{Cite web| title = Israel Prize Official Site (in Hebrew) – Judges' Rationale for Grant to Recipients | url = http://cms.education.gov.il/EducationCMS/Units/PrasIsrael/Tashas/Hagashas/NimukeiAshoftimGashash.htm}}
==Death== Yisrael Poliakov died of cancer at the Rabin Medical Center-Beilinson Campus in [[Petah Tikva]] on October 30, 2007, at the age of 66, following a two-week hospitalization for heart problems. Poliakov's coffin was taken to [[Cameri Theater]] in Tel Aviv for a public [[funeral|memorial service]], and was buried in a cemetery in [[Kibbutz]] [[Einat]]. Fellow HaGashash HaHiver member Yeshayahu Levy told [[Israel Army Radio]]: "...lost a brother. There is no other word. We've been together since 1958, and he was part of me. He was a great talent, an outstanding comic actor, and a wonderful friend... The pain is great." Actor [[Moshe Ivgi]], who costarred with Poliakov in ''The Rubber Merchant'', told the Jerusalem Post: "He was a great actor who was blessed with comic and dramatic qualities, and it was a pleasure to work with him. Poli was a modest and ego-free man, full of love, and I am sure he would have done so much more." President [[Shimon Peres]] stated "Generations upon generations watched him and fell captive to his charm".{{cite news |title= Israeli comic 'Poli' dies |url= http://www.jewishledger.com/articles/2007/11/19/west_mass/lifecycle/obituaries/obit05.txt |publisher= [[Jewish Ledger]] |date=November 13, 2007 |accessdate=December 3, 2007}} ==See also== *[[List of Israel Prize recipients]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb name|id=0689082|name=Yisrael Poliakov}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Poliakov, Yisrael}} [[Category:Israeli comedians]] [[Category:Israeli male film actors]] [[Category:Israeli male stage actors]] [[Category:Israeli male television actors]] [[Category:Israeli people of Russian-Jewish descent]] [[Category:Israel Prize for lifetime achievement & special contribution to society recipients]] [[Category:People from Jerusalem]] [[Category:1941 births]] [[Category:2007 deaths]] [[Category:Deaths from cancer in Israel]] [[Category:Israeli entertainers]] [[Category:20th-century Israeli male actors]] [[Category:21st-century Israeli male actors]]
